text:
'Garbage in, garbage out'**
Charging families for each bag of rubbish they throw away seems like a good idea for the environment and for saving money. However, it might not be. In many developed countries, the way we collect rubbish is similar. Rubbish bags or bins are picked up regularly by special trucks and taken to a dump. Economists find this strange because, in most places, this service is free. Households pay for it through local taxes, but a family that throws away four bags of rubbish each week pays the same as an elderly couple that only throws away one bag. However, rubbish disposal does cost money. The more rubbish people throw away, the more rubbish collectors and trucks are needed, and the more local authorities have to pay for dumping it. This creates a basic economic problem: if rubbish disposal is free, people will throw away too much rubbish. 
One solution is to make households pay for the cost of throwing away their waste. This would encourage them to throw away less and recycle more, as long as local governments provide places to recycle. But two American economists, Don Fullerton and Thomas Kinnaman, found that this logical solution can have complicated and sometimes disappointing results. They studied several American towns that started charging households for rubbish. The most common method was to sell stickers or tags that people had to put on their rubbish bags or cans. Only bags with these tags were picked up during the weekly collection.
In a study published last year, Fullerton and Kinnaman looked at a scheme started in July 1992 in Charlottesville, Virginia, a town with about 40,000 people. Residents had to pay 80 cents for each tagged bag of rubbish. This seemed like a good use of market forces. However, the authors found that the benefits of the scheme did not cover the costs of printing the tags, paying sellers, and the workers running the program. Although the number of bags collected fell sharply by 37%, this was mainly because people started to cram more rubbish into each bag instead of buying more tags. This method, known as the 'Seattle stomp', is not as effective as using machines at landfill sites. The weight of rubbish collected fell by only 14% in Charlottesville. In 25 other Virginian cities without a pricing scheme, the weight of rubbish also fell by 3.5%.
Worse still, some people began to dump their rubbish illegally instead of paying for collection. Although it is hard to measure, the authors estimate that illegal dumping may account for 30-40% of the reduction in collected rubbish. The only positive outcome was a 15% increase in the weight of materials recycled, suggesting that people chose to recycle (which is free) instead of paying to have their rubbish taken away. However, this increase may not be directly related to the fee, as many people were already recycling in Charlottesville.
In a more recent study, Fullerton and Kinnaman looked at rubbish disposal in more detail. They found that charging for rubbish does reduce the amount of waste, but not by much. On average, a 10% increase in sticker prices only reduces the amount of rubbish by 0.3%. This is less than in other studies, but it is not surprising. To significantly reduce rubbish, people would need to buy less of everything. A small tax on rubbish is unlikely to make a big difference. 
If this is true, we should think about whether other factors, like income and education, are just as important as price. For example, in richer towns, people throw away more rubbish than in poorer towns, and they have less time to recycle. Should we say that charging households for rubbish is a bad idea? Not really; free disposal is probably too cheap. But the effects of simple policies can be complex. Detailed economic models are often needed to understand them, and sometimes the results are not very pleasant.

Theodore Zeldin talks about how our work life could change. Do you feel respected and appreciated at work? Success in a job is not enough anymore. Many people feel that their work is not valued or understood. Even famous people can feel unhappy despite their success. Loving your job used to be enough to make you special, but now you need to think about how your job affects you as a person, your mind, character, and relationships. This question is very important. No matter how skilled you are, if your work makes you boring and unable to talk to others, then no amount of money or status can make up for that.
Zeldin wants to find ways to make work more fulfilling and meaningful for everyone, not just a way to make money. Work should help us live better lives, discover new talents, and meet different people. However, just trying to end unemployment is not enough. As more people get educated, they want jobs that are interesting and helpful.
Even jobs that used to be respected, like doctors and accountants, are not as appealing anymore. Doctors often feel more stressed than their patients, and accountants worry about their profession's ethics. Many architects do not get to use their creativity, and managers feel stuck in their own rules. A study shows that many middle managers are losing their confidence. At the same time, companies and organizations are getting smaller. Efforts to improve decision-making and rewards have not made employees feel more committed. In Britain, only 8% of workers feel that their values match those of their organizations.
Zeldin is studying different jobs to see how they affect people. He is looking at important topics like happiness, love, friendship, and respect. Now, he is focusing on finding better ways to earn a living. Many experts work to help companies make more money, but we also need to think about ourselves as people and who we want to spend our time with.
How many of us feel truly alive at work? How many of us feel like we are stuck in our jobs, unable to leave because of our qualifications and careers? For example, many hotel workers are very smart and lively, but they often have low pay and long hours. This is because the idea of what a hotel is has not changed much since the Ritz, which represents old-fashioned luxury. A hotel is not just a place to sleep; it is a place where people from all over the world meet, even if they do not talk to each other.
Many hotel staff are foreigners who want to learn a new language and culture, but they often have only simple interactions with guests. Hotels could be cultural centers that connect guests with the city and each other. Hotel owners could use the knowledge of their staff instead of just giving them basic tasks. If they listened to their staff's dreams, they would see that hotels could offer many more services. However, accountants often tell them to focus only on making money.
It is time to rethink what work means, not just from a financial point of view, but from a human one. For Zeldin, work is about relationships. Many people want more than just following orders; they want to design their own jobs and choose their colleagues and customers. This requires good communication skills, which are different from just talking. Real conversation creates a bond of respect and helps us understand each other better. This kind of conversation is important for equality. Every time we have a meaningful conversation, we change the world a little bit.

'BROADCASTING: The Social Shaping of a Technology'**
The word 'broadcasting' originally meant to spread seeds widely by hand. This idea is not just about farming; it also represents hope for growth and success. It suggests that with the right conditions, we can achieve a good outcome. The idea of broadcasting assumes that there are central resources available to help spread information.
We need to understand why a new technology that sends words and pictures electronically was organized in a way that fits this farming idea. Television, as a technology, is connected to other forms of communication like the telegraph and the telephone. However, from the beginning, it was seen as a central 'mass' medium. This means that it was designed to send information from one central place to many homes, which matched the social and economic structures of modern societies.
There were some attempts to create different ways of using television. For example, in the early 1930s, radio enthusiasts in Britain experimented with two-way television, which could have replaced regular telephones. Popular science magazines like Radio News published articles on how to build television equipment, and many people tried these experiments. However, in 1938, big companies agreed on standards for television that pushed these amateur efforts aside. This marked the end of a chance for television to develop as a more community-based form of communication.
Broadcasting was not only influenced by strong economic interests but also by the social structures of modern life. In the early 1930s, television in the USA was mainly used for public shows and was seen as competition for the film industry. Most people in Britain and Germany experienced television in public places rather than at home.
The idea of community-based or amateur television was unlikely to succeed. Instead, television systems that focused on public viewing were common in several countries during the 1930s. However, manufacturers saw a chance to sell television sets for homes, and as living standards improved, more people could afford entertainment at home. This trend is now happening worldwide.
There is a clear link between social changes and the way broadcasting is organized. As societies modernized, power and wealth became more concentrated, and traditional communities broke apart. People became more mobile, which made them feel more isolated compared to earlier, stable communities. Centralized broadcasting helped governments share important information with all citizens and created a sense of community within the nation.
While broadcasting has often been seen as a way to support democracy, it has also been shaped by the need for equal access to information for political and social participation. Television is changing, and there is a chance that the term broadcasting may become outdated. If that happens, it will only refer to a specific way of using audio-visual technology during a certain time of social change.

Clutter**
Sometimes, it feels like no matter how many things you own, you never feel secure. It is normal to want a home that meets your needs, but there comes a point when wanting more things becomes too much. Modern advertising is designed to make us feel insecure. One common message is that if you don’t have certain products, you are not as good as others. To see how much advertising affects you, try not to look at any billboards the next time you walk down the street. We are surrounded by advertisements on television, radio, newspapers, magazines, posters, t-shirts, and the internet, all telling us to buy more.
**Caves**
Research teams and universities around the world have spent many years studying caves. They focus on where caves come from, how water moves in them, and the living things inside them. Caves are a small but interesting part of nature. They make us curious and encourage us to learn more, which is why many researchers study them. Because caves are natural features, they have been studied for a long time, especially in places where they affect our lives. However, visiting many caves requires physical skill, so cave research often involves both scientists and people who explore caves for fun.
**Weather Watch**
Many careful people, using only their senses, started the study of weather, known as meteorology, which has become a complex science since the 17th century. Today, satellites and electronic tools give us a lot of weather information quickly. Computers can solve complicated math problems much faster than humans. Meteorology uses many difficult words that are hard for non-professionals to understand. However, human experience is still very important for making weather forecasts. Observations made by people can provide valuable information that helps professionals understand the atmosphere better.

**MUSIC AND THEATRE**
Until recently, I believed that opera is mainly theatre. Now, I think differently. After working at a national opera house, I learned that opera is mostly about music, and theatre comes second. This is how it should be. However, I come from the world of theatre, where the words and the actors are the most important. In theatre, once the show starts, there is no one directing the action, and the performers and the audience usually speak the same language.
At any music performance, whether in a concert hall or an opera house, there are many people who, like me, do not have a lot of knowledge about music. Some may feel embarrassed about what they don’t know, while most are amazed by the talent of the performers. A great singer or a skilled musician is easy to admire. Even a good musician shows us the results of years of hard work. Watching top-class music is similar to watching an athletics match. We know athletes are doing something similar to what we do when we run for a bus, but we also see how much better they are.
Theatre audiences have different expectations. They often do not understand the skills of an actor and may not be impressed by a long and difficult speech. They usually ask, “How do you learn all those lines?” This does not mean that theatre audiences are less demanding than music audiences; many of them are the same people. It may mean that audiences and performers are more equal in theatre than in music, no matter how difficult the material is.
The question is, does music need to learn anything from theatre? I believe it does. I have seen how a different approach can change the experience for concert-goers. Live music is very theatrical, full of emotions, and can connect with the audience in a special way. However, the rules that still exist in music, like strict dress codes and showing too much respect to conductors and soloists, create a gap between performers and listeners that can feel uncomfortable.
On the other hand, when contemporary music audiences clap between movements or after a great performance, it can be a way to show appreciation, but it can also disrupt the flow of the music. Is there a solution? Yes, a lot is being done. Many projects are happening across the country to invite new audiences into concert halls and opera houses and to break down the barriers that make people feel that “serious” music is not for them.
I remember a special event, the community opera "In Search of Angels," which took place in a cathedral and then moved into the town. It was an amazing musical experience where the skills of the musicians were very important, and it changed many audience members' lives. They were not just there to watch and listen; they also contributed directly.
What I wish for in music is a bit more of the excitement and boldness that the best theatre can show. Sometimes this can come from using unusual or challenging locations, which can surprise both performers and audiences. People may have to give up some comforts, like a good sound or warmth, but theatre audiences have learned to be brave and follow artists into unexpected places.
I know that most plays are performed in a traditional way, similar to concerts. However, I believe that something should change in how we experience music. I can only speak as a fan: I love theatre and spend as much time (and money) as I can enjoying music. I want both to succeed and for more people to enjoy the pleasure I get from being in the audience.

**Text:**
**Sand**  
I admire how sand can be changed into useful things like glass and concrete, but I do not like it when it is just sand. To me, it is mostly a problem that gets in the way between a parking lot and the sea. It blows in your face, gets into your food, and can hide important things like car keys and coins. When you are wet, it sticks to you and is hard to remove, even with a strong hose. But, strangely, when you step onto a beach towel, get into a car, or walk on a clean carpet, it falls off you easily. For days after, you find sand on the floor every time you take off your shoes, and even more when you take off your socks. Sand stays with you longer than many illnesses. So, I would rather not have sand around.
**Lock and Key**  
People have always wanted a safe home for privacy and security. The old way of using a rope to lock a door has changed to using electronic locks with plastic cards. But people still want to keep out the "bad guys." The idea of a lock and key is partly about feeling safe. Some companies have tried using smart cards to open electronic locks, but many people do not like them. You might accept them at work, but at home, everyone wants to turn a real key in a lock. Because of this, when a locksmith company made a new electronic lock, they included a real metal key.
**Modern Art**  
I was nervous about visiting the new Tate Modern gallery because, like many people, I do not understand modern art. I know I like some of it, especially furry things, neon light sculptures, and big photographs. Maybe if I knew more about it, I would have more opinions. But art is not just about understanding; it is about feeling something from it. This is a nice idea, but it has not worked for me before. However, this new gallery has tried to help visitors understand the art better. The first thing I noticed was the labels that explained the art and what it means. Instead of just looking at the pictures, these labels helped me understand them better.

**Every Picture Tells a Story**
**Adapting Novels for Film**
Turning a novel into a film often means cutting down the story. This can be frustrating for the writer, but it can also be helpful. While writing a script, I noticed that I could remove a lot of dialogue and descriptions from the book and still keep the main idea. This does not mean that the original words were unnecessary. It is about how each medium asks the audience to pay attention and how they repeat information. 
In a novel, repetition can help readers remember important character traits and who is speaking. Even though we can often guess who is talking from the dialogue, having tags like "he said" makes it easier to read. In stage plays, the dialogue often mimics real speech, sometimes using a lot of unnecessary words just to keep the conversation going, which can make it hard to understand the main message.
**Watching Movies**
When we watch movies, we can feel like we are part of the story. It takes us away from our everyday lives for the time the film lasts. However, once the movie ends and the lights come on, we return to reality. People often do not feel guilty about the time spent watching a film, and this feeling of unreality can make it hard to take movies seriously. Many people from older generations, including our teachers, did not see movies as art; they thought of them as just entertainment. 
**The Film Studios**
The Leiper Film Company studios were made up of many different buildings. The layout was confusing, with only a few recognizable places like the Script Department. Most of the rooms looked the same and were used for meetings. Finding a specific room was not easy. The studio had three main entrances, which made it even more confusing for visitors. There was no clear way to ask for help or get directions. However, most people who worked there knew how to get around. Thanks to their hard work, stories of romance and adventure could be shared with audiences. 
**Film-Makers**
Many people want to make movies. Bookstores have many guides on scriptwriting and film production. Universities offer courses, and there are competitions for aspiring filmmakers. For example, Robert Rodriguez made his film *El Mariachi* for just $7,000, which helped him become a well-known director. He wrote about how he felt pressure to succeed quickly, comparing himself to famous directors like Orson Welles and Steven Spielberg, who made their first big films at a young age.
In the past, filmmakers had to take their time to learn the craft. They often started as editors, writers, or cinematographers before directing their own films. For example, John Huston was 35 when he made *The Maltese Falcon*, and Fred Zinnemann was in his forties when he directed *High Noon*. Today, without the support of studios or television, new filmmakers often have to work independently.

In the past, the council houses were all over the western side of the city. They were rows of small, old houses made of orange brick or pale white plaster. In summer, the smell from the May and Baker factory, which was two miles away, filled the air with a strong smell of sulphur. In the mornings, a common sight in that part of Norwich was a paperboy making a face as he walked up someone’s front path. I have forgotten most of my early life, but I remember sitting near an upstairs window and looking at the houses as they disappeared into the distance. 
I also have memories of my mother, who was ironing towels in a house that I don’t think was ours, and of snow falling on a big mansion at Earlham. My mother appears in my early memories because I remember her as a small, precise, and often angry woman. I never really understood why she was angry, so I couldn’t do anything to make her feel better. Even as a child, when I went with her to small shops or into the city, I noticed that she was very lonely. She felt alone even in a room full of people. 
My mother had strict rules that I didn’t understand. For example, we were not allowed to walk into our neighbors' gardens or disturb their rose bushes. We had to sit quietly in the dining room for long periods, with our hands folded, listening to the radio shows she liked. There were many rules like this. 
Over time, I remember other people in our lives. Even though my mother was lonely, she had some friends. There was Mrs. Buddery, who loved the Royal Family, Mrs. Winall, who hardly spoke, and Mrs. Laband, who was more lively but not always liked by the others. Looking back, I see that they were not very good company. They often talked about their bad legs, the cold weather, and their ungrateful children, which made me feel included in their complaints. 
I felt like a heavy weight, made up of the West Earlham houses, my mother, her friends, and the need to "behave properly," was on my shoulders. I felt I had to grow up quickly and find a way to lift this weight. Growing up in West Earlham followed a clear pattern. Until you were five, you stayed at home and bothered your parents. I remember long, boring days when I played on a rug while my mother sat in an armchair. 
Then, after your fifth birthday, you went to Avenue Road infants school, which was half a mile away. Some lucky kids had mothers with old bikes that had child seats. I think my mother let me go with other children from the street. If I remember anything from those early years, it’s the summer holidays. During those days, I saw glimpses of the world outside West Earlham. There was an old man next to Mrs. Buddery who told stories about being in the Merchant Navy. Once, there was a charity fair at a house far away where a kind woman gave out lemonade and tried to get me interested in something called the League of Pity, which was a junior charity. But my mother dismissed it, saying the organizers just wanted money. 
My mother often talked about how people were only after money, and she had a very low opinion of politicians. If she thought about the House of Commons, she probably imagined it as a place where rich people opened letters full of money sent by gullible people. I might be exaggerating, and I might not see her good qualities, but my mother did not show much kindness. 
To be fair, my mother knew she was responsible for my education. Sometimes, she would take me on the bus to the Norwich Castle Museum. We would walk through rooms full of paintings by local artists. My mother didn’t completely dislike this, and she even started to have opinions about the art. I remember once she stopped in front of a painting of a Roman soldier and said, "Well, I wouldn’t want to meet him on a dark night!" This was one of the few times I remember her trying to make a joke. 
**Questions:**
1. What type of houses were common in the western side of the city?
2. What smell filled the air during summer?
3. How did the narrator feel about their mother’s personality?
4. Name one of the narrator's mother’s friends and describe her.
5. What did the narrator remember about the summer holidays?
6. What was the League of Pity?
7. How did the narrator’s mother feel about politicians?
8. Where did the narrator and their mother go on Sundays?

Philadelphia Avenue**
I walked down Philadelphia Avenue on the odd-numbered side. The evening was getting darker, and the air was humid with a light drizzle that made my walk feel secretive. I knew this side of the street very well; our neighbors were the Matzes and the Pritchards, and there was Han Kieffer's grocery store. The Krings and the Pottses lived nearby, and they were my first friends, all girls. 
These houses were familiar to me, even if I didn’t know everyone’s name. I remembered the small channels in the cement that carried rain from the roofs to the sidewalk, which I would skate or scoot over. As the street went downhill, the houses seemed to get simpler: the porches were lower, and the front yards were smaller. 
Over the years, things changed: wooden porch railings were replaced with iron ones that looked a bit Southern or Spanish. In Shillington, some houses I remembered as homes became stores, and strangely, some stores, like Pep Conrad's and Han Kieffer's, became homes again. I wondered how the people used those spaces and how they lived with the smells of the products.
**Bachelor Fads Furniture Designer Rick Gilbert**
Rick Gilbert lives in a flat that used to be a curtain warehouse. It has the typical features of a loft, like exposed brick and big doors where curtains were once lifted from trains. But Gilbert did not want a completely open space. He said it was hard to relax or work when everything was in view. 
To create a separate area near the entrance, he used a large piece of corrugated plastic. This helped hide his office, made a hallway, and led to the kitchen in the middle of the flat. He wanted the kitchen to be a neutral space where he could cook for friends or make coffee for clients. 
To balance the modern look of his plastic screen and stainless steel kitchen, Gilbert chose light wood for the floors. His flat has futuristic chairs and sofas, but it also has sentimental furniture from his parents or things he bought at markets.
**Bruce Chatwin**
Bruce Chatwin lived a very romantic and wandering life, which has puzzled many people. His life and writing were full of secrets and some lies, but he was a brilliant and unique writer. His first book, *In Patagonia*, published in 1977, is a wonderful work of imagination. It is a travel book that changed travel writing, full of excitement and deep insights. 
Even in this book, Chatwin mixed facts with fiction. When he described people and events, he sometimes changed the truth to make a better story or to highlight what he wanted to say: that through travel, we can discover amazing histories that seem to be waiting for future explorers.
**Swimming**
During a warm summer rain, I ran across the lawn behind my house and jumped into the pool. As I swam, I kept my eyes just above the water. Each raindrop created a small splash that turned into bubbles. The best moments were when the rain got stronger, drowning out the birdsong, and steam rose from the water as if the pool was meeting the sky.
In the summer of 1996, while enjoying this rain, I thought about swimming across Britain. I wanted to follow the rain as it traveled to the sea, escaping the frustration of swimming back and forth in the pool like a tiger in a cage. 
Many of us live in a world where everything is labeled and explained. This makes our reality feel more like a visual experience. That’s why walking, cycling, and swimming are important. They help us reconnect with the wild and old parts of our world by getting off the main paths and discovering things for ourselves. A swimming journey would let me explore the mysterious parts of our world, like dark woods or high mountains.

'CRYING**
Charles Darwin thought that crying did not have a clear purpose in human evolution. However, he was likely wrong. Recently, scientists have shown that crying is important for social connections. Psychiatrist John Bowlby pointed out that crying helps create a bond between a mother and her child. Many people believe that tears, especially in children, show feelings of helplessness. 
It is harder to understand why adults cry. The sound of crying is less important than the way it looks. Crying may have helped early human groups build trust and connect with each other. People cry for many reasons. We might cry to show sympathy for someone who is suffering. Sometimes, we cry without meaning to, like when we hear beautiful music or moving speeches. We may also cry when watching a sad movie, and interestingly, this happens more often when we are with others than when we are alone. The social role of crying is clear, but research is still ongoing.'

**The Heat is On**
We have all heard about global warming, but how much warmer will the Earth get, and how will it affect our lives? Most people know what global warming is, but few understand its effects. A warmer climate will likely change the weather in many parts of the world. Since the atmosphere is connected to everything on our planet, any climate changes will significantly impact plants, animals, water, and soil.
Humans have learned to use natural resources to help us grow food, build cities, and support billions of people. Any changes to these resources are serious. The challenge we face is understanding how the world will change and what is causing these changes. Over the last 100 years, human actions have increased the amount of certain gases in the atmosphere, which are linked to global temperature. These gases are likely affecting the global climate, but we do not fully understand how the climate system works.
We know that greenhouse gas levels have changed in line with global temperatures over the past 40,000 years, suggesting a strong connection between the two. Evidence shows that the Earth's surface has warmed by about 6°C in the last century. Most scientists believe this warming is not just a natural process but is partly due to human pollution.
A lot of research has been done to predict what will happen because of higher global temperatures. Scientists use computer programs called general circulation models (GCMs) to analyze how temperature, pressure, sunlight, and other factors interact to predict climate conditions. However, these models are not perfect and can be slow and expensive to use. We do not fully understand all the processes in the climate system, but we know it is complex.
Despite these challenges, most people agree that climate change will happen faster than we have seen before. Current predictions suggest that by the year 2100, the average global surface temperature could rise by 1°C to 3.5°C, sea levels could rise by 15 to 95 cm, and rainfall patterns will change. Scientists also expect more extreme weather events, like heatwaves, floods, and droughts, in some areas. These changes will likely impact the natural environment and human life.
Climate change can affect where ecosystems, like forests and grasslands, are located, the types of species in them, and their ability to provide resources we need. This includes food, water, and places to live. Some effects may be harmful, but not all changes will be negative. For example, in Australia, research shows that wheat production has increased due to warmer temperatures, which have reduced frost damage.
However, many predicted effects of climate change are concerning. Even small changes in climate can affect water availability, especially in dry areas. The Mediterranean region has already seen less rainfall in some areas. In southern Portugal, for example, rain is now falling more in autumn and winter, with less in spring.
Another issue is the melting of glaciers, which affects ice and can harm wildlife and human structures. The Arctic ice is at risk of melting completely, which could make shipping and oil exploration easier but also increase the risk of icebergs.
One of the most serious effects of global warming will be rising sea levels. Warmer water takes up more space, and melting ice adds to this. Since about half of the world's population lives near coastlines, rising sea levels could lead to severe flooding in cities like London, New York, and Tokyo. Many people could lose their homes and jobs, creating millions of environmental refugees. Small island nations could be especially hard hit, as they might completely disappear, causing devastating effects for their people and cultures, as well as for countries that would need to help those displaced.

Mission to Mars**
Wanted: a married couple, around middle age, for a 501-day trip to Mars. Applicants must be strong both physically and emotionally. This couple could be the first astronauts on Mars if Dennis Tito's plans to launch a spacecraft on January 5, 2018, succeed. The spacecraft will take the crew to about 160 km above Mars. It will use Mars' gravity to return to Earth without using extra fuel, which is very important. The 2018 date is set because the next time Mars and Earth will be in the right position for a launch is in 2031. 
It is a big challenge, but there is a race to create new technologies for this mission. If these technologies are ready in time, the spacecraft might succeed. Even if it does not leave Earth, the work done for this mission will help future space missions.

**AESTHETICS**
Sometimes, the existence of art makes it hard to understand art itself. This is because art is a physical object, like a building, book, painting, or statue, that exists outside of our personal experiences. People often think of art only as these objects, not as what they mean or how they affect us. 
When a piece of art becomes very famous or is considered a classic, it can be hard to see it in a new way. This fame can create rules and ideas that block fresh thoughts about the art. When we separate art from the people and experiences that created it, we lose its meaning. Art then seems to exist in its own world, away from everything else that humans do.
A key job for anyone writing about art is to connect these beautiful works with everyday life. Just like mountains are part of the earth, art is part of human experience. Those who study the earth, like geographers and geologists, show how mountains relate to the earth. Similarly, those who study art must also show how art connects to our daily lives.
To understand art better, we sometimes need to forget about the art itself and focus on ordinary experiences that we usually don’t think of as artistic. We can enjoy flowers without knowing much about plants, but to understand how they grow, we need to learn about soil, air, water, and sunlight. In the same way, to understand art, we should start with simple experiences that catch our attention and bring us joy.
Many people enjoy things like movies, jazz, and comic strips, but they don’t always see these as art. When people think of art as only what is found in museums, they miss out on the joy found in everyday experiences. Even those who disagree with the idea of art being only in museums often still separate art from daily life. The best appreciation of art happens when it is connected to the things we do every day.

Observing Lions**
Many people think that lions hunting for food are amazing to watch. In the fading light of sunset, a group of lions quietly comes out from the shadows and surrounds their unsuspecting prey. They seem to be perfect social animals, working together to achieve a common goal - getting their next meal. However, after many years of studying these animals in the wild, we have a different view. 
When we began our research in 1978, we wanted to find out why lions hunt together, raise their young, and scare off rivals with their loud roars. If we measure an animal's success by how many offspring survive, then working together does not always help. If one animal is too generous, its friends may benefit while it suffers. So, why do lions seem to ignore the rules of self-interest? We thought we would find the answer in two or three years. But lions are very good at doing nothing. 
It has taken many different research methods to learn about their behavior. Since wild lions can live up to 18 years, we are only now starting to understand the answers to our questions.
**Pop Music Review**
The release of Bedrock's third album was an important moment for a talented band that had struggled before. "New Life" started a movement that changed rock music in this country for the rest of the decade. Gone were the serious themes and heavy guitars of the past; instead, a lighter mix of catchy local styles came in. 
The album combined social observations and strong emotions with sounds from fairground organs and brass bands. Humor and irony were also present, and the singers did not hide their backgrounds. The album showed that Bedrock was skilled at collecting ideas and writing songs. They wrote about traditional English topics like sunbathing and Sunday afternoons. However, the album's true strength was in its deeper, sadder songs like "So Low," which had a beautiful melody about weather, and "To the Brink," a serious ballad. 
The beauty of "New Life" is its high quality - 16 tracks with no weak songs, which is impressive in an era of long CDs.
**Extract from an Autobiography**
As a child, I was always interested in stories about 'The Sibyl,' wise women who had great influence in the ancient world. At first, I only knew of one from a story my mother told me. An old woman from Cumae offered King Tarquin of Rome nine books for 300 gold pieces. He refused, so she burned three books and offered him six for the same price. When he refused again, she burned three more. He finally bought the last three for the full price. I understood that there was an important lesson in this story about sales and life.
I was often a lonely only child. I would ask to play with other kids, but they would say no. My mother told me to do something interesting so that the other children would want to join me. It worked, and it was a lesson I have never forgotten.
When I got the chance to write a travel book, I had to find something I wanted to learn about, something that mattered to me. I am not a keen traveler - at the first chance, I sent my editor a long list of places I did not want to visit. I am only interested in ruins because I prefer to travel through time in my mind.
**What Happens to Your Manuscript?**
When you send your manuscript, it will likely join a pile of other manuscripts waiting to be read - this is called the slush pile. Usually, a junior member of the editorial team (often under 18) or an experienced person who works part-time will look at it. Neither of them has much power, but they want to find something original. The junior member hopes to make a name for themselves, while the experienced person wants to keep their job.
If they think your novel is good, they will pass it to a senior editor. This editor will have to explain why they should accept your novel based on its quality and potential sales. They will also consider if you, as an author, seem like a good long-term choice. It is important to publishers that you are promotable, as a new novel needs all the help it can get. Because of this, publishers often like to meet potential authors before making an offer.

Advertising on Trial**
If you work for an advertising agency, the early 1990s may have been very hard for you. The recession was worse than expected, affecting many countries for thirty years. In Britain, in 1991, the economy shrank, interest rates were very high, and many people lost their jobs. More than half a million people were unemployed, and about 75,000 homes were taken back by banks. Every business was affected, especially the vehicle and building industries, which saw a 30% drop in work. Many people and companies suffered during this time.
Advertising workers were not the only ones losing their jobs, but those who kept their jobs felt a lot of pressure. They were expected to help their companies make money, and they felt their work was being closely watched by their bosses. At the same time, they had to do their jobs with smaller budgets. They were told that doing less could be better. However, the importance of marketing was growing. Companies started to realize they needed to create products that customers wanted, not just what was easy for them to make. 
In the last ten to fifteen years, many companies began to focus more on marketing. This change meant that marketing activities received more attention from management, and some brands started to be marketed properly. This increased the status of marketing workers, but it also added to their workload. Marketing was often seen as a solution to all problems, but about half of marketing budgets were spent on advertising. 
The 1980s were a good time for advertising, but the early 1990s brought the worst times for the industry in a long time. This was partly due to the bad economy, but there were also deeper changes happening. The recession made companies rethink their advertising budgets and question the value of advertising. Many companies wanted to know what they were getting for their money and what return they were seeing on their investment. Advertising was under more scrutiny than ever.
Client companies wanted better strategies, better targeting, better creativity, and better media placement. They wanted the best people from advertising agencies to work on their projects and to be motivated to create great work. While this situation is tough for advertising workers, it also means they face the same problems as their clients: how to do more with less.
Several factors made creating effective advertising difficult. Some were due to the recession, like worries about production costs and a reluctance to take risks, which are often necessary for good advertising. Other changes were happening regardless of the economy, such as demographic shifts, the growing power of retailers, changing consumer needs, the rise of sponsorship, and stricter advertising laws. Some companies also faced the challenge of advertising in other countries.
Because of the economic situation and these changes, advertising professionals had to think about the saying: "Only half my advertising works. The trouble is I don't know which half." Now, more than ever, there is pressure to make sure that advertising is effective. Unfortunately, help for those who want to improve their advertising is not easy to find. Companies and advertising agencies have been too busy dealing with these challenges to share their experiences. Those who have managed to succeed often want to keep their successful strategies private. 
As a result, while conferences and seminars may offer some useful information, the available books on advertising do not provide much help. Many of these books treat the advertising process with too much respect, suggesting that all advertising work is of high quality and great value, which is not true and does not help the employees responsible for the advertising.

**The Lure of the Kitchen**
When I was in university, I decided I wanted to be a chef. This was an unusual choice among my friends. Most people wanted different jobs. Cooking seemed like a hard and unattractive job. Chefs work long hours, face a lot of pressure, do simple tasks, and do not earn much money. However, these reasons did not stop me. I was unhappy at university. The work was difficult, and the social life felt closed and self-important. Being a chef seemed like a good escape from this. It promised a seriousness and honesty that I felt was missing in my college life.
My desire to cook was not just because I was unhappy as a student. It also came from a love for beautiful food. I first felt this when I had a meal at a famous restaurant in London. It was amazing. I still remember my first dish. After that meal, I wanted to kneel and thank the chef who made it. I felt happy for days. This experience made me want to learn the secrets of cooking. I changed my student life into a preparation for becoming a chef. My history degree felt unimportant, and I learned about cooking by reading cookbooks, visiting markets, and making special meals.
**Extract from a Novel**
The swimming instructor at my school was a tough man, small and strong, with tattoos on his arms. When I asked him to teach me how to dive, he told me to sit on the edge of the pool, put my hands above my head, and roll forward, pushing off with my feet. I practiced this until the hour was over. The next time, he had me stand up and dive off the edge. He was strict, and every time I came up from the water, he looked at me with disapproval: "Don't look down, look up!" "Keep your legs straight." "Point your toes!" 
The following week, I went up to the high diving board. It was fixed and bent slightly down at the front. It looked very high as I stood there, trying to gather my courage. Slowly, the noise around me faded, and I felt like I was in a quiet bubble. I waved my arms like I had been taught, tried to look up, and jumped into the air. For a moment, I felt like I was flying. When I hit the water, I fell awkwardly, and my legs were everywhere. The instructor looked at me with disappointment and shook his head. But even he could not take away my happiness. I thought, "This is what they mean by 'free as a bird.'"
**The Traveller**
For those of us who value a comfortable bed, running water, and the chance to live until tomorrow, the idea of a traveller seems strange and fascinating. These are people who choose to take risks, like climbing dangerous mountains or sailing alone on small boats. They might eat insects if there is nothing else to eat and can live for months in uncertain conditions. It is easy to see them as odd or eccentric, like hermits or extreme sports enthusiasts. We know they exist, but their unusual world is far from our daily lives. We can ignore them and feel thankful for our own safe lives, where the biggest risk is crossing a busy street.
**SAILING**
Jonathan Raban is afraid of the sea, which is probably why he spends so much time on it. He does not say he is a world-class sailor, but he is skilled. He sails because, as a writer, he enjoys writing about his sailing experiences. Sailing gives him stories to tell. Raban's small boat has a device that tells sailors their exact location anywhere on Earth. While he likes this tool, he also believes that using a compass was a mistake. He thinks it changed how people relate to the sea. Since the compass was invented, sailors do not pay attention to the waves and the ocean as much. The sea, which used to be full of life, has become just a space to cross. Because of this, a sailor can let a machine steer the boat for long periods. This might be why Raban has time to observe the waves closely.

**Holiday Reading**
Summer gives us two great joys: escaping home and reading books. These joys are closely connected. Books can help us feel more at home in the world. We can relate our own experiences to those in great books written long ago or in faraway places. In the stories of others, we find our own thoughts and feelings. Authors can express what we feel but in a clearer way. What we feel shy or confused about is clearly described in their words, which is even more surprising if the author is from a different time or place. We feel thankful to these authors for helping us understand ourselves better.
Through reading and traveling, we can break free from our daily routines. Our eyes are most open during the first few days in a new place, just like when we read a great book. A good book can show us things we might have ignored before. Our minds become more aware of the details around us, like the colors of the sky, the expressions on people's faces, or feelings we didn’t know we had.
**Author's Note**
These reflections on travel were published as articles in the Observer newspaper over seven years. I have made some small changes to fit the articles better, but not much else. I corrected a few mistakes, but only minor details. If I were to rewrite some parts, I would have to change the original meaning. For example, in my article about China, I thought the Hong Kong dollar would stay strong, but it fell a year later. If I changed my writing to include this fact, it would no longer be a report of what I thought at that time. Like any traveler, I was there, not knowing what would happen next, just trying to understand what I had experienced.
**Ecotourism**
If there were awards for tourism phrases that have been misused, "ecotourism" would win first prize. This term started in the early 1980s when people became more aware of the environment. Tour operators realized that many travelers wanted to make sure their trips would not harm the places they visited. The term quickly became popular. Now, "ecotourism" can mean anything from living with remote tribes for two weeks to a short boat trip through an Australian gorge. Any tour that includes cultural experiences, beautiful nature, wildlife, or a bit of adventure is likely to be called ecotourism. While the original idea was to help travelers make better choices, the lack of clear rules has left many confused about what ecotourism really means.
**Transylvanian Journey**
I lost my notebook about my journey in Transylvania for 50 years, but I found it again a few years ago. It has helped me remember that time, but it was not always perfect. In Transylvania, I had a much easier time than I expected, staying in friendly country houses for weeks. When I stayed in one place for a long time, I stopped writing because I thought there was nothing to record. I was slow to start writing again when I moved on, and sometimes I only wrote short notes instead of full stories. I worried that some details might be out of order when I started writing this book, so I added many warnings. But then I realized that these pages were not meant to be a guidebook, so I let the story flow without too many worries.

Fashion**
Fashion is often thought of as a new idea that started with capitalism in the 19th and 20th centuries. However, many fashion historians say that fashion, in terms of style and design, has a long history. They often begin their studies with the growth of trade in the 16th and 17th centuries. As societies have become more complex, populations have grown, and new technologies for making different types of clothing have been created, the meanings of clothing have also become more complex. Because of this, it is hard to say what any piece of clothing really means today. For example, a man's suit, which seems to be very uniform, can mean different things in different situations and to different people.
**Writer**
Reports in newspapers about publishers fighting over young writers' books can give a false idea of what life is like for most novelists. In my part of the business, where I am not on the best-seller lists, there are two ways to make a living. The smartest writers work in the evenings and have other full-time jobs that will still be there even if their book is not quickly published or made into a movie. Others, like me, do different writing jobs, teaching, workshops, and articles to get by. I have heard of a writing job at a chocolate factory, but I have never found anything like that. Somehow, by balancing part-time jobs and using credit cards, and often thanks to the help of people mentioned in the Acknowledgements, I manage to write my novel.
**Sudden Fame**
The small places we were performing in around the country were starting to sell out, and we needed extra security to control the growing number of excited fans. We had to use secret entrances to the village halls and ballrooms to avoid being overwhelmed by fans. On the few nights we were not working, it was hard to leave the house without being followed by fans. In just a few days, we became celebrities. Our fans watched our every move, and our management took care of all our needs. Even though I still felt shy, I also felt a strange confidence that only shy people who suddenly become famous can understand. In short, I felt completely out of my comfort zone.

Music - The Challenge Ahead**
Technology is changing our lives at work, home, and during our free time. Susan Hallam talks about how this affects music in Britain. In the late 20th century, there were many new ways to listen to music, like radio, TV, records, tapes, CDs, and videos. However, there has been a decrease in live music performances and full-time jobs for professional musicians. 
It is clear that more people will continue to have access to music because it meets many human needs. Music is important for national events and for personal activities, both formal and informal. A society without music is hard to imagine. The question is not if there will be music in the 21st century, but what kind of music it will be and if people will still want to learn to play instruments. I believe that people will still want to learn. 
The music industry is a major source of income in Britain, and musical skills will remain important for many jobs, especially in media. There is also evidence that playing an instrument can help develop skills in young people. Research in the USA shows that listening to or making music can improve spatial reasoning, which is a part of intelligence. While these results need more study, other research in Europe suggests that group music lessons can improve social skills and concentration in children, especially those with behavioral issues.
Current research is looking into how playing an instrument can help develop useful skills. For example, regular practice can help students develop good study habits and focus. Playing in concerts can teach punctuality and organization. Because of these reasons, there will likely be a continued demand for music lessons in the near future.
What about the future? Will there be changes, and if so, what will they be? I think there are two likely possibilities. First, the types of music people listen to will become more varied, with new styles mixing together. Second, technology will be used more in creating and performing music. This will make it easier for more people to compose music, but it may also reduce the need for live performances and musicians.
At the same time, more people of all ages will want to participate in making music. These activities will likely be community-based and reflect the musical traditions of those communities. If we want this future to happen, the music profession needs to prepare. 
Music lessons will need to change to help more people learn different instruments throughout their lives. This will affect the music curriculum and how progress is measured, making it relevant for a wider audience. Musicians will need training to motivate and teach learners of all ages, work with diverse groups, and develop skills in communication, social interaction, and management for community work. 
This is a big change from traditional methods, and it will require accountability. However, this is a chance for everyone in music education to show the high quality of music teaching available. Finally, we need to raise awareness of the importance of music in our lives. Music is essential, but it is often taken for granted. Everyone in the music profession needs to work together to change this.

**The Actor's Craft**
Sometimes, people make fun of actors. This negative view often comes from the actors themselves when they talk about their work in interviews. Instead of explaining their art, they often use boring phrases or get caught up in gossip. Paul Scofield, a famous actor, once wrote to a friend that an actor's work is only interesting when they perform. He believed that talking about acting makes it feel less real. Each time an actor performs, they start fresh, learning about their character and the story. After a play ends, they feel empty until the next performance. This emptiness shows when people discuss acting.
**A Review of Hamlet**
Adrian Lester plays Hamlet in a way that shows he is between being a boy and a man. His performance is simple but very strong. He controls his body and emotions well, showing both anger and humor, making his character both tough and lovable. Even though he seems calm, his talent shines through. You can see how he holds his body, waiting to act. Another actor, Handy, plays Horatio in a way that also shows a strong inner feeling.
**What is Acting?**
What does it mean to act? Is acting just copying real behavior, or is it something deeper? This question is important in the world of theatre.
**One Director's Approach to Rehearsal**
This director has a special way of starting rehearsals called "dropping in." The stage manager shows the script on a screen. While one person speaks, the other actors listen quietly. When it’s their turn, they look at the screen, think about the words, and find the right moment to speak. For example, if the line is, "Queuing all night, the rain, do you remember?" they take a breath and let the memory come to them. They might picture a queue at a bus stop or a concert. The director encourages actors to be open and trust that something will happen when they perform.
**The Perfect Theatre**
A perfect theatre makes you feel important as an audience member. Going to the theatre should feel special, and the staff should understand this too. It feels strange if the workers act like it’s just a job. The theatre should connect the performers and the audience. People in the audience should be able to see and hear everything clearly. The size of the theatre is important; it should fit the human voice and body. If the theatre is too big, it feels wrong because drama is about people. Many theatres built in the late 1800s got this right by creating a space that feels welcoming. I like theatres that have a history, like old stone steps in a church, showing the presence of many people over time. When you go to the theatre, you want to see something surprising and new; otherwise, you might as well stay home.

Paul Simon**
Rock and roll in the 1950s was mainly for young people, but it also had a big effect on the middle class and older people. It opened the door for the next generation of rock stars, who listened to it and knew that this new and exciting music would be important in their lives. For Paul Simon and other young people in the US, the best way to hear this new music was through Alan Freed's radio show, Moondog Rock'n'Roll Party. Freed's show was very popular and important for many young rock stars. Like John Lennon, who was 3,000 miles away in Liverpool, listening to Radio Luxembourg, Paul Simon was captivated by the music from Freed's show. He was getting ready to make his own music instead of just listening to others.
**Snow**
I could not see a clear path, but I thought I would be okay if I was careful. The wind was strong, pushing me down as I slipped on the ice. Suddenly, the snow that looked safe gave way, and I fell into a hole about four feet deep. The snow had formed a roof over a gap between two rocks, and when it melted, it left only a thin layer that I fell through. I pulled myself out, feeling shaken and scared, and I wondered what I would have done if the hole had been thirty feet deep. I sat against a pine tree that was sticking out of the snow to think about what to do next. In an hour, I had only gone about half a mile. It was clear that I would have to change my plans.
**Qualitative Research**
There are many books that help researchers understand qualitative research. While there is a lot of information about collecting data, these books often do not explain how to analyze the data. There is still some mystery about how researchers study their data. Because of this, we asked different social scientists who have worked on qualitative projects to talk about their methods. The goal was to share their experiences and understanding of analyzing qualitative data, not to create a guidebook for new researchers. This task involves making unclear processes clearer. While this may seem easy, we found it to be quite difficult. We have allowed our contributors to share their work in different styles, including personal stories and more formal writing.

Screen Learning**
A few days ago, I saw my six-year-old son eating noodles in a funny way. He was pulling them up with his teeth and pretending to be fierce. "I'm a little dinosaur," he said. He was acting out a scene from a recent TV show, so I asked him what he remembered about dinosaurs. He didn’t remember much. 
Many people are excited about learning through the internet and computers, but is this a good way to learn? One writer shared his experience with an interactive program he tried with his son. The father read the words while the son played with the pictures. The father thought that if his son had spent ten minutes reading a book, he might have learned something. 
Research shows that learning happens best in an environment where there is conversation with teachers or parents. It needs to be guided. Using new technology to teach our children is fine, but traditional education is still very important.
**Hollywood**
By 1918, most of the world’s film-making had moved to Hollywood. The local people did not like this change, seeing their neighborhood in Los Angeles affected by these newcomers. But in the end, they accepted it because of the American value of success. Success is measured by how much money a film makes. 
Hollywood knows a good film when it sees one. In less than a hundred years, Hollywood has changed from a small village to a town as famous as New York, Rome, or Paris. A hundred years ago, you would walk through orange groves to get to the village store. 
However, in some ways, it is still a village, with a narrow view of the world. People in Hollywood mostly talk about films: how much money they have made, who is dating whom, and who is working on which project. Many successful people try to leave Hollywood to live elsewhere, but it is still the main place for anyone in show business.
**Photography**
Photography was created by artists in the 1800s as a new way to show their surroundings. They wanted a lasting record of what they saw. The new technology of light, lenses, and chemicals created images that were more real and detailed than what painters could make by hand. 
This upset many artists. They first liked the new images, but then they said photography could not be considered art. They believed that photography was too connected to reality and not a product of human creativity. 
Despite the critics, photographers knew they had found a new art form. They used photography like other artists use brushes and pencils to show their view of the world, nature, and people.
**Book Illustration**
In the time of black-and-white book illustrations, it was clear that every children's book needed illustrations. This also applied to many novels for older readers, which started to have fewer copies printed. 
Children's publishing was still active, but it was mostly low-budget, leading to many average works. However, the best artists always gave their best work. The black-and-white collection is a mix of both ordinary and amazing pieces, making it a great place for research or casual browsing. 
The best works will likely be shown to the public again, either through new editions of classic books or exhibitions of original illustrations. There are signs that after being ignored for a while, this is starting to happen, and we can see a revival of interest in this artistic period. In time, a creative publisher will likely create a series of classic children's book illustrations from this time, either by reprinting them or designing new editions using the original artwork.

Blogging: Sharing Your Life Online**
Some time ago, a website talked about the risks of sharing your location online. The website's message was clear: when you say, "Hey, I'm at this place," you are also telling many people where you are, including some you might not want to meet. This shows that sharing everything online can have negative effects. 
The internet gives us many chances to share our lives with a large audience. We might think this will bring us wealth or fame, but we can also get lost in all the sharing. It can feel overwhelming. However, we should not lose hope. There is a path to follow, shown to us by early internet users who took risks. 
In the early days of the web, these pioneers explored the internet and learned about its dangers. They faced challenges like losing jobs and friends, long before social media existed. These early bloggers have valuable experiences that we can learn from. 
In January 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started sharing his life online. At that time, the web was mostly used by students and scientists. Hall saw a chance to share his personal story. He created a blog where he wrote about his life and shared photos. In January 1996, he began posting daily, and many people became interested in his adventures. Hall was open about everything; he would write about any topic. 
One day, visitors to his blog found that his homepage was gone, replaced by a video called Dark Night. In the video, Hall shared that he had fallen in love, but when he wrote about it, he was told to choose between his blog and his relationship. He felt that sharing his life online made people not trust him. The blog ended, but the problem of sharing online continues. 
Sharing online can be fun, but if you think it will make people want to be with you, you might be disappointed. In 2002, Heather Armstrong, a young woman in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job. One day, a colleague sent her blog link to the bosses at her company, including some she had made fun of, and she lost her job. 
Experts call this the "online distribution effect," which means people often say things online that they would never say in person. However, our online lives are connected to our real lives. If we forget this, we can make serious mistakes. 
Armstrong's story had a happy ending. After being upset and taking a break from blogging, she got married and started a new blog about her family. Now, she is popular among "mommy bloggers," and her writing helps support her family. She learned an important lesson: the internet lets us say anything, but that doesn’t mean we should.

Enough Sleep?**
Many people today feel tired all the time. In richer and busier countries, not getting enough sleep and feeling anxious have become common problems. Research in the USA shows that 40 million Americans have serious sleep issues. Some popular novels in Britain even have characters who cannot sleep or are set in sleep research labs. People are interested in sleep: how it works, why we need it, and the problems that come with not getting enough. A sleep researcher says, "People need more sleep." When people are busy, they often sleep less. They wake up early to avoid traffic.
Recently, a sleep researcher did an experiment. He let people sleep for up to 14 hours a night for a month. After three weeks, they found they needed about eight hours of sleep. This shows that they were catching up on sleep they missed.
In Europe, a university sleep research lab studies how tiredness affects people. They have looked at how tired sailors are, how airport noise affects sleep, and how tired drivers can be dangerous. They find volunteers by advertising in student newspapers. Volunteers are picked up by taxi, paid £5 an hour, and asked to change their sleeping habits.
Dr. Louise Reyner helps the volunteers feel comfortable. Some worry because they have electrodes on their heads, thinking the researchers can see their dreams. But the lab is more interested in how the body works. In a dark room, there is a driving simulator with a big screen. Volunteers come in the afternoon, when they usually feel sleepy, after not sleeping well. They drive while answering questions. The road ahead looks endless, and the sun is bright.
The young men say they will not fall asleep. Dr. Reyner has a video of one man trying hard to stay awake. At first, he sits up straight, but then he starts to blink more often and his head drops. Eventually, he falls asleep for a few seconds and wakes up suddenly. By the second or third time, the car goes off the road. Dr. Reyner says that drinking two cups of coffee can help someone stay awake for a while. She suggests energy drinks and caffeinated gum for people who work at night.
Scientists know that humans sleep in a daily cycle, like other mammals. When we sleep, we go through four stages, from light sleep to deep sleep. We usually dream during light sleep, and our brains stop our bodies from moving to keep us safe. Scientists think sleep helps repair our bodies and minds, but they are not completely sure. They do know that women sleep about half an hour longer than men, and older people need less sleep, but they don’t know why.
Some researchers say sleep helps us travel through time safely. People in the past had different sleep patterns. A history professor studied British life from 1500 to 1850 and found that people went to bed early, woke up after midnight, stayed awake for a while, and then went back to sleep. This time was used for thinking, remembering dreams, or even stealing. The poorest people benefited the most from this quiet time.
By the 17th century, with more artificial light, rich people started to sleep in a more efficient way. The industrial revolution later made everyone work longer hours in lighted buildings. However, in some non-western cultures, people still do not have strict bedtimes. They sleep for a few hours, wake up, and then go back to sleep. In some tribal societies, noises and the need to watch for danger make it hard to sleep continuously. It seems that people everywhere need more sleep.

We are talking about big cowboy boots. I stood in my expensive designer cowboy boots on the rocks in the Arizona desert. I wore a full cowboy outfit, but I was not a cowboy. I looked into the morning sun at the Arizona mountains and realized I did not belong there. I flew in from Denver early in the morning, thinking I might look like a cowboy. But that thought went away when I saw a real cowboy at the Phoenix airport. He was wearing a dirty shirt and carrying a bag. When he saw my new cowboy boots, he raised an eyebrow and left without saying anything.
I thought there should be clothes for an ex-racing driver that would make me feel normal. I loved being a racing driver and driving fast cars. But I don’t do that anymore. I can’t even if I wanted to. I wondered what I should do now. A racing driver should have other jobs ready for when he stops racing. I thought I had some ideas, but they didn’t work out.
One idea was to be a commentator at races, but there were many former drivers wanting that job. Another idea was to sell classic cars, but that didn’t work either because nobody was buying them. So, I decided to stop trying before I lost everything. Being an "ex" at anything is hard. Who wants to hear about how I almost became the World Champion? Nobody wants to hear a story that ends with "almost." Even if I had been the champion, people would only listen for a short time before getting bored. 
I don’t want sympathy, and I don’t get any. I had a good career, made money, and saved some. But I miss the excitement of driving a powerful racing car. I miss going very fast and the thrill of racing. I also miss the attention from fans and reporters who cared about what I said. Being somewhat famous had its perks. Businessmen and politicians liked to say they knew me, and kids would ask for my autograph.
Now that I don’t race anymore, I have a lot of free time. Just last week, my phone rang twice, but I have so much empty time. I looked up at the blue sky. There were no buzzards flying above. Maybe Arizona doesn’t have buzzards. But I saw some small brown birds in a cactus nearby, and they seemed to be telling me to leave their nest alone. I never thought the desert had songbirds. I realized that a fake cowboy in fancy boots still has a lot to learn.

Vancouver**
In the last ten years, many people from around the world have moved to Vancouver, in western Canada. In the evenings, residents walk around the city, and if you join them, you will likely hear different languages. People come to Vancouver for its mild weather, beautiful location between the ocean and mountains, clean and safe environment, and good education and job opportunities. Some locals may complain about how quickly new buildings are being built, but it is clear that new residents and tourism have helped the city grow. Vancouver was once called 'Terminal City' because it was a gateway to other places. Although this name is not used as much now, Vancouver is still a gateway.
**Putting Pen to Paper**
Journalists like me are often not good at writing letters. Some say this is because we do not like to write for free, but I think it is more about how we try to make our writing very effective. In our work, we focus on getting the best results, so we lose the natural feeling of writing a letter. A true artist, who does not think too much about the effect of their words, does not have this problem. I believe that understanding the impact of words is a sign of a real artist. When Shakespeare wrote his famous lines, he probably did not think about how the sound of the words made them powerful.
**Supermarket Opening**
Opening a new supermarket used to be a big event in Britain. A soap star, a DJ, or a member of the royal family would usually come to cut the ribbon. Now, new supermarkets seem to open every day, so famous people are not needed anymore. Last week, people waiting to enter the new Superbuy store did not care who opened it, as long as they were at the front of the line. According to someone who knew an employee, the first five men to enter would get a bottle of aftershave, and the first five women would receive a bunch of flowers. This news spread quickly among the crowd, making those at the front feel proud and those who arrived late feel jealous.

Citizen Kane**
When the film *Citizen Kane* was released in 1941, there was a lot of excitement about it. However, it did not do well at the box office. The film became popular again later because of television. It is one of the most important films that has inspired many people to become filmmakers. This is surprising because it was Orson Welles's first film. Welles believed that the film was successful because he did not know the rules of filmmaking; he just made the film the way he wanted. He also had a great team, including cameraman Gregg Toland, screenwriter Herman J. Mankiewicz, and special-effects expert Linwood Dunn. When Welles and Mankiewicz decided to create a story about a newspaper owner who was similar to William Randolph Hearst, Welles knew he had a great opportunity to show his skills as both a director and an actor.
**Dermot and Carmel**
That morning, Dermot thought Carmel was acting a bit strange. He had mentioned twice that he might be late and that he might stop at the golf club on his way home. He wanted to talk to someone, and the golf club was a good place for that. Carmel had nodded her head as if she did not really hear him. "Will you be okay? What are you going to do today?" he asked. She smiled and said, "It's funny you ask. I was just thinking that I have nothing to do today, so I will walk downtown and look at the shops. I feel like it would be a waste to just relax all day." Dermot smiled back and said, "You deserve to enjoy your day. And if I am late, I won’t need any food, so don’t worry about it." "That's fine," she replied.
**Title Race**
"Tea boy? Do you mind? I am a mobile lukewarm beverage resource facilitator." 
Human nature can be very funny. A recent study showed that job titles can cause jealousy and problems at work. A survey by a well-known recruitment company found that 90% of employers and 70% of employees believe that job titles create divisions among coworkers. Most surprisingly, the survey revealed that 70% of office workers would give up a pay raise for a more "motivational" or "professional" job title. If our desire for better titles is so strong that it overcomes our need for money, we have a serious problem. In the early twenty-first century, no one wants to be called "subordinate." The job titles being discussed focus on skills (like specialist or coordinator), but they are really just fancy words.

**The Vienna Assignment**
I was in Vienna to take photographs. This was usually the reason I traveled. Photography was not just my job; it was a big part of my life. I loved how light fell on different surfaces and how one picture could capture a moment in time, a city, or a person. I always hoped to take the perfect photograph. As long as I had film in my camera, I could keep trying. I had a simple rule: finish one roll of film, load another, and keep looking for new pictures. 
Once, I took a photo of a smoke plume from a burning oil well that became very popular. It was a lucky moment, but they say you create your own luck, both good and bad. After that, I decided to work freelance, which I thought was a smart choice. However, life had other plans, and things didn’t go as well as I had hoped. The mid-nineties were not as successful as I expected, especially after my photo was on the cover of Time magazine. That’s why I found myself in Vienna instead of somewhere more exciting. But I was still taking photographs, and I was getting paid for it, which I thought was good.
The assignment came about by chance. I had taken photos in London for a picture book called *Four Cities in Four Seasons* that featured London, Paris, Rome, and Vienna. I had received a nice payment for my work in London during all four seasons. I had my own style, capturing the beauty of flowers in Hyde Park and the busy streets of Piccadilly. I knew that some of my best work would not be used because it was just a picture book, not something meant to change people’s views.
After I submitted my winter photos of London, I learned that the Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, had left his job in Vienna for reasons I didn’t need to know. Instead of hiring someone new, they offered me the job. The Austrian publishers liked my work, and I was available, while other photographers were not. I was happy to go because things at home were not good. A week in snowy Vienna sounded great to me.
They put me up at the Europa hotel in the old city. I had visited Vienna before with my wife, but it had been a busy and hot trip, and I hadn’t taken many photos. This time, being alone in cold January, I knew it would be different. As soon as I arrived and saw the beautiful light over the snowy roofs, I felt excited. I was ready to take great pictures.
