She grew up in a home where her mother taught piano, and many children came to learn. Joanna wants to make music available to everyone, not just those with special talent. She believes that everyone should have the chance to learn the piano, just like learning to swim or speak a little French.
Some children learn quickly, while others take their time and may give up. This can happen at any stage. Some kids find the beginning too hard, while others feel pressure to be like the talented children they see on TV. Joanna worries that some parents use music to push their children to achieve, instead of letting them enjoy it. 
When asked if she thinks other piano books are not good enough, Joanna says she does not want to criticize them. She believes her colorful books are not the only ones that can make learning fun. To help young beginners, she includes stories in her books and CDs. She wants to make learning interesting from the very first lesson. 
Joanna believes that learning should be fun. Children should be allowed to play freely and explore the piano. As they progress, they need to learn to read music, which can be challenging. Joanna understands this because she relied on her ear when she was young. However, she thinks that practice is the most important part of learning.
Joanna knows that it can be hard to practice. She did not practice a lot until she went to the Royal Academy of Music, where she learned to play more difficult pieces. Now, she enjoys practicing and spends about eight hours a day on it, which she says is more important than performing. 
She understands that many people find practicing difficult. Joanna suggests that whether you practice for twenty minutes or five hours, it is important to have a goal. Other tips include playing through a piece, even if there are mistakes, and mixing difficult pieces with easier ones.

Writing by Hand and on Screen**
Dr. Johnson said that "what is written without effort is usually read without pleasure." This means that good writing takes hard work. When I look back at my handwritten school essays, I see that I made very few mistakes. Today, I would rewrite them many times. I think this is because writing by hand was hard. Writing slowly helped me think better. When it is easy to change things on a computer, we often do not pay enough attention. Many writers find that the time they spend fixing mistakes on a computer is about the same as the time they spent writing by hand. Also, emails, unlike handwritten letters, can feel less personal. Many love letters are now sent by email, which is better than just sending simple messages. At least these emails are written in some English and grammar. However, words on a screen can feel dull. Writers often do not understand the power of writing and can exaggerate their meaning. Words typed quickly can lack the care and personality of handwriting.
**The CD**
I put down my cup and looked at the CD. The case was not very nice, but the shiny disc inside looked interesting. "Wonderful little things, aren't they?" Mr. Warriston said when he came back into the room. I agreed and carefully handed the disc to him. "It's amazing that they can fit seventy minutes of music on them," he said, turning on the music player. Lights turned on, and he pressed a button to open a small drawer. He put the disc inside and pressed the button again to close it. "Some people say they sound cold, but I think they..." "Do you have to turn them over, like records?" I asked. "What? No," Mr. Warriston said, standing up. "You only play one side." "Why?" I asked. He looked surprised and then thought for a moment. "You know," he said, "I have no idea. I don't see why you couldn't make both sides playable and double the capacity..." He looked at the machine. "You could have two lasers, or just turn it over by hand... hmm." He smiled at me. "Yes, good point." He nodded toward my wooden chair. "Anyway, come on, let's get you sitting in the best place for the stereo effect, okay?" I smiled, happy to have asked a technical question that Mr. Warriston could not answer.
**Books vs. Electronic Text**
When comparing books and electronic text, the author Malcolm Bradbury said that if matches had been invented after cigarette lighters, we would have been amazed at the improvement. Many people say that electronic text is a big change, like the invention of printing, and that it is almost complete. They forget that changes in how we think take a long time. For example, a book from 1979 said that by the 1980s, books would slowly disappear. So far, this has not happened. Reading long texts on a screen is often not enjoyable, so many people do not do it. Computers encourage people to read only parts of texts. Some people say that this new way of reading leads to new types of stories. But many books have never been read from start to finish, like religious texts and dictionaries. What is new is that computers do not encourage us to read everything carefully.
**The Office**
Charles walked into the office and saw a perfect world of order. The carpet was clean, and the dark wooden desk looked just like it did at the auction five weeks ago. Neat file holders were being put away. Twelve years of trade journals filled one wall. Kathleen struggled to close the filing cabinet and then turned to him. "You have to use computers, Charles. This is just too much." "Hello, Kathleen. Oh, this is amazing," he said, admiring the room and its antique furniture. He was not thinking about computers or any machines in the room, not even a pencil sharpener. "Simply amazing," he said, avoiding the topic of computers. Over the two years he had known her, they had talked about this many times. She could never understand why he did not want to use technology, even though he was good with computers and had published an important paper about them. She had inspired that paper. Through the keyboard, she could change any software into something new that could do amazing things.

"You don’t take sugar, do you?" shouted his secretary. She was not really asking; she was stating a fact because she had been making Lancelot coffee for many months. She often forgot small details because he was not usually supposed to be there. But now, he was there all the time. He realized that staying away only caused more problems. He thought about how he had gone from being a respected advisor, meeting authors and playwrights for lunch, to being a stressed worker with no place to park when he arrived at the office.
"This came," she yelled, waving a manila folder before putting it in front of him. "From that guy in Los Angeles. You said you wanted to see it." A label on the folder read: "A World History of the Short, by Ian Cuthbert." Below that, it said "An Expanded Synopsis." Lancelot did not want to see the word "synopsis." He wanted to see a label that said "A First Draft." He had already seen a synopsis of this book and did not want to see another one, even if it was revised. Ian Cuthbert had received a large advance for this book when Lancelot had bought the company. Ian was one of Lancelot's old friends, and he had made a mistake by asking him to write books. Ian was known for being unpredictable, and Lancelot felt that he was becoming even more difficult to deal with.
Lancelot skipped the introduction he had read many times and looked at the synopsis. He recognized almost every phrase. He closed the folder and pushed it aside. Clearly, at this rate, Ian's manuscript would never arrive. The synopsis lacked the brilliance that Ian was supposed to have, and it felt empty. Lancelot remembered stories about a famous author whose last book was published after his death, chapter by chapter, with payments made one at a time. But in that case, the payments were small amounts that had never been given. Ian's advance had been huge, which was against the usual rule that authors must deliver a manuscript before getting paid.
Lancelot, who had studied modern languages at Oxford, remembered when Ian Cuthbert was seen as a great talent in Cambridge. Ian's friends had planned to take over British theatre, and they succeeded quickly. But Ian seemed lazy compared to them. He wore his overcoat like a cape and talked about famous French writers as if he had met them. For some reason, Ian's creative talent remained hidden. While less talented people became successful, Ian stayed away from the spotlight. Even when he was a well-known literary figure, he was hard to work with. He was supposed to edit a magazine about the arts, but it never got published. His contract with a fashion magazine was renewed three times, but it only created stories about how much he was paid, which kept increasing to try to make him work more.
At meetings, Ian often criticized other people's ideas. Ten years later, he could hardly be counted on to show up for his own funeral. Lancelot was starting to think that "A World History of the Short" had been a mistake from the beginning.

England's Breakfast Revolution**
Health experts agree that a good breakfast is very important. However, breakfast is a relatively new meal in England. In medieval times, people rarely wrote about breakfast. There are some mentions of travelers eating a meal at dawn before long journeys and sick people having breakfast for health reasons, but most people did not eat breakfast unless they were kings or nobles.
In the sixteenth century, breakfast started to become common for everyone. Some writers say this happened because food became easier to get. However, they may not have thought about other important changes in society. For example, new job patterns meant that more people had to work set hours. Many of these jobs started very early in the morning. Because of this, eating a meal in the morning became necessary and was not just for rich people anymore.

**Photography**  
When a photographer takes a picture, they choose what to show based on their skills, personal views, and experiences, as well as social and cultural influences. In this book, we will explore how these factors affect the style, content, and meaning of a photograph, and how viewers understand and react to these images. For example, a casual reader of a newspaper usually understands the photographs printed in it. However, instead of just accepting the photograph as it is, we might ask if it truly shows what the scene looked like at that time. Or, does it show the photographer's opinion? Is the exact moment captured important, or should we see the photograph as a symbol of a situation in the world?
**More than a Game**  
For me, sport is more than just a game. The most successful athletes have strong self-belief. You need to focus completely if you want to succeed in sports. There is only one way to be the best, and you must put everything else aside. Sports can be tough, and no one will do the work for you. It’s a matter of survival. Sports have taught me discipline and determination, but they also show the importance of teamwork. My sport allows me to shine individually, but it is still a team game, and I must balance both. It is similar to life – you can succeed alone, but you should not forget about others around you. Sports have given me a lot, not just money. They have opened doors for me and shown me things around the world that many people will never see. However, you also have to give up a lot to enjoy these benefits.
**Tuning In**  
Some experiences stay in our memory so clearly that they become special moments we remember well. For me, one such moment happened one night in California many years ago. I was awake, listening to a beautiful mockingbird singing from a tree in my neighborhood. I don’t have trouble sleeping, but the bird's amazing song kept me awake. As I listened to its complex melodies, I felt like I was in a wonderful musical world. To understand the bird's patterns, I used my knowledge of jazz and Indian classical music. The bird made me feel like I was enjoying a stunning live performance. I reacted with joy as the bird sang different musical variations through my open window, until I finally fell asleep.

People have always had strong feelings about birds. They love them, fear them, and even worship them. But what does this say about us? Paul Evans reports.
In a greenhouse, a little brown bird called a wren is bumping against the glass. Some people think this bird has a special message, while others see it as just a bird that is stuck. Both ideas could be true. Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In medieval times, people believed that the way wrens flew could tell them about their luck. Today, wrens are still seen in pictures and decorations in many British homes. Even if old beliefs about them are not as strong now, people still care about wrens. A place without wrens feels sad.
This connection to birds comes from a time when people relied more on nature for survival. They developed a way to understand the importance of other creatures. However, these beliefs can change over time. For example, the red kite bird was once seen as a valuable part of city life in London. But later, people thought of them as pests, and they almost disappeared from many areas. Now, red kites are seen as important birds again and are being protected and reintroduced to help them thrive.
Our connection with birds goes back to the beginning of human history. Early humans watched birds closely because they could warn them about danger, bad weather, and food. Birds also connected them to their dreams. When we think about why birds matter to us, we are also thinking about what it means to be human. Birds can fly, sing, and represent freedom. Our interest in birds reflects our own identity and our relationship with nature.
Some people might think our feelings for birds are old-fashioned and not important today. But these feelings are still part of us, and losing them would be hard. That is why, in recent years, birds have become important indicators of environmental change. In Britain, 30 bird species are now endangered. This is sad not only because we might lose these birds but also because it represents a loss of culture. Birds like the skylark, turtle dove, and lapwing symbolize love and magic. Many people feel sad about losing these birds, especially those mentioned in famous poems and stories.
However, the loss of other birds that are not part of literature or folklore is often ignored. Folklore is important because it includes stories and legends that connect us to the past. These stories have a stronger bond with people than scientific facts. They help us feel emotions that are often hidden in our busy lives. Whether we watch birds on TV or in our backyards, the joy we feel cannot be fully explained by science. Birds engage us in ways that are hard to understand, and the stories we tell about them help us make sense of our feelings. The wren in the greenhouse connects our present with a rich history, holding onto its song and moving into the future—a mystery that keeps us thinking.

Maps**
The purpose of a map is to show the relationships between different points and features on the earth's surface. These relationships are based on distance and direction. In the past, people often measured distance in time, like saying "it takes so many hours to walk" or "a day's journey by river." This way of measuring was more about how easy it was to travel through the land than about the actual distance. 
Direction is also important, but for most travelers, the main questions were "Where do I go from here?" and "How far away is it?" Because of this, written directions were often just as important as maps. Even today, some maps, like those for train systems, do not always show true directions. 
In the beginning, important landmarks along a route were marked by signs, which could be realistic or simple, and their size showed how important they were. The way maps were made varied depending on their purpose and location, so it is important to understand the specific style used when studying early maps.
The history of map-making, or cartography, is mostly about how the accuracy of distance and direction has improved over time. Other sciences have helped in this process. For example, instead of using shadows or stars to find direction, people started using the magnetic compass. They also created tools that allowed them to measure angles very accurately.
As people explored more of the world, they tried to create maps of what they knew. Astronomers found out that the earth is not a perfect sphere but is slightly flat at the poles, which helped improve maps of large areas. 
Over time, the needs of map users changed. Travelers and merchants were not the only ones using maps anymore. Soldiers, especially after the invention of artillery, needed accurate maps to understand the land better. This led to the creation of contour maps. Later, archaeologists, historians, and modern geographers also had their own specific needs for maps.
Today, cartographers create maps for many different purposes, including geological layers, climate, and land use. The growing recognition of the importance of maps in many sciences has led to a new era in cartography. 
It is important to note that the development of maps has not always been steady. There have been times of slow progress, mixed with periods of rapid change. Old ideas sometimes stayed alongside new ones. Cartographers have often had good ideas but had to wait for better tools to use them. Since it is easy to copy old maps, many map publishers have been slow to accept new ideas. 
Therefore, we should not blindly trust maps as proof of current knowledge and techniques. The many maps we have today are the result of a lot of human effort and thought. They are a valuable record for those studying history. This is what makes the study of historical cartography so interesting and important.

I met a young man named Andrew Lloyd Webber in his nice living room. It was much better than the messy rooms where his family spent time. Andrew had a huge collection of records, the first stereo record player I had ever seen, and even expensive wine glasses and furniture. He had a scholarship to study history at Magdalen College, Oxford, and had nine months before starting school. During this time, he wanted to become a famous composer like Richard Rodgers.
I also had big dreams. I wanted to be a pop star for reasons like money and fame. But my dreams were not as important to me as Andrew's were to him. When Andrew suggested that I try to be a famous lyricist like Oscar Hammerstein, I was happy to give it a try. He played me some of his music, and I could tell he was very talented.
We agreed to meet again and write something together. I was still more interested in pop music than in musical theatre, but I knew I had met someone special. I thought it would be exciting to work with him, even if we didn’t become famous right away. I was also thinking about how I might still end up as a lawyer, as my father expected.
The next day, back at my office where I was training to be a lawyer, I felt less sure about a future in show business. I still looked for ads for bands needing a singer and wrote some simple songs. I worried that I might stop enjoying pop music soon, as my father predicted.
But I wanted to see Andrew again. He was interesting and talked about food and architecture. He had been working on a musical about Dr. Thomas Barnardo, a man who started orphanages in the 19th century. I thought the story was good, but not very exciting. Andrew believed in his music, and I could see he had talent.
I started working on the lyrics for the musical with a lot of energy, especially for the funny songs. Andrew shared the plot and played me the music. I even skipped a day at the law office to write my first lyrics. That day, I didn’t know it, but I was starting a new career. 
**Questions:**
1. Who is the young man that Tim Rice met?
2. What did Andrew Lloyd Webber want to study at university?
3. Why did Tim Rice want to be a pop star?
4. What was the name of the philanthropist that Andrew's musical was about?
5. How did Tim Rice feel about the story of Dr. Thomas Barnardo?
6. What did Tim Rice do instead of going to work one day?

**Text:**
**Language**  
You and I are part of a species that can communicate with each other very well. Language is a big part of being human, and it is hard to imagine life without it. If you see two or more people together anywhere in the world, they will likely start talking. When people are alone, they often talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I like to think of language as an 'instinct'. This means that people know how to talk, just like spiders know how to make webs. Spiders did not invent web-making, and it does not require special education or skills.
**Climate and Weather**  
Climate and weather, which are created by the air around us, greatly affect the lives of animals and plants. Climate can change how landscapes look. For example, warm and wet weather all year allows tropical jungles to grow, which are full of many different species. In contrast, cold and windy areas have fewer living things. The daily weather patterns that create the climate are caused by large air masses rising and mixing, as the atmosphere is always moving. Some of this movement is because the air is on a spinning Earth, and the thin air does not move at the same speed as the Earth. However, the sun is a more important cause of air movement.
**Coffee**  
As a barista, my job included serving drinks, but I was also responsible for making coffee. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, a restaurant's success can depend on its coffee. I spent several days learning how to make coffee, including how to clean and maintain the restaurant's espresso machine. I also learned how to make a good cappuccino. By the end of the first week, I realized that making a good cup of coffee was harder than it seemed, and I thought I might have to go back to cleaning ashtrays. Luckily, my boss was patient. He said, "Making coffee is both an art and a science, and you need time to learn it."

Art on TV**
Why does television often struggle with programs about visual arts? Painting and sculpture are great subjects for the camera because it can show the whole artwork and then zoom in to see the details. However, there are not many TV series that show the joy and complexity of looking at art. A good example of this is Robert Hughes's series called *American Visions*, which has eight parts. Hughes is a trusted critic with a strong personality, and he has almost eight hours to introduce British viewers to American art, which is often ignored in British galleries. I expected the series to focus on famous artworks, but instead, it looked at how American history and culture are shown in its art and buildings.
**Dealing in Metals**
For 20 years, I worked as an international metals dealer and became known as a speculator. The metals market is not as regulated as other markets. With some luck, a willingness to take risks, and a good understanding of the market, it is possible to make a lot of money. Taking risks is part of this industry. This adventurous culture fits well with a free-market global economy. However, the free-trade economists who believed that the market would keep the prices of scarce metals high have found the opposite is true. More minerals are being extracted, and the cost of raw materials is going down. When considering inflation, the prices of most metals are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to investigate claims against a large company that benefits from these cheap raw materials.
**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**
Abaco and its nearby cays are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas, which stretch from Florida to Cuba. Each island has its own character and something special to offer. To get around the islands and cays of Abaco, you need a boat. If a boat is not included with your room, don’t worry. There are many ferries and water taxis available. You can also rent boats if you want to explore on your own. Sailing is the most popular way to travel here. Abaco is called 'The Sailing Capital of the World' for good reasons. The calm, protected waters are perfect for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The cays and their beaches stretch for 200 miles like a string of pearls. At night, the lights of the restaurants and cafes in Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay shine brightly.

Build Your Own Bamboo Bike at the UK’s First Workshop**
You can build your own bike at the Bamboo Bike Club in the UK. This workshop is run by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan. When you join a course, you get a custom bike frame designed by a computer and a fun weekend of bike-building.
It is Saturday morning in Hackney Wick, east London. The Bamboo Bike Club is the only place in Britain where you can learn to build bikes from bamboo. I went to see what was happening. There was a lot of energy and fun in the workshop. Bamboo is becoming popular for making bikes again. Companies like Calfee Design from California and Bamboo Bikes from Yorkshire have brought back this method, which started in 1894. However, many cyclists find bamboo bikes too expensive. A ready-made bamboo frame can cost around $2,995 or £1,868. 
James and Ian wanted to create a bamboo bike business that was affordable for regular cyclists. They spent years working in a shed in Brecon, Wales, to develop their idea. They realized they did not just want to sell bike frames; they wanted to help people enjoy making something special and sustainable. This led to the Bamboo Bike Club, which is more about community than business. James works on wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer, but they run the club in their free time. 
They offer monthly courses where you can build your own bike frame at a good price. On the first day, James and Ian teach you how to choose strong bamboo and how to make strong joints. You start by putting together the front triangle of the bike, then the seat and chain assembly. They use alloy tubes for parts that need extra strength, like the handlebars and wheel forks. 
For someone like me, who is not very good at DIY, this can be challenging. James and Ian help everyone by checking each cut and joint. They are friendly and encourage you to try again if you make a mistake. The bamboo is already checked for quality, so you can choose how your bike will look: plain bamboo, black, or mottled.
On Sunday, you spend time building the lugs, which are the parts that connect the frame. You wrap the joints with hemp bindings and glue them to make them strong. After adding a waterproof coating, your bike is ready for wheels, brakes, gears, and other personal touches. James and Ian say their bamboo bikes are just as strong as metal bikes. Ian has used his bike for over a year, and James has tested his bike off-road for three months without breaking it.
While bamboo bikes may not look as polished as metal ones, they are unique. James and Ian believe that the individuality of each bike is important. I think bamboo bikes are great for relaxed rides rather than racing. I chose a 'Classic English' frame for a smooth ride. 
I tried James's bike, and it felt light and smooth, thanks to bamboo's ability to absorb bumps. James says that the real joy of these bikes comes when you ride them. They are fun and easy to ride. The best part? The price is less than £500.

**Self-help Books**  
Diane Reverend was an editor at Random House in New York when she first saw a book by a new pop psychologist, Dr. John Gray. "I knew it would be a bestseller," she says, and she was right. Dr. Gray is now very rich, and Diane Reverend has her own company. Dr. Gray's book helps people communicate better between men and women. It is very popular and is part of a big self-help industry that tries to help people improve their lives. This industry also creates many new needs and supports the publishing world in New York. In Britain, people are seeing that many self-help books are not very good, but many are published anyway. For every self-help book that is published, many others are not accepted because they are too similar or too specific. This is a good thing. Editors are always looking for the next big hit, and they care more about how well a book can sell than about the writing style. "How marketable is the author? What's the 'hook'? Is it something everyone can relate to?" Diane Reverend lists the important questions. She adds, "If someone has a catchy title, that's a big part of the success. It means you can reach people."
**Autobiographies**  
When someone writes an autobiography, there should be an understanding that they are telling the truth. However, this is often not fully followed. There are many reasons why a writer might not tell the whole truth. They might feel ashamed of certain actions or thoughts. They might think some things are not important enough to share. Sometimes, writers may choose to invent stories that express the truth better than just sticking to the facts. They might call their book an autobiography just to make readers believe it is true, even if it is mostly fiction. This can happen without any bad intentions.
**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**  
People who study detective stories say that this genre reflects the problems of society in the late 1800s and early 1900s. A detective story often symbolizes human desires like greed or lust, and solving the crime helps restore order in society. In Hammett's stories, society is shown to be corrupt. The detective and the criminal are two sides of the same person. They understand each other and have a strange connection. The detective is seen as too honest by criminals and too shady by the law. He is both a criminal and a competitor. Sometimes, the detective feels guilty about his role, and this can make him more eager to punish the criminal.
**Science Writing**  
Stephen Jay Gould is one of the best science writers today. I met him at the Grand Hotel while he was promoting his new book. Neither of us felt comfortable there. Gould said he could not write well in such a fancy place. He believes that knowing the culture is important for a writer. Science is its own world, and only scientists can explain it well. If you do not understand the science community, you will struggle to write about it. One of Gould's main ideas is: never write down to your readers. "Do not make it too easy," he says. "You can use simpler words, but do not change the main ideas. If readers feel you are talking down to them, they will not enjoy your writing."

**Air-conditioning**  
At Cannons Gym, a popular place for City of London workers during lunch, it feels very cold inside. To handle the high summer temperatures, the gym has used a lot of air-conditioning. Sometimes, when it is quiet, the gym feels like it is in the Arctic. This shows how people often misuse air-conditioning today. It is now a common part of work and leisure, showing how humans can control the climate. However, many air-conditioned buildings could use other ways to stay cool. They could use natural light and fresh air, and have thicker walls that keep heat out during the day and let it go at night. These ideas may seem simple, but they can make a big difference and would reduce the need for air-conditioning.
**Sundials**  
It is interesting that as we start a new millennium, more people are interested in sundials. Sundials are tools that tell time by the position of the sun. A hundred years ago, they were very important for keeping time. As clocks and watches became better, sundials were mostly seen as garden decorations. Now, they are being taken seriously again. David Harber, who makes sundials, believes people like them because they connect us to the planets. He says there is a special moment when a sundial starts to work. They are calm and beautiful objects that remind us of our place in the universe.
**Paint Your Own China**  
My idea of china-painting came from a visit to an arts and crafts show long ago. There, serious-looking older women showed how to paint delicate flowers on a teacup with careful brushstrokes. It was fascinating to watch because each stroke created a perfect petal or leaf. Their hands were steady, and the paint never smudged. I thought these women must have practiced for many years or had a special talent. Because of this, I wondered what kind of people would join a china-painting class. Would beginners be good at it? However, the atmosphere in the class was friendly and fun. The students were there to enjoy themselves, and even the teacher did not want to paint flowers on teacups as quickly as I had remembered.

The Wrong Country**
Uncle chose a package holiday for Keith and Dawne at a good price. They had a flight from Gatwick Airport and twelve nights in Venice, in a hotel called Pensione Concordia. When they went to the travel agency to book the trip, the clerk told them that the other people in their group were a school group from the south coast, all learning Italian. But something went wrong. They ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, somewhere in Switzerland.
At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their tickets and said everything was fine. An hour later, they were surprised to hear older people on the plane speaking with accents from the North of England. Keith thought there might have been a cancellation or that the Italian class was on another plane. They ordered drinks, and then more drinks. 
When they landed, a stout woman with glasses told them to stay together. The brochure did not mention an overnight stop, but when the coach arrived at its destination, Keith realized that this was clearly an overnight stop. It was close to midnight, and they were tired, so they did not question their right to the beds they were offered. But the next morning, they were worried when they found out they were being offered the beds for their whole holiday. 
The receptionist smiled and said, "We have the lake and the water birds. You can take a boat to Interlaken." Keith calmly told him, "There has been a mistake. We were supposed to be in Venice, at the Pensione Concordia." The receptionist replied, "I do not know that name. This is Switzerland." 
Keith insisted, "A coach is supposed to take us on. An official said so on the plane." The receptionist said, "Your group is booked for twelve nights in the Edelweiss Hotel. If you have changed your minds..." Keith interrupted, "We haven't changed our minds. There has been a mistake." The receptionist shook his head, saying he did not know about any mistake.
Dawne added, "The man who made the booking was bald, with glasses and a moustache." She gave the name of the travel agency in London. A woman named Mrs. Franks, who was the stout woman from the plane, approached them. She smiled and said, "I am married to the man with the bad leg." Dawne asked, "Are you in charge, Mrs. Franks? We are in the wrong hotel." 
Keith explained, "It seems we got into the wrong group. We reported to the Your-Kind-of-Holiday girl and left it to her." Dawne added, "We should have known when they weren't from Dover. We heard them talking about Darlington." Keith wished she would let him talk. 
He said to Mrs. Franks, "We noticed you at Gatwick. We knew you were in charge." Mrs. Franks replied, "I counted you, but you probably didn't see me. Let me explain. Your-Kind-of-Holiday sends clients to many places, with different holidays at different prices. There are villa holidays for young people and treks to Turkey and the Himalayas." 
She continued, "All tickets and labels look similar, yellow with two red bands. If you followed others with the yellow-and-red label, you might think you could end up anywhere!" She laughed and added, "But that couldn't happen." 
Keith insisted, "We are not supposed to be in Switzerland." Mrs. Franks said, "Let's see." She then walked away, leaving them standing there. The receptionist was no longer at the desk, and they could hear typing. 
Dawne whispered, "She seems kind." But Keith was not listening. He thought about everything that had happened: giving the tickets, waiting, and then boarding the plane. An elderly man interrupted his thoughts, saying, "Nice to have some young people here. My name is Nottage." His wife said they had the best night's sleep they had in years because of the lakeside air. 
"That's nice," Dawne said. Keith walked out of the reception area, and Dawne followed him. Outside the hotel, they did not say that it was ironic they had ended up on a holiday with older people when they wanted to escape from them. Uncle had said so himself when they tried to convince him to join them.

'HE WAS A PEOPLE PERSON'**
American business leaders are looking to the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton as a good example of management. Eluned Price reports.
Most people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and what he did. However, America has only recently discovered him. The Wall Street Journal called Shackleton "an Antarctic explorer whose achievements went mostly unnoticed for most of the 20th century," which is not entirely true. Now, Americans are showing great interest in him. Many biographies and stories about his famous voyage on the Endurance are being published. The American Museum of Natural History is planning a big exhibition, and a film about Shackleton's life is being made.
Some American managers see Shackleton as a role model. They tell stories about his actions with great respect and find lessons in his leadership and communication skills. They even refer to each other as "speaking Shackleton." Shackleton, known for his determination and resourcefulness, has become a model for modern management consultants.
Jim MacGregor, a managing partner at Abernathy MacGregor Frank in New York, has looked up to Shackleton for many years. His firm focuses on communication during mergers, acquisitions, and corporate crises. For example, they deal with situations like "the factory exploded" or "half the workers have to be let go." While Shackleton did work in public relations for a steel company in Glasgow, it might be hard to see how his experiences in extreme conditions relate to modern business problems.
"Even if a company handles its crises well, it can still cause harm by communicating poorly," says MacGregor. "Shackleton is a model for management because he was a strong leader and communicator. He had clear values and was at his best when he and his team had a lot to lose, like their lives."
One of Shackleton's most interesting decisions was to turn back when he was only 97 miles from the South Pole. This decision showed his commitment to his men's safety. In a crisis, people want to know who is in charge. While many managers today avoid responsibility, Shackleton was willing to take charge.
His 1914 expedition became legendary. His ship, the Endurance, was trapped in ice for nine months and eventually sank. When the ship went down, Shackleton told his men, "We should all reach safety if you do your best and trust me." From the diaries kept during the journey, it is clear that Shackleton was always in control. 
"Shackleton thought everything through, planned for every situation, kept his men informed, and asked for their opinions," says MacGregor. "He was flexible and ready to change plans when needed. We have developed effective principles based on Shackleton's story that clients can relate to without feeling criticized."
Shackleton believed that an explorer needs optimism, physical strength, and patience. "One of the hardest things to do in tough times is to wait, especially in America, where people want quick solutions," says MacGregor. "If you invest in bonds and guess wrong about interest rates, you should hold on and wait to get your money back. Selling too soon would mean a big loss. Also, don’t be afraid to change your plans if they are not working. If a new product is not selling well, stop selling it."
Shackleton led by example. On the way back from the Endurance, he saw Hurley, the expedition photographer, without gloves. He insisted that Hurley wear his gloves, saying he would throw them overboard if he didn’t. Someone else remembered Shackleton doing something similar with a biscuit when they were close to starving on a previous expedition: "He said he would leave it in the snow. Millions of pounds could not buy that biscuit."
As Caroline Alexander, author of *Endurance*, says: "The public's interest in heroic actions is growing. Shackleton shows that there is little heroism today. He stands out as a true example of the ideals we long for now."

'Finding Food in Madagascar'**
In the forests of Madagascar, there is a special animal called the aye-aye. This primate has a way of finding food that is similar to how a woodpecker does. Both the aye-aye and the woodpecker look for insects by digging into wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes and its long tongue to get the insects. The aye-aye, however, uses its sharp front teeth to chew into the wood and its long third finger to reach inside and get the insects.
Scientists have studied the aye-aye's feeding habits for many years. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University has been watching two male aye-ayes named Nosferatu and Poe, a female named Samantha, and her baby, Annabelle. He wanted to see how they find insects hidden in the wood. 
Dr. Erickson first checked if the aye-ayes could find insects by looking for signs, like holes in the wood where insects might have entered. He gave them logs with small holes. Some holes had mealworms inside, while others were empty. The aye-ayes went straight to the logs with food, showing they did not need to see the holes to find the mealworms. 
Dr. Erickson thought the aye-ayes might be using their sense of smell or hearing to find the insects. However, tests showed they could find mealworms even when they could not smell them or when the mealworms were dead and silent. So, how did they find the food? 
Dr. Erickson found that the aye-ayes would chew into both empty spaces and those with mealworms. They seemed to sense the hollow spaces in the wood. When looking for food, an aye-aye taps the wood with its long finger and listens carefully. Dr. Erickson believes the aye-aye is using echo-location, which means it listens for sounds that bounce back to find hollow areas. It can also hear insects moving when they are disturbed.
Some scientists think that the aye-aye takes the place of woodpeckers in Madagascar, but there are also birds like the Sickle-billed and Nuthatch Vangas that look for insects in wood. So, the woodpecker role may not be empty. The aye-aye is unique because it acts like both a woodpecker and a bat that uses echo-location. It also behaves like a squirrel. Its front teeth keep growing, just like a squirrel's, and it has been seen in the wild chewing through nuts and using its long finger to get the nut meat inside.

'Ordinary People, Ordinary Lives'**
Most of us have pictures of our grandparents, but how many of us know what their lives were like when they were young? The few diaries we have are often not enough, and family stories are sometimes only half-remembered. What will our grandchildren know about us? We often plan to write things down, but we never seem to do it. We might leave videos instead of photographs, but videos are still just images. 
Hannah Renier has found a solution: she writes autobiographies for other people. She creates a book of at least 20,000 words, with pictures if needed. Her books are not about famous people, but about ordinary lives. The idea came to her when she spoke with her family and realized how much of the past was being forgotten. 
"When I started, I didn’t take it as seriously as I do now," she says. "I met people who really wanted to share their interesting lives. They say they are doing it for their children or for future generations, but they enjoy it too." The promise of privacy helps people feel free to share their true feelings. 
"I felt I could be honest," says a 62-year-old man who has made and lost money in his life. "I was surprised by what I shared. There were painful things, like my divorce." He wrote his story for his family, but he hasn’t let his children read it yet. "There are things that might hurt them, and I want to wait until after I’m gone for them to read it." 
He also noticed patterns from his childhood that caused him to repeat mistakes. Ms. Renier has seen this in others too. "Many people are influenced by their parents," she says. "The things they learned as children affect them for the rest of their lives. They often marry people their parents liked or choose partners to rebel against their parents." 
"Many people still regret things from their past. Even after many years, they hold onto feelings about their parents. If they had problems when they were young, they still have them as adults. They try to impress parents who were never impressed, and some want to say, 'I can’t stand my mother.'" 
Ms. Renier listens more than she asks questions. "I’m not here to judge or be nosy. Sometimes people share something and then say, 'I’m not sure if that should be included.' I usually keep it in, but they can change it later. Most people want to be honest." 
"This is not about showing off. It’s not about saying, 'Look at my interesting life.' Things are changing quickly, and we are forgetting our past. This work helps people connect with their roots. We need to remember our ancestors because families are not as close as they used to be. People want to feel a sense of lasting memory." 
Each book includes up to 30 hours of recorded interviews, which Ms. Renier uses to write the life story, organizing the events and adding her interpretation. Modern technology helps her create everything except the binding with its gold lettering. You can choose the color of the cover and the title. 
The final books are well-organized and written nicely. They are not cheap, costing nearly £3,000, with extra copies at £25 each. Ms. Renier gets about 10 inquiries each week, but the price stops many people from buying. "I thought it would be less expensive than it is," she says. "But the people I’ve worked with are often from wealthy backgrounds, readers of magazines like Harpers & Queen, which is where I advertise. They are the kind of people who would have had their portraits painted for their families."

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**  
The Museum of Classical Archaeology has one of the few collections of casts of Greek and Roman sculptures in the world, with over six hundred pieces. It is important to know that none of the sculptures are real. All the sculptures are exact copies made from the originals, mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Museum is in a specially built gallery with great natural light. The benefits of plaster casts are many: groups of sculptures that were originally displayed together but are now in different museums across Europe can be seen together as they were meant to be. You can see almost all the famous works of Greek and Roman sculpture in one afternoon.
**B. Cambridge Darkroom**  
Cambridge Darkroom is a place for photography that has community darkrooms and a gallery showing different photography exhibitions. We often run courses and workshops for people of all ages and skill levels, including a popular Beginner's Course, a shorter Induction Course, and Master Classes with guest photographers. We have a membership program that allows all members to use our darkrooms. We also help young photographers (aged 12 to 16) improve their skills with our Young Members program, led by our resident photographer. We sell photography books and magazines and have a full range of photographic materials.
**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**  
The Sedgwick Museum has a wonderful collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks, and minerals from all geological ages and parts of the world. It also has Britain's oldest complete geological collection, from Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728). This collection includes nearly 10,000 rare and interesting specimens stored in their original cabinets from the early 18th century. Adam Sedgwick was a Professor of Geology and took care of the Woodwardian collection. Throughout his life, he greatly increased the collections, creating a truly outstanding museum. The collection is organized by geological age so that the major changes in life on Earth can be seen over time. The new Whewell Gallery displays the beautiful minerals and gems of the collection. The displays have clear labels to explain what they are and how they are used today.
**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**  
There are over 400,000 air photographs in the collection, taken by university staff over the last 45 years. The University has its own aircraft based at Cambridge Airport and takes photographs all over Great Britain. The photographs are interesting as they show a detailed record of the landscape, showing both nature and human activity from prehistoric times to today. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the helpful library staff can answer questions. The photographs cannot be borrowed, but copies can usually be bought. These are made to order and usually take about a month.
**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**  
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is the second oldest and longest-running centre in the world, and it is one of the most unusual tourist attractions in the region. You can have hours of fun creating wall hangings by rubbing one of over a hundred different brass plates from the tombs of medieval knights and ladies. By making resin copies, called facsimiles, the centre has preserved the originals and made brass rubbing an enjoyable activity for everyone. The brass plates, which are another way to remember the tomb statues, spread from Germany across medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Many beautiful brasses were destroyed during various revolutions. Most of the remaining brasses are in Britain, and the widest range can be seen at the Cambridge Centre.

From Here to Fatherhood**
**A. The Theatre Director**  
I have had a strange personal life, but I have been lucky to spend 35 years with small children, and I have loved every moment. This morning, I enjoyed feeding the baby, which is what being a father means to me. I feel very lucky with my children. We all enjoy the same things: opera, theatre, books, and music. This brings us closer, especially now that they are mostly grown up and I feel more like a friend than a father. I do not believe in hitting children. I have slapped my children in anger before, but I do not think it is right. I may not have been the most attentive father, but I have always tried to be there for them. I am available if they need me, but I believe they should reach out to me. If I chase them to ask why they haven’t called, it makes them feel guilty. My parents did that to me, and I would never do that to my children.
**B. The Advertising Executive**  
I was young when my children were born, only about 25, and I found the responsibilities hard at times. It made me feel older quickly, but it also kept me young, which I appreciate. As they became teenagers, they showed me things I might have missed, like music and fashion. This has helped me in my job. I missed some important events when they were young, like their first concerts and sports days, and I feel sad about that. However, now I can take them on holidays to the south of France. They get along well with my friends and come to parties and work events without feeling nervous. I think it helps that my job is seen as interesting.
**C. The Politician**  
My first child was born just as I was starting my political career, and I had more children soon after. My wife and I promised to spend time with them, but as I became more involved in politics, it became harder to find time. I only accept weekend meetings and events where my kids can come with me. If I didn’t, they would feel left out. This way, they can see what I do when I am not with them, and they don’t feel like I am disappearing. I have noticed more politicians bringing their kids to work. Maybe we are all realizing how important it is to include our children in our lives.
**D. The Writer**  
My first marriage ended when my daughters, Kate and Bonnie, were young, so I had to think more about being a father. I worked hard to stay close to my children. My ex-wife and I even tried living next to each other for a while, so they could visit easily, but I think it confused them. Kate has said in interviews that I was always there for her, but I am not sure I was a good father. I was around a lot, but I think I treated my kids like adults too soon. Kate recently said that we were too relaxed as parents. I wish I had set more rules and structure. I still worry about my older daughters just as much as I do about my youngest. In that way, your children never really leave you.
**E. The TV Presenter**  
I was ready for kids. I was 30, had met my wife, and we had a nice home, so we thought, "Why not have a child instead of just buying new furniture?" Having my daughter Betty has helped me understand who I am. It feels special to have a child, but it also makes you just one of many parents. Sometimes I feel frustrated, but just one smile from her makes everything better. A baby's smile is the best way to feel happy.

**THEATRE**
**A. Tamburlaine the Great**  
Marlowe's play about a powerful warrior can feel very long, but Terry Hands' production makes it exciting. He has cut parts of the text and created a show that is fast and full of energy. Antony Sher plays the main character and gives a great performance, doing impressive stunts while speaking. The audience is captivated by his intense desire for power.  
*Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*
**B. Women Laughing**  
This play by the late Michael Wall is now in London after being shown in Manchester. The first act creates a tense feeling as two married couples talk on a sunny lawn. In the second act, the story changes and becomes a strong, emotional look at the effects of illness. Wall was a talented writer who died too young at 44.  
*Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)*
**C. Amphibians**  
Billy Roche is a new Irish playwright who has added to English theatre. His plays are set in Wexford, and this one looks at the decline of the fishing industry with deep characters, strong emotions, and some funny moments. The play can feel a bit aimless at times, but it builds to an exciting ending.  
*Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*
**D. Murder by Misadventure**  
This is a traditional thriller about "the perfect murder." Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play two crime writers who want to kill each other. Although the story is familiar, the surprises are clever.  
*Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)*
**E. The Alchemist**  
Young director Sam Mendes finds the humor in Jonson's comedy about 17th-century tricksters. After a successful run at the Swan Theatre, the show is now on the Barbican's main stage, with Jonathan Hyde, David Bradley, and Joanne Pearce giving great performances as the three con-artists.  
*Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*

Peter James' production of Harley Granville Barker's comedy about fashion and women's roles in Edwardian society is now in London after being successful at the Edinburgh Festival. The staging is stylish, the acting is excellent, and the play is a classic that deserves more attention.

This new musical by playwright Alan Ayckbourn tells a version of Beauty and the Beast set in a London suburb. It features a beautiful score by John Pattison and a heartfelt celebration of love, making it a charming show.  
*Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)*

David Thacker's production of Shakespeare's comedy was not very good, but it is saved by strong performances from Ron Cook as Dr. Caius and Anton Lesser as the jealous husband, Ford. Many other actors seem uncomfortable in their roles.  
*Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*
**I. The Voysey Inheritance**  
This is another important revival of Granville Barker's work, now touring. It tells the story of a respectable lawyer who leaves a corrupt financial legacy to his son, resulting in a great play.  
*Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)*

**Hide and Seek**  
*Yvonne Coppard*  
Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game where they watch a strange bookshop. Emma sees that one of the few customers is her Uncle Jim. He tricks her and tries to turn her against her friends. When Emma's life is in danger, the story becomes very serious. She is locked in the cellar of an old house. This book shows family life, childhood friendships, and warns that adults are not always safe. It is an important and interesting read.
**Backtrack**  
*Peter Hunt*  
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, work together when they find out that their family members were involved in a train accident in 1915, where eight people died. Different viewpoints and documents like maps and personal stories help the reader understand what happened. This is a clever and complex novel that needs careful reading.
**Pigeon Summer**  
*Ann Turnbull*  
Mary Dyer does not fit in with her family or the male-dominated culture. She loves her father's racing pigeons and takes care of them when he goes away for work, even though her mother is upset. Set in 1930, this story teaches that "There are different kinds of cleverness." Thoughtful readers will enjoy it.
**Yaxley's Cat**  
*Robert Westall*  
In this chilling story, a mature woman named Rose rents a cottage to escape her unhappy life with her husband. She brings her two children with her. A fierce cat and strange items in the cottage reveal why the last tenant, Sepp Yaxley, disappeared. However, the locals do not welcome them, and their lives are in danger. By the end, the violence is controlled, but Rose is still troubled by her son’s behavior. It is a gripping story.
**Someone's Mother is Missing**  
*Harry Mazer*  
Sam is a chubby and talkative boy who admires his cool cousin, Lisa, who comes from a wealthy family. When Lisa's life falls apart, Sam helps her find balance, and they both learn the importance of family. The story moves slowly at times, but it has gentle humor and shows the growing friendship between the two teenagers. It can be interesting for both boys and girls.
**Stanley's Aquarium**  
*Barry Faville*  
Barry Faville writes with confidence and humor, bringing his New Zealand setting to life. Robbie takes a job gardening for an old man named Stanley. At first, she finds him interesting, but later she is disturbed by what he keeps in his aquarium and his plans for them. The story takes a thrilling turn while still exploring character and relationships. It is unusual and compelling.
**Dodger**  
*Libby Gleeson*  
This is a sad story about Mick, who has troubled relationships and a difficult school life. The story is told through flashbacks, letters from a teacher, and Mick's own notes. He learns to deal with the negative views of others and his own low self-esteem through a school play and the help of a caring teacher. It is highly recommended, even though it is a painful read, especially at the end.

'Science and Weightlessness'**
Journalist Tom Mumford joins students who are testing their ideas in weightlessness. The aircraft looked normal from the outside. The pilot told the 13 students from Europe and America that it was built in 1964 and was a Boeing KC-135 refueling tanker, based on the Boeing 707. But inside, it was very different. The inside was a long white tunnel with few windows and bright lights along the padded walls. Most of the seats were removed, except for a few at the back where the nervous students sat.
For 12 months, these students had competed to join this special flight offered by the European Space Agency. They had to suggest creative experiments to do in weightless conditions. The best ideas won a place on this unique flight, which felt like an amazing roller-coaster ride. For the next two hours, the Boeing would fly in a way that felt like a giant bird flying up and down. 
When the pilot cut the engines at 3,000 meters, the aircraft went higher because of its speed before falling back down. In the few seconds between going up and coming down, everything inside the aircraft became weightless. The students would feel like they were closer to the moon than to the Earth.
The flight took off smoothly, but the students quickly realized this was not a normal flight when the pilot made the plane climb steeply for about 20 seconds. The engines roared, and the students felt the blood rush from their heads. Then the engines stopped, and they experienced weightlessness almost immediately. For 20 seconds, they floated in silence, as if the floor had turned into a trampoline. They could not tell which way was up or down. 
After ten seconds of falling, the pilot pulled the plane out of its dive. The return of gravity was sudden, and some students landed hard. After the first curve, some students felt sick thinking about the 29 more to come. Thirty curves gave them ten minutes of "space time" for their experiments. The Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to see how cats always land on their feet. They released a device to test this, and one student managed to turn it over using a remote control. 
A German team from the University of Aachen studied how metal joints are affected by weightlessness, which is important for building future space stations. Another team from Utah State University worked on creating solar sails from thin liquid films that harden in sunlight. They believe that once they perfect this process, satellites could use solar sails like yachts use wind.
After two hours of flying between heaven and Earth, the students felt excited, not sick. One student said, "It was an unforgettable experience. I wanted to be an astronaut before, but now I want to even more."

**With the Trees, I Planted My Stake in New Zealand**  
**JONATHON PORRITT TALKS TO DANNY DANZIGER**
Jonathon Porritt is the author of *Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology*. 
I had a strange time in my life when I didn’t have any summers. I went to New Zealand every summer, which is actually winter there. So, I had nine winters in a row, which was great because I like winter. My parents had the idea to buy a small piece of land for my brother, sister, and me to take care of. My mother said, “If you can plant trees on it, then you can have it.” The idea was that we would always have a connection to New Zealand, which is nice because my father grew up there. They found a piece of land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land is not very good, but it is good for planting trees. 
I have always been interested in land. I spent a year in Australia working on sheep farms and doing different farming jobs, so the idea of planting trees sounded nice, and I was excited. I think my family became excited too as we went along. I started planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, we had planted the whole 70 acres together. In New Zealand in 1968, it was a very rainy winter. It rained a lot, almost every day we were planting. I don’t think I have ever been so wet or cold for such a long time. 
Every morning was a challenge: getting ready for planting. I would come out of the Land Rover warm and dry, but then the rain would start, and my clothes were still damp from the day before. My boots were wet, and my hands struggled with slippery laces. “My mind starts to think about many strange ideas and reflections about life.” In that first year, I had a helper who was an experienced tree-planter, which was very helpful because I had never planted trees seriously before. 
You wear a planting bag around your neck and fill it with as many trees as you can. When the bag is full, it is heavy, and it only gets easier when it is lighter. The hardest part was getting the lines straight. You decide how far apart to plant the trees, then you line up three poles to guide you. Once you are in line, you plant all the way down the line, then turn around and come back. I enjoy hard work, and it made me fit. After a while, you can plant trees almost automatically. You get used to a rhythm and use the fewest movements to dig the hole. 
The rhythm is important. Many farming jobs require you to train your body to do the same movements, and then it becomes easy. You develop a regular process: taking the tree out of the bag, digging a hole, putting it in the ground, stamping it down, and moving on. Mentally, it is interesting. My mind starts to think about many ideas and reflections about life. A lot of my thoughts about nature and our place in it began during those days. 
I have been back to New Zealand four times since then and watched the trees grow, which is very satisfying because I planted them. I feel a connection to what happens to them. I always worry when I read news about strong winds or droughts in New Zealand. Such news makes me feel anxious. However, everything worked out well, and those trees are now 20 years old and healthy. 
I should add that I took a break from teaching and went back in 1984 for three months by myself. I wrote my first book there, *Seeing Green*. There is a simple cabin on the tree farm with just a bed, a table, and a chair. In the mornings, I would write; in the afternoons, I would prune the trees, and in the evenings, I would do research. My connection to that area is still very strong. It is the place I feel most connected to in terms of the bond between people and the earth.

'CARING FOR BADGER CUBS'**
"What now?" was my first thought when one of my helpers brought a cardboard box to me. My husband Derek and I have run an open farm in Somerset for six years, and we are known for taking care of orphaned animals. But the noise from the box—a mix of a cackle and a bark—was strange to me. I looked inside and saw three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their soft coats were like velvet, and their milky eyes looked up at me from their tiny black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most badger cubs are born between mid-January and mid-March and live underground. If they lose their mother, they often die from hunger. These three cubs were found by builders who accidentally disturbed their home while working. Their mother was found dead, and the cubs were still trying to suckle from her. They looked healthy but were cold and whimpering. After removing the fleas, I took them into the farmhouse kitchen and placed them beside the stove to keep warm. There were two females, named Primrose and Bluebell, and a male named Willow. At first, I used a syringe to feed them, but I had to wipe them with a warm cloth first to make them feel like their mother was licking them. This helped them go to the bathroom. For the first few days, I fed them every four hours. Within a week, they learned to drink from a bottle and started to move around, although a bit unsteady. They were happy with each other and a heated pad as a substitute for their mother. 
Three weeks later, I noticed that Willow seemed tired, but he was still eating normally. This was a warning sign. I should have acted quickly, but I didn’t realize how serious it was. The next morning, I found him dead. The vet said he died from a lung infection. When feeding any animal with a bottle, it is important not to let them drink too fast, as it can cause problems. In Willow's case, this led to an infection that was hard to treat, especially for such a small cub. Feeling sad about my loss, I continued to care for the other two. Then, six days later, a local farmer came to see me. He had found another male cub, abandoned by its mother. He knew she would not return, and the cub was cold and hungry. This new cub, named Willow II, joined us. At six weeks old, he was about two weeks younger than the females. I soon found out that he was very difficult to feed. I had to keep moving the bottle and squeezing it to get him to drink. After ten minutes, he would finally latch on as if he hadn’t eaten all day. By the end of April, the females were eating creamed rice and anything else I offered. Willow II was happy to stop using the bottle but had trouble eating without making a mess. Eventually, I gave him a sausage, which he slowly learned to eat. After a week of sausages, he was ready for more food. At nearly five months old, they were all eating cereals for breakfast, meat and vegetables for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, hard-boiled eggs, and sunflower seeds in the evening. Badgers usually eat 60 percent earthworms, plus beetles, baby rabbits, mice, and plants. My badgers were better off than others that year because the summer was very hot, making it hard to find earthworms.
By August, my badgers started to be active at night and would go for walks at dusk or late at night. We often walked through the cider orchard, where they would get excited and chase each other. I learned to avoid their playful nips, but Derek, who joined us less often, sometimes got caught and ended up with bruises. During these late-night walks, I saw other badgers in our field. They were likely looking for food because their own areas were disturbed. Badgers are very territorial and can be aggressive, so we put metal sheets over the gate to keep them out. The local press took pictures of me walking the badgers, and many people wanted to help us build a home for them on the farm. With advice from others, we designed a new home for the badgers. My son Daniel drew the plans, and we built a sett with tunnels, an enclosure, and a badger gate. It had three chambers, one larger than the others, with a glass side so people could see inside. As the sett was built, the badgers explored it before their walks. Eventually, they became more interested in the tunnels than in walking. The building costs were higher than we expected, but a local bus company helped fund it, and local businesses donated materials. Everyone wanted to see the badgers have a home. One evening, they finally moved in. After watching them for a while, we left them to settle. Half an hour later, I returned to check on them and saw three badgers curled up in their chambers, sound asleep. 
Now, my walks with them are not as regular, especially since they don’t wake up until midnight. We see Primrose only sometimes because she has joined a nearby sett, but Bluebell and Willow II still come to say hello before running off into the night. This is their territory now, a place they know well and a home they have happily accepted.

In Search of True North - and the Man Behind Halley's Comet**
Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow Sir Edmund Halley's journey to study compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports.
Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, one of his important achievements was to chart the 'variations of the compass' during his sea voyages on the warship Paramore. These variations, now called 'declination', show the angle between magnetic north and true geographical north. Without this information, sailors could not correct their compasses, making it hard to navigate the oceans.
Halley was one of only two men in England at that time who were paid to do scientific research. He set sail for the Cape Verde Islands to chart declination in the North and South Atlantic, but the trip was stopped because of problems with the crew. Halley then made a second voyage that took him to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. From this journey, Halley published a chart in 1701 showing the variations of the compass in the Western and Southern Oceans. More advanced charts were used by sailors for over a century until changes in the Earth's magnetic field made them less accurate.
Dr. Clark wants to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's trip by retracing the route of the Paramore. He needs to raise £70,000 before starting, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, who led the first expedition across Antarctica, is helping him.
Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while working at Halley Station in Antarctica, where he read about Halley's life. "Halley had an amazing life," Dr. Clark says. "He was a respected scientist and led expeditions. He was not just an astronomer; he also studied geophysics. While he was Astronomer Royal, he mapped the stars and worked on other projects."
During this time, Halley created a diving bell and helped Sir Isaac Newton with his famous book, Principia Mathematica, which is important in physics. Dr. Clark believes that retracing Halley's voyage will give him the recognition he deserves. His planned expedition, called 'In the Wake of the Paramore', will also have scientific value. It will involve taking measurements that Halley made, but with better tools. These measurements are important because the Earth's magnetic field is always changing.
Dr. Clark explains, "We usually measure the size of the magnetic field, but not its direction. To measure the direction, we need to know true north. On our expedition, we can use satellites to find that." The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments for the trip. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements around the world. Dr. Clark hopes his measurements will fill in any gaps in the satellite's coverage of the Atlantic Ocean, and having ground measurements will be helpful for comparison.
Halley's journey was significant because it was the first scientific expedition at sea, and he was the first civilian to be appointed as a naval captain for this purpose. Does Dr. Clark have the right experience to make his journey successful? He has spent two years in Antarctica and worked in the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey. He has also sailed the 13,000 kilometers from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with four different crews.
Does he share Halley's passion? "I am ready to give up my life for eight months to do this, so some might say I'm obsessed. But I wouldn't want to sail across the Atlantic again without a good reason. Halley and his interesting life have given me a real sense of purpose."

'POWER DRESSING'**
Every summer, the peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tail feathers to the hens. This behavior has puzzled scientists for a long time. Charles Darwin, a famous scientist, wondered how birds could have such extravagant features in a world where survival is tough. He believed that animals evolve through natural selection, meaning that the strongest and best-adapted individuals survive and reproduce. However, he thought that peacocks' tails were not useful for survival and suggested another idea called 'sexual selection.' This means that females choose males based on their beauty.
Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, had a different view. He believed that if peahens liked the males with the most beautiful tails, there must be a good reason for it. He thought that the tail was not just for show but indicated something important about the male's ability to survive.
Now, 100 years later, scientists are still trying to find answers. At Whipsnade, there are 200 peacocks that live like wild birds but are used to people, making them easier to study. Marion Petrie and her team have two main questions: Do peahens really prefer the males with the most impressive tails? And do these males have other qualities that help them survive, or is it just about looks?
The researchers have observed the peacocks and found that hens seem to prefer males with more eye spots on their tails. These males attract more mates. However, it is still unclear if these attractive males are better in other ways. William Hamilton from Oxford University suggested that showy male birds might be healthier and have fewer parasites, and their beautiful feathers show this. But the researchers have not yet been able to check the health of the peacocks at Whipsnade.
This year, Dr. Petrie is studying the offspring of attractive and unattractive males to see if the children of the attractive males grow faster and are healthier. If they are, it would support Wallace's idea that females choose mates for practical reasons.
There is also an interesting theory from mathematician R A Fisher. He suggested that if a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail, their sons will inherit the long tail, and their daughters will prefer long tails. This could lead to a situation where males with the longest tails have the most mates, and the preference for long tails continues to grow. This idea could explain how peacocks developed their impressive tails and also support Darwin's idea that females might choose beauty for its own sake.

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**
Tom Cunliffe believes that the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He showed this with his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of beautiful yachts with new technology. Most of these boats come from a big change in boat design that happened 25 years ago. In contrast, my boat is quietly resting in a tidal creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but if you see it, you might think it is 100 years old and that its owner is a romantic person. Maybe I am, but I’m not sure.
This boat uses the best parts of old boat design, but modern technology has made it easier to build. However, even though technology is important in boat design and building, it often keeps sailors away from the real challenges of life at sea. These challenges are often what they wanted to experience by going to sea. I am not saying that sailors should go back to suffering through every difficulty. I believe it is important for my boats to have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable places to sleep. But why go sailing if every sail works by itself? Dealing with sails that flap in the wind is part of being a sailor.
Why should we change our steering positions from a safe place at the back of the boat to a less safe spot in the middle? The sad truth is that this makes the cabin feel like a big ship, with a bed larger than the one at home. For me, a boat should be a boat, not a house on the water. When I bought my earlier boat, Hirta, to sail around Britain for a TV race, the previous owner said it had all the comforts but no luxury. During my time with Hirta, I learned how true this was. She had heavy sails, no running water, little electricity, no fridge, no central heating, no winches, and no electronics, especially for navigation. Yet, she was the easiest boat I have ever sailed.
However, classic boats like Hirta need a lot of care. When I hurt my back badly, I realized I could not keep sailing her. I looked for a younger boat but found nothing good, so I decided to build a new boat from scratch. The Westerman has never let me down. Although the designer, Nigel Irens, and his assistant, Ed Burnett, are skilled with computer design, Irens first drew this boat on a paper napkin and later used a computer. After creating a model, just like boat builders did in the past, we worked together to improve the design. The final version was perfect.
The completed boat has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of her first six races.
