She looks timeless, moves beautifully in the sea, and her interior, made from reclaimed pitch pine, feels peaceful. This might be because she was designed only as a sailing boat, without thinking about any furniture. This is the best way to design a boat. In her calmness, she shows that you don’t need to follow trends to be happy, and that sometimes it is wise to learn from history. Made from wood treated with a special glue, she does not let water in. So, she has all the advantages of a fiberglass boat but looks, feels, and sails like a real boat.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**
Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are becoming very popular. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.
**A. HENLOW GRANGE**  
I was happy to go to Henlow Grange for six days because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the big 18th-century house was very comfortable, and I felt calm right away. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I started attending body conditioning classes like yoga and stretching. The instructors are very well trained. I was surprised at how flexible I felt as the week went on. They offer many treatments, including aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The facial treatment lasts an hour and makes you feel refreshed. The staff in the treatment rooms were very friendly and professional. The atmosphere was full of energy and enthusiasm. Henlow is planning to renovate this year, adding a half-size Olympic swimming pool and a Light Diet Room. You can also ride bicycles around the grounds. If you want to relax, you can read a magazine or take a peaceful walk in the garden. During my stay, I felt happier and had a better appetite. I left feeling great and full of energy, which lasted a long time. I will definitely visit again. This is a perfect getaway for busy women. Save Room 5 for me!  
*Marcella D'Argy Smith*
**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**  
The calm and relaxing atmosphere of this stately home was clear as soon as I walked up the big staircase into the reception area. The Hall has a beautifully decorated library, a lovely conservatory, and plenty of space, so you can be alone if you want. When you arrive, everyone gets a medical check-up, which includes an examination and checking weight and blood pressure. We were all called patients, which felt strange since I am healthy. However, I was impressed that a shoulder problem found during the check-up was quickly shared with the fitness instructor, and we worked on it in group workshops and individual sessions. Each patient follows a specific diet. I lost weight without starving, but I was still hungry enough to get a bad headache on the second day. My daily menu included grapefruit and honey for breakfast, salads for lunch, and a mix of fruit, yogurt, and hot broth for dinner. If you are not on a light diet, you can eat in the main dining hall, where the food is tasty and well-presented. You have a massage or water therapy every other day. All extra treatments are reasonably priced.  
*Liz Gregory*
**C. CAREYS MANOR**  
Careys is not a health farm and does not pretend to be one. It is a lovely old manor with cozy log fires and a spacious lounge. If you are counting calories, you might want to skip the gourmet food. The French chef makes rich sauces and delicious desserts. Luckily, the hotel has a gym and a soft-water pool, so I could exercise after enjoying the food. (You can choose a 'health-conscious' diet if you want to lose weight.) There is a spa bath, steam room, sauna, and treatment rooms. A big attraction is the sports injury clinic. I got advice on an old shoulder injury. The physiotherapist suggested good posture, exercises, and massage. Careys is comfortable and luxurious, relaxed and calm. If you want to explore, there is beautiful countryside around.  
*Beverly D'Silva*
**D. CLIVEDEN**  
Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel that treats guests like royalty. It offers health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, a swimming pool, tennis, horse riding, and more. There are beautiful woodland walks and gardens on the 376-acre estate. Waldo's is a famous restaurant with amazing dishes. It took me a long time to read the dinner menu because there were so many choices. The meal was fantastic, especially the sticky-toffee pudding with banana ice cream. I went to bed very happy! The next morning, I spent a few hours in the gym to burn off some calories before my next meal. In the Pavilion, I enjoyed a facial with gentle heat and essential oils, followed by an aromatherapy massage. I thought about all the other reports my fellow journalists would write about fitness and beauty treatments. Cliveden has everything if you want to use them before enjoying a meal at Waldo's.  
*Kay Letch*
**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**  
The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It is the best because it is the most delicious I have ever tasted. It is the worst because it has 360 calories, which is a lot if you want to lose weight. You have been warned! The second best thing is the wonderful aromatherapy massage. I chose a relaxing oil blend and fell asleep twice during the massage. I had my best night’s sleep in years. The place is modern and well-organized, with great facilities and luxurious bedrooms. There are many therapists and beauty rooms, so it is easy to book appointments. They offer a variety of treatments, from manicures and pedicures to deep-cleansing facials and body treatments. The guests are a mix of people, from football teams to mothers and daughters, friends, and singles. Ideally, I would take a break here about once a month.  
*Eve Cameron*

**NATURAL TALENTS**
In the seven million years since humans separated from chimpanzees, we have not changed much. Genetically, we are still more than 98% similar to chimps. This means that the differences between humans and animals are very recent. Our ability to create art and other things we think are unique to humans comes from just a small part of our genes. This is a big responsibility for a few genes.
Recent studies of animal behavior show that many traits once thought to be unique to humans are now seen as differences in degree. For example, both humans and wild chimpanzees use tools. Chimpanzees use sticks to eat and as weapons, while sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys also have a simple form of language, with different sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. This means that besides art, there are not many clear differences between humans and animals.
If human art comes from a special genetic ability, it is strange that our ancestors did not create art for almost 7 million years after separating from chimps. The earliest forms of art may have been wood carvings or body painting, but we cannot know for sure because these materials do not last. The first clear evidence of human art appears around 35,000 years ago with cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments.
If we believe that our recent burst of creativity makes us different, we need to think about how our art is different from animal art. Three main differences are often mentioned: human art is not useful, it is made for enjoyment, and it is learned rather than instinctive.
First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." This means that human art does not help us survive or pass on our genes, unlike many animal behaviors. Some human art does communicate ideas to other people, but this is not the same as passing on genes. In contrast, birdsong helps defend territory or attract a mate, which does help them pass on their genes. So, by this idea, human art does seem different.
The second claim is that only human art is made for enjoyment. We cannot ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mostly sing during the breeding season, so they may not be singing just for fun. Again, this suggests that human art is unique.
The third claim is that human art is learned, not instinctive. Each human group has its own art styles that are learned. For example, songs in Tokyo are different from those in Paris. People can learn each other's songs. In contrast, some birds are born knowing how to sing their species' songs, even if they have never heard them before.
Human art changes quickly. For example, Roman writers described geese honking 2,000 years ago, and they still do today. But human art styles change so fast that even a casual museum visitor can tell a twentieth-century painting from an older one, like the Mona Lisa. Art experts can often tell when a painting was made and who made it, but they might confuse two chimpanzee artists named Congo and Betsy. Congo made up to 33 paintings in one day and got upset when his pencil was taken away. In 1957, there was an art show in London for their paintings, and many of them sold, which is something many human artists cannot achieve.
These paintings by chimpanzees blur the lines between human art and animal behavior. Like human art, the chimpanzee paintings were not made for practical reasons; they were created for the satisfaction of the painter. You might argue that human art is different because most human artists want to communicate something. However, the chimpanzees did not care about sharing their art with others, as they often discarded their paintings. This point may not be as strong, since some famous human art was also created for personal satisfaction.

An Amazing Adventure**
The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on Earth. It is also one of the most dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell his story. There are very few big adventures left and very few heroes. Children's stories used to have brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes focused on faraway places. Today, you do not find such people in stories or in real life. Or so I thought until I met Charles Blackmore.
Blackmore's big adventure was leading a group across the Taklamakan Desert. Its name means "once entered, you never come out," but local people call it the Desert of Death. He remembered the dangers and excitement of that amazing journey while at home with his family. The team he led included four Britons (one was the medical officer), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were long-distance truck drivers. This misunderstanding could have been very dangerous and could have ruined the expedition.
This mixed group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of the world's toughest desert, and Charles Blackmore wrote a fascinating account of their journey. At that time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to fill a gap in his life, and to learn more about himself. "I always thought I would spend my whole life in the Army. I was offered a promotion, but suddenly I wanted to see who I really was outside of that. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was very worried that I wouldn't come back because nobody had ever done that route before; we went into it without knowing what would happen. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was very good to us."
Anyone reading his amazing story will wonder why he used the word "good." The team faced many hardships: sickness, extreme temperatures, severe thirst, and losing part of their water supply. "But," Blackmore explains, "when we were at our limits and the camels had gone without water for seven days, we found some. We did not experience the desert's famous sandstorms. And we never faced the freezing cold that could have stopped us. That does not mean we did not have challenges. The fine sand got into everything, especially our blisters and wounds. The high dunes were hard to climb for us and for the heavy camels, which often rolled over onto us."
"What pushed me on more than anything else was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Our budget and time did not allow for one. No aircraft ever flew over us. Once we got into the sandhills, we were completely on our own. I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was very scared about my physical ability. I remember the first day -- we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot that it was hard to breathe. I thought, 'We have to do it now!' At that moment, I was very scared."
If it was like that at the beginning, how did they feel at the end? "When you've walked for 1,000 kilometers, you are not going to give up. You've gone through so much; you have so much behind you. We were very thin but also very strong despite our exhaustion. My body was fit, and my legs were like machines. I could walk over anything."
In the middle of the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert, looking up at a full moon, and thinking of his family. How aware was he of how hard it must have been for them? "Inside me, there is someone trying to find peace. When I have doubts about myself now, I think back to the image of the desert and remember that we managed to do that together. I feel prouder of that expedition than of anything else I've done. Yet, when I think of my life, I think of my family and the happiness we share. Compared to that, the desert does not measure up."
Has Charles Blackmore found peace? "I long for the challenge and the open spaces. We were lifted by our sense of purpose. Now, I find it hard to be part of the sameness of modern life."

Life was getting too busy for Susan Harr, so she decided to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it gives us useful devices that make life easier and give us more free time. However, Susan feels that we have become too dependent on technology. 
After a bad experience with her broken word processor, which cost her a lot of money to fix, she started to think that gadgets are often not worth it. She began to let go of some household technology as it broke down. This made her question what "free time" really means. Does it just mean we have more time to buy and use more gadgets? 
When her broken machine started making strange noises, she left it outside, where it now sits quietly. She enjoys sewing by hand instead of using a noisy machine. She likes that she can take her sewing with her wherever she goes. 
There are some gadgets she still finds useful, like her washing machine, but she has also found joy in living without others. For example, she returned her rented color TV and went back to a small black-and-white one. This change helped her family spend more time walking their dog, reading, talking, and enjoying other hobbies. 
Susan used to think she needed her sewing machine, but now it is just a table for plants. She has started sewing by hand and finds it relaxing. She can listen to the radio or talk to family while she sews. If the task is simple, she can even watch TV at the same time, which makes her feel less guilty about watching. 
Sewing by hand is not boring; it is satisfying and calming. She enjoys seeing her work become neater and feels that things get done quickly. Life feels slower and more enjoyable when she works with her hands. 
Susan has also started to enjoy washing dishes by hand, which allows her to daydream. Now, she looks around her house and wonders if she really needs things like a freezer, microwave, or electric lawnmower. She thinks they could save a lot of money by living without some of these gadgets. 
**Questions:**
1. Why did Susan Harr decide to unplug her gadgets?
2. What bad experience did Susan have with her word processor?
3. How did returning to a black-and-white TV change Susan's family's activities?
4. What does Susan enjoy about sewing by hand?
5. What does Susan think about the need for gadgets in her home?

Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker who makes beautiful furniture. Joanna Watt meets him. When I arrive at his workshop in East London, he greets me quickly with a handshake and says, "Well, fire away then!" He seems busy, and his workshop is full of unfinished furniture and pieces of wood in many colors. Hurst has been making furniture for ten years and has a good reputation. He always has many orders, even though he does not advertise himself. People know that if they want a good cupboard, table, or bookcase, Hurst is the right person to contact.
Finding a furniture-maker is not hard, but finding one who makes high-quality furniture is more difficult. Hurst says, "There are few real cabinet-makers now. Many people call themselves furniture-makers." He is often disappointed by the quality of modern furniture. He does not like cheap, mass-produced items and craftsmen who make low-quality pieces. Hurst's desire for perfection is a big part of his success, along with his talent. He is confident in his skills and says, "I have a huge natural ability. I have always been good at making things." 
Hurst learned his craft by asking questions and practicing. Most of his work comes from private clients. Some clients come back to him many times, which he finds very satisfying. However, he admits that not all client relationships are easy. He finds it frustrating when clients do not know what they want. He prefers clients who are clear about their needs.
Although Hurst is proud of his work, he also respects other craftsmen. He says, "There are people far better than me." He criticizes those who take too long to make one piece of furniture and does not like degree shows where students try to make their work look fashionable. He believes furniture should be practical and useful.
Hurst is confident but not pretentious. As I leave, he reminds me, "After all, I am only making furniture."

Three Theories About Sleep**
People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This shows that sleep is very important. However, scientists do not fully agree on why we need to sleep. There are three main theories.
The first theory says that sleep is important for our bodies. It claims that we sleep to keep our bodies healthy. While we sleep, our bodies work to fix any damage from the day and to help us feel better.
The second theory focuses on learning. It suggests that sleep helps us process the information we learn during the day. This means that without sleep, we might not be able to learn well.
The third theory is about energy. It says that we need to sleep to recharge our energy, so we are ready for the next day.

**ECCENTRICS**
An eccentric is someone whose behavior is unusual. They do not follow the accepted rules of their society. This raises the question, "What is normal?" Most of us have our own quirks and strange habits. It could be a love for entering newspaper contests, collecting beer mats, or writing letters to the editor about many topics. Eccentricity shows our individuality.
Inside us, there is often a struggle between two forces. One is called individualism, which is the desire to be unique, and the other is conformity, which is the desire to fit in. For many people, the need to be accepted and liked is stronger than the need to stand out and be different.
People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often come together. They form clubs, hold meetings, and organize events to share their interests or problems. The key word here is 'common.' They look for others who understand what their friends and family might see as strange.
Most of us feel a tension between wanting to fit in and wanting to be ourselves. Even when we follow the crowd, we may not like being told that we are doing so. We want to show our individuality, like when a man at a bar says, "I say what I think," or when a new person insists, "You must take me as I am."
Anyone can choose to be more individualistic at any time. Many people succeed in their careers by doing this. For example, Bob Dylan, the American singer, said, "When you feel strongly about what you are doing, pursue it without giving up. You will surprise many people." However, showing individuality is not the same as being eccentric, especially at first. 
When a pop singer wears strange clothes to get attention, or a socialite makes shocking comments to be noticed, that is not eccentricity. But if they continue these behaviors until they become part of who they are, then they might be considered eccentric. The most important part of eccentricity is that it is natural. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they simply are.
True eccentrics do not care much about what others think. They act based on who they are. This makes them different from enthusiasts, pranksters, clever criminals, show-offs, and recluses. These people are aware of the world around them. They often act to impress others or to escape from society. In contrast, eccentrics go about their lives without worrying about what others think.

**Natural Books**
We asked four well-known naturalists to share the wildlife book that has influenced them the most.
**A. Geoffrey Lean**  
It was easy for me to choose the author. As an environmental journalist, I have met some important people in this field. One of them is Barbara Ward, a small and gentle woman. She is very important in environmental issues in Europe after the war. She combined her experiences from different environmental movements into her own strong ideas. When I was a young journalist, she helped me understand these issues better. Choosing the book was harder. It could have been *Only One Earth* or *Progress for a Small Planet*. But I believe Barbara's most important book is *The Home of Man*. It talks about the rapid growth of cities and the big themes she cared about. It is a powerful call for what we now call "sustainable human development." I have read many books since, but none are as good as this one.
**B. Linda Bennett**  
When I read *Signals for Survival* by Niko Tinbergen, I can hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of the guano in the sun. This book wonderfully explains the interesting world of animal communication with words and pictures. After reading it, if you watch a gull colony, you will see how their chaotic activity is actually a well-organized social structure. You can identify which birds are partners and recognize families later in the season. Niko Tinbergen was a great behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. His work with talented wildlife artist Eric Ennion made this book special and interesting for anyone who loves wildlife. Ennion's paintings show how one gull can be aggressive while another is calm, showing the skill of a true naturalist.
**C. Lee Durrell**  
The book that has influenced me the most is *My Family and Other Animals* by Gerald Durrell. This book not only led me to a wonderful husband and a career in conservation, but it also deepened my love for the natural world. I was studying animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read it. After two years of challenges, this book made me feel hopeful again. It beautifully connects animals, people, joy, and nature, showing a world worth saving. Some people think humans are the worst because of the harm we have done to other species. But I remember Gerald as a boy in the book, seeing all living things as a family that is connected, no matter if they are good or bad. This is an important idea for everyone to understand.
**D. Bruce Pearson**  
I found *The Shell Bird Book* by James Fisher in my school library soon after it was published in 1966. I was immediately attracted to it, especially the 48 colorful bird paintings by Eric Ennion. These images caught my attention. I already had other bird books and had spent holidays learning to identify birds. They inspired me to start sketching what I saw. But *The Shell Bird Book* offered much more. It had beautiful paintings, chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and even a chapter on birds in music, literature, and art. This wide range of information and exciting images encouraged me to appreciate birds and nature in a broader way. The book showed me that my emotional and creative responses to nature are just as important as scientific ones. Since art was my stronger subject, I began to see new opportunities for myself.

DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS?**
We asked five British publishers about how book reviews affect sales. Here is what they said.
**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. They are the first thing we look at in newspapers. A study showed that many people said they bought a book because of reviews, more than because of ads or recommendations from friends. Authors feel differently about reviews. Both authors and publishers are upset when there are no reviews, but publishers are usually okay with bad reviews. They think that any review can help sales because readers want to see for themselves. Publishers like reviews that match their own opinions about a book since they are often the first to read it.
**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers both care about book reviews, but they have different needs. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed, especially in a good way. Book reviews today are better and more varied than they were 40 years ago. However, many paperback books still do not get enough attention. Publishers should not complain too much because they need reviews to help readers discover books and authors. A good review from a trusted source can really boost sales, especially if there are several good reviews.
**Publisher C**  
Reviews are very important for publishing. Without them, we would struggle to promote our books. Most of our books are not by famous authors, and we do not advertise much, so we rely on reviews from literary editors. Good reviews are often more valuable than ads because readers trust them. Publishers say they care more about the size of the review than its content. Good reviews can help a book and an author succeed, but they need support from other sources like recommendations from readers and good marketing.
**Publisher D**  
I wish I understood the relationship between publishing and reviewing in Britain! In the United States, a single review can make or break a book. Here, bookshops often do not pay much attention to reviews. Sometimes it takes many years of good reviews for people to notice a good writer. However, some poorly reviewed books still sell very well. It is unpredictable, but non-fiction books allow reviewers to share their knowledge about the topic instead of just focusing on the book.
**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers hope for great reviews. But do they really help sell books? I once published a biography that received excellent reviews, but it did not sell well because people thought they could just read the reviews instead of buying the book. Does the name of the reviewer matter? Thirty years ago, if certain reviewers liked a book, people paid attention. Now, sometimes it is the unexpected reviewer or the creativity of the review that encourages people to buy the book.

**WEATHERVANE MAKER**
Making weathervanes is an old skill that goes back to ancient Egypt. Today, this craft is still alive in the workshop of Graham Smith. He is one of the few people in the country who makes hand-cut weathervanes. Graham creates unique designs based on what his customers want. "This way, I can make a special item just for them," he says. Many of his customers are women who want to buy gifts for their husbands. They look for a special gift that shows the man's job or hobbies.
Graham's work is very different from the traditional cockerel design, which is the most common type of weathervane. The first weathervane he made was not a cockerel, but a witch on a broomstick. His friends liked the surprise gift he made for his wife and asked him to make weathervanes for them too. "I realized that there are endless possibilities for designs," he says. Graham decided to focus on making weathervanes. He had trained as a precision engineer and worked in that field for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, decided to change their roles. She went to work as an architectural assistant, and he stayed home to take care of the children and grow his business. This was five years ago, and he is happy with his new path. "My old job was not creative, but this work is exciting and artistic," he says. "I really enjoy designing."
Graham has now created over 100 original designs. He pays close attention to detail and always gets the customer's approval for the design before he starts cutting it by hand. He also keeps many traditional designs available because they are still popular. "People like handmade items," Graham says. "They want something a little different."
Graham does not plan to expand his business because he wants to keep it as a rural craft. "I have found my place in the market. People love unique items, and I feel satisfied when I see a simple shape turn into something almost lifelike," he says. "For centuries, weathervanes have helped people understand the weather by showing changes in wind direction." He adds, "Now, with more people moving to the countryside, they want to add a special touch to their homes. This has helped crafts like mine."
Graham is now busier than ever, sending flat-packed weathervanes to customers around the world. Buyers from America and Denmark are especially interested. "The price depends on how detailed the design is," he explains. His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. No matter the occasion, Graham can create a special gift.

'Beginner Takes All'**
Before it was published, *The Horse Whisperer* was the most talked-about book of the year. It is the first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans, and it has made him a lot of money. Here, he shares his inspiration and success.
At the start of the year, Nicholas Evans was having a tough time. A film project he had been working on, called *Life and Limb*, fell apart suddenly. He was worried because it had been two years since he had earned any money, and he was in debt to his bank. A smart person in his situation would have found a job, maybe returning to television. But instead, he made a surprising choice. He bought a ticket to America and went there for three months to research his first novel.
Even though he was acting on impulse, he had an idea for the story for a while. He had met a farrier (a person who shoes horses) while visiting a friend in Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a gentle horse that suddenly became aggressive. The owners were desperate until they heard about a gypsy who could calm the horse just by talking to it. These special people were called "horse whisperers." This story inspired Evans.
He started to research horse whisperers to write a screenplay, as he was a filmmaker. But after the failure of *Life and Limb*, he decided to write the story as a book. During the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. He later said, "It was a strange time. I was watching people, but I felt alone and worried about my life. I had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, and now I was in debt and unsure how to support my family."
By the end of August, he had returned home and written the first half of the book. He was still worried about money and needed to know if he should continue. He showed the book to a friend who was a literary agent. The agent read it and said it was "fine." When asked, he thought Evans might get $30,000 as an advance for the book. Evans needed more money to pay off his debts. He had spent seven months on *The Horse Whisperer* and still had at least two months of work left.
In October, he sent the first two hundred pages of the novel and a 12-page summary to seven UK publishers just before the Frankfurt Book Fair. Soon, his agent called to say he had turned down the first offer of $75,000. Evans was shocked and asked, "What?" The agent replied, "It's okay, I feel something good is happening."
What happened next was amazing. Within a week, the novel was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for £550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record amounts for a first novel. Evans said, "We couldn't believe it; we were in shock. We never sent the manuscript to New York, and we still don’t know how it got there." They also did not send it to Hollywood, but soon major film studios were interested in it. 
Evans's UK agent worked with an agent in the US, and when they said they could get $3 million for the film rights, they laughed in disbelief. They all agreed to this amount, and that night, four famous filmmakers called Evans to ask for the chance to pay $3 million for his unfinished novel.
Evans shared this story while we drank coffee on his porch overlooking his garden. He mentioned that he had turned down an offer to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. He said, "It has been like a fairy tale. I don’t want to ruin it. Writing at that level is very hard, and I don’t want to become just an employee of these people who have paid me so much money. I would hate to write a draft and then have them say, 'Thanks, Nick, but we will hire someone else now.'"
He wanted to stay involved but from a distance. The success of his novel led to new support for *Life and Limb*, but he was not sure if he wanted to make it anymore. He said, "I think it would be foolish not to write another novel."

'Young Masters'**
Bobby Fischer is trying to return to chess, but age is against him. Chess is now more of a young man's game. After being away from chess for 20 years, Fischer is back and playing against his old rival, Boris Spassky. Fischer won the first game, which was impressive, but he is not the same player he was in 1972. He is now 49 years old, out of practice, and not in good shape. Spassky is even older.
Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Fischer helped make chess popular, and now there is a professional chess circuit. Winning is the main goal for modern players. In international chess, a player’s nerves and stamina are just as important as their intelligence. The pressure in chess has always been high. Players use a chess clock to make sure they finish their moves in time. If they don’t, they lose the game. Now, games can last longer, and many are played without breaks. This has made it harder for older players.
In the last 30 years, every new world champion has been younger than the last. Of the ten best players in the world, eight are under 30. The way chess is played has also changed. Many players prepare off the board, using computers to study their opponents. A small computer can store one million chess games and help players find weaknesses in their rivals. In recent matches, players have had teams of helpers working to find mistakes in each other’s games. The beginning of a chess game is now studied very carefully, and being well-prepared can decide the game.
Today, there are more great players than ever before. Many grandmasters compete for small prizes around the world. Success in chess requires both physical and mental effort. A single game can last up to eight hours, and players must stay focused. A moment of distraction can lead to losing. The chess clock adds to the stress, and the end of the game can be very intense. Players often have only seconds to make their moves, and they must act quickly. This creates a situation where nerves and determination are crucial to winning.
At the highest level of chess, losing is very painful. Winning brings great joy and a chance to recover from the stress. However, one win is not enough to win a tournament. Chess tournaments usually last 9-11 days, with games every day. World championship matches can be even tougher. For example, a match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in 1984 had to stop after several months because both players were exhausted. Karpov lost a lot of weight during that time.
Can Bobby Fischer overcome these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do is play chess." This makes his long absence from the game surprising. But it also made him a legend. If he has returned for the money, he is in a good position, as both he and Spassky will earn millions from their match. However, if Fischer believes he can prove he is still the best player, the outcome could be very disappointing for him.

Fame and Fortune**
Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are becoming famous.
A. Nick Grosso is in his early 30s and has written three well-received plays. He is now turning his first play, Peaches, into a movie script. "It's low budget, but we don't know how low," he says. "It won't be over £30 million, but it could be as low as £30." Nick is very talented, but the surprising thing is that before writing Peaches, he had never been to a play or read one. "When I wrote the play, I never thought it would be performed," he says. "It's set in a car. I probably wouldn't do that now because I know it would be hard to manage. I knew nothing back then." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After finishing A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I realized I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my writing to be heard, not just read, because of the rhythm and rhyme," he explains. "Suddenly, I was with people who thought like me. It was the first time I enjoyed being in school. It was very inspiring."
B. Comedian Simon Pegg, 28, has come a long way since studying drama at Bristol University. He is now writing a TV comedy series and has just finished a tough tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. He has always worked hard. Even in Bristol, he was practicing his comedy in clubs. "University was very theoretical," Simon remembers. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a serious actor; I was always more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it really isn't. If you have courage and good material, it's great to make people laugh." He has performed with the comedy group Funny Business, but his work with Steve Coogan has been the most successful. "He saw my show, and since I was a big fan of his, he probably noticed I was copying him," Simon admits.
C. Ciaran McMenamin, 24, became known when he danced on TV as the lead in the series The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star. The response was very positive, and his career has taken off quickly. "It's been a great opportunity for me," he says with a smile. "Now I can choose what I want to do, which is what I've always wanted." This is a comfortable position for him, especially since he just graduated. Looking back at his early career, it's clear he was always meant to succeed. Encouraged by his mother, he went from leading roles in school to the Ulster Youth Theatre, where he stayed for four years. "I was using acting to avoid homework," Ciaran laughs. "But then I decided I wanted to take it seriously because I had a talent and passion for it." Now he is waiting for the praise to come, but when asked about fame, he becomes thoughtful. "When you're 18, you think you'll love the photos and interviews, but you soon realize that's not why you act. It's about getting respect for doing good work."
D. Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which has just signed a deal for three albums with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to be very successful when their single, Chimera, is released soon. "The record company has a different idea of good sales than I do," he says. "They want a big hit, but for me, if two people buy it, I'll be happy." Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to enter the music business ever since. "It's funny how things happen," he says. "I had been performing at student gigs for eight years and was starting to feel tired. I was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had connections at Domino, and we formed Matrix. It couldn't have come at a better time. There were times I felt very down, and I was in some terrible bands. But hopefully, it will all be worth it."
E. Poet and author Stephen Richards is 27 years old and has won many awards and honors. He is well known in the poetry world, where he has been touring and giving readings several times a week for the past six years. His first novel, Hidden, will be published in March. "It's a story about obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I couldn't write as a poem." Stephen loved creative writing in school but lost interest in education later. "I decided not to go to university, but I became bored stuffing envelopes at a theater and realized I should go." After university, he published his first work, a children's book, in 1992. "I don't think my parents expected me to be a writer; they thought I would just be a reader because that's all I did as a child." With his poetry getting great reviews, moving to novels is a brave step. "My poetry has a structure, and there is less chance of making big mistakes," he explains. "A novel can be any length, so there are more words that could be bad. My main goal is not to just write a lot without caring about the quality."

A. Isabel is a 31-year-old art student who thinks she looks good in jeans, but she rarely wears them. She is worried that her knees might ruin her chances of finding the right man. Despite this, she remains hopeful, which helps her and others in the story. The author writes in a lively style, using chapter titles like "Our Hero Feels Inspired," similar to an early silent film.
B. This story is about a local radio station in America that almost fails. It is told from the perspective of a smart, shy child named Francis With. Francis works for WLT (With Lettuce and Tomato) Radio, which was started by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station plays a mix of singers, preachers, and announcers. The author uses humor and simple writing to take readers back to the 1940s and 1950s, a time of old stores and classic cars.
C. In this story, it is normal for a second husband to talk to his wife's first husband. When professor Richard Vaisey falls in love with a Russian poetess, he shares his feelings with her ex-husband. The poetess writes bad poetry and wants Richard's help for her brother, who is in prison. The author skillfully tells the story with humor and insight into relationships, making it an enjoyable and clever read.
D. In 1960s London, two sets of best friends—two women and two men—are connected for 25 years. At the beginning of the novel, James Hudson, a wealthy American, is starting a newspaper with his friend Richard Blake as the editor. The launch is important, but so is the fact that a woman they both loved, and one of them married, was killed years ago. The story includes murder, ambition, love, and jealousy, and the writing is strong. This book allows readers to really get to know the characters.
E. This story, written by a great American author, is about Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty about something he did. To make up for it, he becomes a father figure to his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, he is slowly becoming an unusual bachelor. The story explores many emotions and shows the special bond Ian forms with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm and lovely book that balances sadness and humor.

**Volunteer Tourism**
Four writers discuss international volunteer work. 
A. It is difficult to say that volunteer work really helps development a lot. While volunteer tourists can help build homes or schools, they usually pay a large fee to do this work. This money could be given directly to a local community, which could pay for more labor than one volunteer can provide. This is especially true for gap year volunteers, who often do not have much technical skill or professional experience. Many studies question whether gap year volunteering is mainly about helping others or if young people want to gain experience that will help their careers. However, these projects can help develop people who will act ethically and help those in need in the future.
B. Volunteering can lead to better international understanding, improved conflict resolution skills, and more participation in global issues through civic organizations. It can also help create international social networks among regular people. In this way, the benefits can be greater for both volunteers and the communities they help. However, if volunteering is mostly done by wealthy people, it may help them gain a global perspective and improve their careers, but it will not help those who do not have access to these opportunities.
C. At its worst, international volunteering can be seen as a form of charity that benefits wealthy Westerners more than the communities they aim to help. At its best, it can provide benefits to both volunteers and the organizations they work with, while allowing for the sharing of skills and experiences in developing communities. Most importantly, volunteering can raise awareness about the unequal power relations and deep-rooted causes of poverty and injustice.
D. Volunteer tourism fits well with the idea of helping others. These small efforts to "make a difference" can seem positive, especially when people are frustrated with big governments and businesses. However, this approach can ignore the need for democratic government and reduce development to individual acts of charity, which may not truly change the situations of poor communities. While volunteering can be a good act, when it is promoted as sustainable development, it can show a misunderstanding of the real issues of global inequality and poverty faced by many in developing countries.

Sound the Alarm**
Stuart Harris reports
Many of us listen to the radio in the morning, and we often need something to help us get out of bed. This is why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one? A group of us, including myself, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five clock radios that are available now.
One model has a 'dual alarm function'. This means you can set two different wake-up times, one for work days and one for weekends. However, it does not let you snooze and then wake up later, as I first thought. Since this model costs about the same as another one we tested, having a cassette player is a good deal. You can listen to your favorite tapes to fall asleep and wake up to a quiet morning. We all agreed that the radio quality was excellent, but the size was a problem. It is as big as a rugby ball. Paul Bridges said, "Any clock radio I buy must leave enough space on my bedside table for my keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. I always book a wake-up call just in case the alarm doesn’t work."
This model was voted the best-looking and overall winner. Paul Bridges said he was "in love with it," even though the clock he tested kept getting stuck at 16:00. I liked the digital display with its nice grey numbers on a soft green background. The snooze button is wide, so you can tap it easily with your eyes closed. However, the buttons felt nice to touch, which made me play with them too much. The clock has a backup battery, so you don’t have to reset it if the power goes out. We all liked this feature. But we found it hard to set up, even though learning to use it made us feel cool.
Tom Granger thought this model, which has a built-in lamp, was "very cheap" in quality. He had to read the instructions twice to get it to work because the clock kept changing from 12:00 to 02:00. The lamp was hard to adjust, and you couldn’t read by it because it only shines on the clock, which is already lit. Paul Bridges found the lamp funny but agreed that the radio was difficult to tune. The buzzer sounded like an alarm on a submarine, which made me want to throw it across the room. Interestingly, this model is the third most popular on the market. It is aimed at young people, with its bright colors and fun design. Tom Granger said, "I would choose this one because it stands out more than the others." 
The traditional controls made it the only model we could set up without reading the instructions. Unfortunately, the alarm can be off by 20 minutes; the manual says, "the alarm may sound about 10 minutes earlier or later than the set time." Paul Bridges laughed at this idea and said this model was "very annoying" and "completely useless."
The simplest and cheapest model we tested was liked by Tom Granger because it was "very standard and took up little space." It has old-fashioned dial tuning, which he found easier to use. "With modern push-button tuning, you’re never sure if you pressed the buttons in the right order," he said. However, he agreed that manufacturers had to improve radio quality because of button-tuning. I thought the tuning was not very good, as did Paul Bridges, but we agreed that the radio quality was fine. The buzzer on this model worked well; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

Hedgehogs**
A hedgehog is a small animal with sharp spines on its body. Hedgehogs live in many parts of the world, but they are not found in America or Australia. All hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they are in danger, so their spines point outwards. This helps protect them, but how well it works depends on how many spines they have. Some hedgehogs that live in the desert have fewer spines because they need to be lighter. These hedgehogs are more likely to run away from danger instead of rolling up. 
Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day, often hiding under bushes or in holes in the ground. Although all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all of them do. In good conditions, some hedgehogs stay awake all year.

Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**
It is hard to be good at any sport, even for men, but women often have to work even harder. Training and competitions take a lot of time, so they have to make sacrifices. Despite this, they are overcoming challenges and breaking records. Here, we talk to some amazing British sportswomen who are reaching their goals.
A. **Jill, 27, Skier**  
"It's a great feeling to fly through the air and land safely, but it can be scary. Sometimes I don’t feel well or it’s windy, and I can’t see well, but I keep going. It’s hard to have a life outside skiing because we train for ten months each year. I give up a lot of my social life and friends, but it was my choice. There are six men and three women on the British team. We all compete on the same courses and get treated the same - it’s a young sport."
B. **Caroline, 22, Cyclist**  
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike to join a charity race. I won because I cycled faster than everyone else, which was amazing since I had never cycled before! I earn good money as a professional cyclist, and there are many opportunities for sponsorship. However, I worry that people might think I am successful because of my looks, not because I am a good cyclist. So, I focus on cycling and train for at least four hours every day, plus some stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands how much time it takes."
C. **Annabel, 26, Rower**  
"Rowing is hard for girls because very few schools offer it. Most girls start when they are 19 or 20, which makes it harder to succeed internationally. Also, coaches often change, so the women’s team lacks stability. But I enjoy it and love being fit, plus there is a good social life."
D. **Ffyona, 24, Long-Distance Walker**  
"When I was 13, I dreamed of walking around the world, not knowing how big it was! I felt trapped in Britain and didn’t like anyone controlling me. Now, I am more careful. Each walk has been different. Walking across Australia was the hardest experience for me. I walked 50 miles a day with little sleep and many blisters on my feet. But I set a record! I had to because my sponsorship money would run out after 95 days. Some men think women are more likely to fail, so they see sponsoring us as a risk."
E. **Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**  
"Some men have big egos when driving. When I do well, they often ignore me. Being a woman has its challenges. When I reach a corner, some men think, 'I have to beat her,' so I have had many tough moments! You need to be competitive and strong. It is hard to earn money, and what I do make goes back into racing. Women have been racing since the 1920s and have often been seen as unusual. It’s great that more women are starting to race every year. I love saloon car racing because I always aim for a perfect lap."
F. **Alison, 28, Triathlete**  
"I wake up at 5:30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evenings, I cycle or run. Yes, I sometimes fall asleep at my desk! There is a lot of pressure before a race, and when I compete, I really push myself. I often ask myself why I do this. The answer is: a) I am happier when I stay fit, b) I would be lazy if I didn’t push myself, and c) racing is very social. Men and women usually compete together, but when events are covered in the news, 90% of the articles focus on the men’s events, and only 10% mention the women’s events. The prize money is not as good for women either. But now we have formed an International Triathlon Women’s Commission to help improve this."

The day I met Picasso
Richard Cork remembers how, as a 78-year-old student, he met one of the most famous artists of the century. Even from a distance, he could see Picasso eating lunch at an outdoor restaurant in Cannes. I was an 18-year-old student, traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old van. I had run out of money and found a job painting boats by the water. But I spent a lot of time drawing and was lucky to have my sketchbook with me when I saw the famous artist.
Picasso was known to be a private person who usually stayed away from others to work. So, I was very surprised to see him sitting at a table with his wife, Jacqueline, and three friends. Without my friend's encouragement, I would never have had the courage to go over and ask for his signature. I was nervous when I introduced myself and offered my sketchbook, but he kindly agreed. He wrote his name at the top of the page and then added some lively lines below. Picasso's art often showed things from real life, so the lines might have represented a cloud, the sea, or the shape of Cannes harbor.
I thanked him and started a shy conversation. Since Picasso's English was not very good and my French was not great either, an American woman at the table helped us communicate. She kept calling him "the Maestro," which made it hard for me to speak. But I told Picasso that I loved art and admired his work. After a while, I went back to my boat and proudly showed my friend what I had. But my friend noticed that Picasso was still having lunch. "Is that all?" he asked, looking at the signature. "Why don’t you go back and talk to him more? You won’t get another chance like this!"
With my sketchbook under my arm, I returned to Picasso's table. I thought it was better not to ask if I could draw his portrait, as he might say no. So, I just stood by the table, put my pad against a screen, took out a crayon, and started to draw. When Picasso saw me, he smiled and made it hard for me to draw. He acted out funny faces, rolling his eyes and sticking out his tongue. It was like he was playing a game. I wanted to give up, but his playful spirit made me want to keep going. 
Finally, Picasso relaxed and let me study him without moving. I noticed how strong and alert he looked, wearing a blue-and-white striped shirt. He looked much younger than his age, with bright, dark eyes that were very intense. His eyes were captivating, and I tried to capture their strength in my drawing. Even though he was surrounded by friends, he seemed to be in his own world, quietly focused on his own thoughts.
When the American lady told me that Picasso wanted to see my drawing, I felt shy and said it wasn’t good enough. But Picasso insisted, and when I showed him my sketch, he nodded in approval. Then, to my surprise, he said it was his turn to draw. I quickly gave him my crayon, and he made a few quick strokes on the paper. In seconds, he drew a bearded face that looked very different from my careful drawing. He had moved one of my eyes onto my nose and captured my smile with just one lively line. I looked like a character from one of his playful artworks.
I thanked Picasso and asked if he would sign my drawing. The American lady explained that he said I already had his signature. So, he was not going to give me another one! Still, I feel very lucky to have met Picasso and to have received his attention. It meant a lot to me. 
**Questions:**
1. How old was Richard Cork when he met Picasso?
2. Where did Richard see Picasso?
3. What job did Richard have before meeting Picasso?
4. Who helped Richard and Picasso communicate?
5. What did Picasso do when Richard started to draw him?
6. How did Richard feel about meeting Picasso?

Shopping Tricks**
Have you ever gone into a store and bought more than you planned? Here are some tricks that shops use to make you spend more money.
A. **Freshness First**  
Supermarkets know that people like fresh food. They often put fruits and vegetables at the entrance of the store. Some even have bakeries that fill the air with the smell of fresh bread. The colors in the store, like green, can also make you think of fresh food. However, most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen foods and cleaning products, is not fresh.
B. **Smart Displays**  
Where products are placed in the store is very important for sales. Supermarkets use computers to find out which areas shoppers visit the most. They put high-profit items in these areas. Products at eye level are more likely to be bought. Special offers in 'dump bins' attract bargain hunters. Sometimes, they place related items together, like ice cream next to dessert toppings.
C. **Hiding Essentials**  
Supermarkets often place basic items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, shoppers pass by more tempting, expensive items on their way. Stores may also put popular products far from the entrance, hoping that loyal customers will look for them and see other items along the way.
D. **Less is More**  
Chain stores have changed how they display their products. For example, the Next chain shows fewer items on the shelves, making them seem special. Even though their clothes are mass-produced, their store design helps them sell better.
E. **Total Costs Matter**  
Shoppers care more about the total cost of their shopping than the price of each item. Supermarkets mix cheap and expensive items to attract customers. They sometimes sell basic items at a loss to bring people in, which is called 'loss leaders.' They also get discounts from manufacturers by buying in large amounts.
F. **Price Tags**  
In chain stores, shoppers usually buy fewer items and pay more attention to prices. For example, pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 can make a difference. This pricing strategy can also help reduce theft by making staff ring up sales for small change.
G. **Lighting Matters**  
Both supermarkets and chain stores think carefully about lighting. Chain stores try to use natural light so customers can see the true colors of clothes. Supermarkets use special lighting to make fresh foods look more appealing.
H. **Guiding Shoppers**  
Many chain stores use different carpet patterns to guide shoppers. One pattern shows the paths through the store, while another marks sales areas. Some stores, like Marks and Spencer, use nicer carpets in sales areas to encourage shoppers to explore.
I. **In-Store Promotions**  
When you enter a supermarket, you often see big pictures of delicious food, which can make you hungry. In the U.S., some supermarkets are testing 'video trolleys' that show ads for products while you shop. These trolleys aim to attract impulse buyers and can increase sales by about 30%.

Sea, Ice & Rock**
Chris Bonnington (58) is famous for climbing Mount Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written many books, such as *Quest for Adventure* and *Everest the Hard Way*. Robin Knox-Johnston (53) started his career at sea in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-1969, he was the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He set a record for crossing the Atlantic Ocean, taking just 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard in England. 
Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote about their journey in their new book, *Sea, Ice and Rock*. In 1979, while working on *Quest for Adventure*, I called Robin to ask for an interview. He invited me to join him for a sail. I could teach him some climbing techniques, and he could teach me how to sail. It was my first time on a yacht. We sailed for a while and then stopped. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while we paddled to shore to practice climbing. The route was difficult, but I was impressed by how steady Robin was in tough conditions. 
When we reached a big drop, I asked Robin if he had ever climbed before. He hadn’t, so I showed him how to do it. After I finished, Robin politely asked if he could go down the way he used ropes on his boat. He was used to using his arms, but I wanted him to use his legs. I was not very happy about it, but he safely lowered himself down. During that trip to Skye, Robin and I became good friends. His idea to combine our skills for a trip to Greenland was a natural next step after our time in Skye. 
Robin impressed me as a leader. Normally, the captain makes all the decisions, but Robin asked everyone for their opinions first. Most of the time, people were too afraid to give advice, but it felt good to be part of the decision-making. To be honest, I found sailing difficult and boring. The moments of crisis were easy to handle because they made me excited. The hard part was spending many days in the middle of the sea. I prefer being on land and am not very handy. Robin, on the other hand, is a natural sailor and enjoyed fixing the engine or the toilet. I felt that Robin didn’t really need me, which made me feel a bit useless at times. 
The crew was also very close together: six people on a 32-foot yacht that was meant for four. When we reached Greenland and it was my turn to lead the expedition, I found it hard to be responsible for Robin’s safety. There were many times when if Robin had fallen, he could have pulled me down with him. I had to be careful about that. I also underestimated how hard climbing Cathedral, Greenland's highest mountain, would be. Robin is not a natural climber, which made his efforts even more impressive. 
The first time we tried to reach the top, we were climbing for 24 hours. On the way down, we were so tired that we almost fell asleep on steep slopes, 1,500 feet above the ground. Robin worked very hard, but he trusted me completely. He just followed my lead. When it became too difficult and I knew we had to turn back, he accepted it. I also knew that Robin was worried about the boat: whether it would get through the ice and if it was okay. Still, he wanted to try climbing the mountain again. 
The only time we had a problem was on the yacht on the way home. We were taking turns to keep watch. I was supposed to wake up at 4 am for my shift, but Robin decided not to wake me. He thought he could handle it alone. The night before, I had almost fallen asleep. I felt that he didn’t trust me, which made me feel insecure, and I told him. Robin quickly reassured me that I was wrong to think that. 
While we enjoyed the trip to Skye, we didn’t really get to know each other until the end of the Greenland expedition. I found that beneath his tough exterior, Robin was a kind and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**
Apples have been part of human life for a very long time, in many different colors, shapes, and sizes. However, in the late twentieth century, we risk losing this important part of our history.
**Prehistoric Times (8,000 BC)**  
People have been eating apples since ancient times. In neolithic Britain, they would spit out apple seeds. About 10,000 years ago, they left apple remains near lakes in Switzerland and Italy. In Switzerland and near the Caucasus mountains, ancient people even stored dried apple halves for winter. These apples were wild crab apples, small and not like the apples we eat today.
**Norman Knowledge (1000 AD)**  
The French learned how to grow fruit from the Romans, and this knowledge was brought to Britain. The Romans introduced some apple varieties, but many did not grow well in Britain. British monks continued to experiment and create new apple types, which are the ancestors of many Western apples today.
**Medieval Favorites (1200)**  
In the thirteenth century, several apple types became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain, known for its pear-like shape, was the main dessert apple until the eighteenth century. The Costard was a cooking apple sold in Oxford markets from 1296 until the late seventeenth century. However, the country faced problems like droughts and the Black Death, which led to fewer apples being produced and more being imported. In the sixteenth century, King Henry VIII sent his fruit expert, Richard Harris, to France to learn about apple growing. Harris returned with many new apple types, including the famous Pippins, and started the first modern orchard in Kent.
**Settler Treasure (1750)**  
By the seventeenth century, apples were very popular in Britain. The first settlers who went to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand took apples and seeds with them. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia, and the Pilgrim Fathers brought them to America. In North America, John Chapman, known as 'Johnny Appleseed', planted apple trees across several states. He was seen as a kind man and became part of many stories.
**Modern Delicious (1850)**  
Around this time, a Quaker farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new apple tree growing from a dead tree's roots in Iowa. He named this apple 'Hawkey'. When he showed it at a fruit show, a judge tasted it and said it was 'Delicious'. In 1895, this apple was sold as 'Delicious' and became very popular worldwide.
**Granny Smith (1850)**  
Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was found in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. She was the daughter of convicts and worked as a midwife. In 1868, she discovered a small tree growing among discarded fruit. She moved it, and soon she was harvesting green apples that became famous worldwide. She said, "It's just like God to make something useful out of what we think is rubbish," referring to both the apple and her own background.
**Uniformity Issues (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown all over the world, but most come from just a few varieties chosen for their appearance and how well they travel, not for their taste. This lack of variety is a problem, as it reduces the different types of apples available. While some gardeners in the UK have kept old apple types alive, many apples in the US have been lost. However, people are starting to want more variety. We cannot rely only on amateur gardeners to save apple diversity; we must work to protect and value the natural variety of apples for everyone’s benefit.

Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**
Explore Worldwide is a leader in adventure travel. We create trips for people who want more than just a beach holiday. Our focus is on visiting new and interesting places with unique travel plans. Our brochure has over 100 exciting adventures, including tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions, in more than 60 countries. Most trips last from 1 to 4 weeks.
**Small Groups**
We travel in small groups, usually with about 16 people. These informal groups are led by experienced guides. This gives you a chance to learn more about the places we visit and connect with local people. It is a rewarding experience for all travelers.
**Different Ways to Travel**
We use many types of transport during our trips. You might travel by coach, local bus, train, minibus, boat, canoe, or even on foot. Each trip reflects the local environment.
**Who Travels with Explore?**
Our travelers are interesting people who are ready for new experiences. Most come from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are suitable for anyone in good health, reasonably fit, and adaptable. Most travelers are between 25 and 55 years old. About half are couples, while the rest are solo travelers.
**Activities and Interests**
It is hard to describe Explore Worldwide because each trip is unique. We have divided our adventures into 8 categories, each highlighting special activities. These highlights are important parts of the tours, but many other factors also make our trips enjoyable, such as unique places, local customs, and personal experiences.
**Cultural/Adventure**
Most of our trips have a strong cultural focus. Some tours emphasize local cultures and historical sites. For example, if you are interested in culture and history, consider our trips to Egypt, Jordan, Turkey, Greece, India, and more. Many trips include short walks to visit less-known sites.
**Wildlife and Nature**
Our wildlife safaris take you to some of the best game parks in the world, where you can see animals in their natural habitats. In Africa, you might even leave your vehicle to explore the wild. You could track mountain gorillas in Zaire, hike with local guides in Uganda, or canoe on the Zambezi River. Most safaris involve camping, but some offer hotel stays.
**Cultural Encounters**
A special part of our adventures is meeting local ethnic groups. You might meet the Tuareg of the Sahara, the Maya of Mexico, or the Huli of Papua New Guinea. Many of these cultures are at risk, and we aim to promote understanding and respect while minimizing cultural and environmental impact.
**Easy/Moderate Hiking**
Many trips include easy walks through beautiful countryside, often staying in rented homes or hotels. You can also hike from village to village, sometimes staying overnight in local homes. These trips are available in places like Spain, Greece, Morocco, and Thailand. On longer hikes, your main luggage is transported separately, so you only carry a small bag.
**Major Treks**
We offer some challenging treks for experienced hikers. These may involve walking at high altitudes and staying with local people or camping in the mountains. We usually have support vehicles and porters to help carry gear.
**Wilderness Experience**
Exploring remote wilderness areas is an exciting adventure. You can discover the beauty of the Amazon Rainforest or the deserts of the Sahara and Gobi. These trips offer a chance to experience something truly special.
**Sailtreks/Seatreks**
These are relaxing holidays where we travel by boat. We use traditional sailboats in Egypt, wooden yachts in Turkey, and ferries in Greece and Thailand. You can also explore the Galapagos Islands on a small motor yacht.
**Raft and River Journeys**
Our river trips can last from a few hours to several days. You can paddle your own inflatable boat or enjoy thrilling whitewater rafting with skilled guides. No experience is needed, and you will quickly learn the safety skills required. Our river journeys in India, Africa, and the Amazon offer a unique view of beautiful landscapes and wildlife.

Richard Nerurkar is a long-distance runner from Britain, known for running 10,000 meters. He visits a training camp in Kenya, which is located ten miles south of the equator. A beautiful mountain path starts from a quiet road in Nairobi and leads to Mount Kenya, the highest peak in the country. This place, called Nanyuk, has been Richard's base for training in the winter for three years. However, he had never trained with Kenyan runners before. 
On his fourth trip to Kenya, Richard decided to change this. He ran in his first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp, where the best Kenyan runners prepare for the World Cross-Country Team Championships. He was invited by the national team coach after finishing fifth in the World Championship 10,000 meters race, behind three Kenyans and a Moroccan. This was a great opportunity for him.
Training at high altitude helps runners produce more red blood cells, which improves their ability to carry oxygen. This is one reason why many Kenyan runners are successful. Richard's first race in Africa was also special because it was the first international cross-country race held on the continent. He finished behind 41 runners, most of whom were Kenyan, but he felt he did well.
Richard believes that Kenyan runners' success is not only because of the high altitude. They have a simple approach to running. Their running style looks easy, their diet is simple, and they enjoy competing. But how do they train? Richard found out during his stay at the training camp.
The camp is at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up Mount Kenya, surrounded by beautiful fields and plants. The living conditions are basic; the athletes share rooms with college students. Their daily routine includes three workouts: a morning run, interval training in the middle of the day, and a steady run in the late afternoon. They start their day at six in the morning. The coach tells them to run easily because they have a tough day ahead. They run about 40 kilometers each day, except on Sundays when they only run 20 kilometers.
Life at the camp is simple. They wash their faces and brush their teeth before breakfast, which includes tea, bread, and boiled eggs. Lunch and dinner are similar, with ugali (a maize dish), stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, they drive to a stream to bathe.
By the end of his stay, Richard understood more about why Kenyan runners are successful. Their success is not just because of their genes, upbringing, or altitude. He thought that the simple life in the mountains, hard training, and their passion for running might be the real reasons for Kenya's success in distance running.

The Challenges of Mass Marketing**
Almost everyone knows that advertising is struggling. This problem is not just because of the recession; advertising started to decline in 1989, before the recession really affected the economy. The issues with advertising are more serious and are happening all over the world. The sad truth is that advertising has not kept up with changes in the economy. Advertisers often think about large groups of people and mass media, but as brands and media have increased, target markets have become smaller and more specific. Even big brand campaigns should focus on smaller audiences, but they usually do not.
Think about your own shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or even 50 items. Most of these items are not from advertised brands, and you may buy several of the same brand. In total, you probably only buy a few advertised brands from the thousands available in the store. Over a year, you are unlikely to buy more than a few hundred different brands. For things like cars, you might only buy one every three years, and you do not buy many clothes either, most of which are not from advertised brands. In total, you probably do not buy more than 400 different brands in a year, compared to the 32,500 brands that are advertised.
If we look at the 9,500 brands that are listed and analyzed by Media Register, the average person only buys about 400 of them, which is about 4 percent. This means that a lot of advertising is not effective. When you watch TV, count how many commercials are for brands you buy or might buy. Most people find that only about 6 percent of the ads are relevant to them, meaning that 94 percent of the ads are likely wasted.
You might think you are different and that you do not respond to advertising, but most people feel the same way. The truth is that most people do not buy the brands they see advertised. There is always some waste in advertising because not everyone who sees an ad will buy the product. However, advertising can still be effective. Many ads have shown that they work. Advertisers need to reach a lot of people to find the few who will respond, as they cannot know in advance who will be interested.
Even the best-targeted advertising does not get a 100 percent response. This is different from face-to-face selling, where a salesperson might succeed with every customer they talk to. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they would not need to use mass media at all. Any advertiser who can gain one million new customers is doing well. For popular products, gaining a million extra customers would be a great success. Therefore, any advertising campaign that can reach even 2 percent of the population is considered very successful. To improve advertising, the messages need to be more focused on specific audiences than ever before.

**Solar Survivor: Charles Clover Visits a Green Home**
Charles Clover explores one of the most environmentally-friendly homes in Britain. This house is in Southwell, Nottinghamshire, which has some interesting surprises. The first surprise is Southwell Minster, a little-known ancient cathedral. It is famous for the 'green' men figures carved by medieval craftsmen in its thirteenth-century chapter house. The second surprise is the 'autonomous house,' built by Robert and Brenda Vale. 
The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle their sewage into compost for the garden, and heat their home using waste heat from their electrical appliances and their own body heat, along with that of their three teenage children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house looks traditional, with a clay tile roof, and is located 300 yards from the Minster. It was designed to match the orange brick of the town's old buildings and was approved by planners, even though it is in a conservation area.
When you ring the solar-powered doorbell, you hear no sound. The house is very well-insulated, with special windows that keep noise out. Inside, it is very quiet. On a sunny summer day, the windows are closed, and the conservatory warms the air before it goes into the house. Robert opens clever ventilation shafts and windows to create air movement because the house is designed to keep out drafts. Even the cats have their own small air-locked door.
The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, cared about the environment long before it became popular. They wrote a book about green architecture in the 1970s called *The Autonomous House*. They first designed a building that produced no carbon dioxide, and then they decided to not use mains water. They created composting toilets, put rainwater tanks in the cellar, and used copper gutters to keep the drinking water clean. They filter the water before using it. Water from washing goes into the garden, and they do not have a dishwasher because they believe it is wrong to use strong detergents.
Robert says, "We wanted people to see that it is possible to design a house that is much better for the environment, without living in the dark." The only medieval part of the house is its design: the hall, which includes the fireplace and staircase, goes all the way up to the roof. The Vales do not pay water bills, and last winter, the house used only nine units of electricity a day, costing about 70p. This is much less than what other four-bedroom houses use for heating.
Soon, they will install solar panels in the garden, which will help the house generate more electricity.
