Today, most gum is made from synthetic materials, with added ingredients that help keep the flavor and improve the texture. However, this was not always true. The ancient Greeks chewed a gum-like substance from the bark of the mastic tree, which grows mainly in Greece and Turkey. Women in Greece liked mastic gum to clean their teeth and freshen their breath. American colonists learned from the Native Americans in New England and chewed the resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, pieces of spruce for chewing were sold in the eastern United States, making it the first commercial chewing gum in the country.
Modern chewing gum started in the late 1860s with the discovery of chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree found in Central America. Gum made from chicle was smoother and more enjoyable to chew, leading to the growth of a whole industry. However, attempts to grow sapodilla trees for chicle have not been successful. As the chewing gum market grew, synthetic alternatives were created.
Today, the few remaining chicle gatherers, called chicleros, have a hard and dangerous job. They travel for miles to collect sapodilla in very humid conditions. They face many dangers, including poisonous snakes and insects. One of the worst is the chicle fly, which lays its eggs in the gatherers' ears and noses. Despite these risks, experienced chicleros climb trees quickly to collect the sap, which they carry back to a camp. There, they boil the sap until it becomes sticky and forms bricks.
Life at the camp is difficult, with a boring diet mostly made of maize and local alcohol made from sugar cane. Even though this work is tough, chicleros worry about their jobs. Not long ago, the United States imported 7,000 tonnes of chicle each year from Central America. Last year, only 200 tonnes were collected in the whole Yucatan peninsula of Mexico.
As chewing gum sales have increased, manufacturers have turned to synthetic materials to lower costs and meet demand. At the same time, gum producers are finding clever ways to market their products. They claim that gum helps you relax, gives you energy, and reduces stress. During both world wars, soldiers were often given gum. The biggest claim is that chewing gum helps reduce tooth decay. Plaque acid forms when we eat, but our saliva helps neutralize this acid and provides minerals like calcium and fluoride. Gum manufacturers say that chewing for 20 minutes can increase saliva flow.
Research is ongoing to create new textures and flavors. Glycerine and other vegetable oils are now used to make the gum base. Most new flavors are artificial, but some still use natural ingredients. Additionally, 137 square kilometers of land in America is used to grow mint for the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

**REMOTE HOTELS**
A. **INDIA - GHANERAO HOTEL, RAJASTHAN**  
Ghanerao Hotel is located at the edge of the Aravalli Hills in a small village known for its craftsmen. It combines the calm of an English country house with Indian culture. The Ghanerao family has lived here for 400 years, and now Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests. The hotel has basic facilities, with hot water provided by bucket, but this simplicity makes it charming.
B. **NEW ZEALAND - HERMITAGE HOTEL, MOUNT COOK**  
One of my favorite hotels is the Hermitage Hotel on New Zealand's South Island. I found it by chance while climbing. After climbing a glacier, we walked down and were surprised to find this hotel in beautiful, wild countryside. It was a wonderful experience to arrive at such luxury after a long climb, with a man playing music on the piano.
C. **MAURITIUS - PARADIS HOTEL**  
On the south-west of Mauritius, the Paradis Hotel is located on a quiet peninsula. The road to the hotel goes along the coast, passing empty beaches where only fishermen are present. The hotel is large and offers many free water sports, but you can easily find peace on its nine kilometers of private beach. If you swim a little way out into the Indian Ocean, you can hardly see the hotel because of the palm trees. In the evening, when everyone has left, you can enjoy the quiet and beautiful sunset.
D. **ST LUCIA - LADERA HOTEL**  
The Ladera Hotel in St Lucia has a stunning view. It is quiet and located high up at 1,000 feet. The open rooms look out between the twin peaks of the Pitons to the Caribbean Sea. The hotel has a colonial style, with wooden furniture and four-poster beds covered with netting.
E. **TURKEY - THE SPLENDID HOTEL, ISTANBUL**  
The Splendid Hotel is on Buyukada in the Princes Islands, a great place to escape the noise of Istanbul. The islands are just an hour away by boat and are very beautiful. There are no cars, only horse-drawn carriages. The Splendid Hotel is a charming wooden building with white paint and red domes. Although it is a bit old now, it still has a lot of character.
F. **FRANCE - CHATEAU D'ETOGES, EPERNAY**  
In the small village of Etoges, in the Champagne region, there is a lovely seventeenth-century chateau. It is surrounded by a moat with two swans. The chateau has 20 unique rooms, some with four-poster beds, and one room even has a billiard table. They offer special weekend rates for two nights, including breakfast and dinner, plus complimentary champagne.
G. **KENYA - THE FAIRVIEW HOTEL, NAIROBI**  
The Fairview Hotel is a comfortable place in Africa that is not overly luxurious. It is a popular stop for travelers resting after a safari and planning their next adventure. Guests often decide to stay longer after seeing the beautiful gardens and rooms. The hotel has many green areas and buildings on Nairobi Hill, away from the busy city center. It is a great place to enjoy the African sunset while having a drink and looking forward to a delicious dinner.
H. **ITALY - HOTEL SPLENDIDO, PORTOFINO**  
The Hotel Splendido was first signed by the Duke of Windsor. Many famous people have visited, including actors and celebrities. Today, you might meet wealthy guests, but the hotel, which was once a monastery, is still very beautiful. It offers simple but delicious food and has lovely Persian rugs and homemade pasta.

Sue Brown is a hotel inspector. Christopher Middleton watched her during an inspection. One minute into the inspection, things are already going wrong for the Globe Hotel, but the staff do not know it yet. The receptionist is busy talking on the phone and does not notice Sue and Christopher. Sue whispers, "She hasn't even acknowledged us. Very poor." This is a common mistake that Sue has seen many times in her 11 years as an inspector. She expects better from a hotel with three red stars, which means it is one of the top 130 hotels out of 4,000 in the guide she works for.
Before they even enter, Sue feels something is off. The entrance is through a door with no staff, just a buzzer, and a long, empty hallway. "This is not what I expected," she says. Things get worse when the receptionist says, "We have no record of your booking." There are 15 rooms in the hotel, but only three are occupied. The room they are offered is not good. It feels stuffy, and there is a big hole in the wall behind the wardrobe.
When Sue started her job, people called her "The Woman in Black," even though she never wore black and did not think she was tough. The next morning, after paying her bill, she tells the hotel manager, Robin Greaves, who looks scared when he sees her. He quickly apologizes for a bad smell in the lounge, saying there is a blocked drain. Sue suggests that he should guide guests to another lounge instead of the one with the smell. Greaves takes notes and seems worried. He has only been at the hotel for five months and is unsure if Sue's feedback will help.
Not everything is bad. Sue praises Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the young waitress, who shared interesting information about the hotel’s 400-year history. The dinner was also good enough to keep the hotel’s two-rosette food rating. Greaves asks, "What do we need to do to get three rosettes?" Sue replies, "Don’t serve a pudding that collapses." Greaves looks disappointed.
Sue's job is to tell the hotel what is wrong, even if it is hard to say. She remembers a time when a woman complained that Sue got her son fired because he served her apple pie with his fingers. Sometimes, she receives angry letters from hotel owners. "You get used to it, but it still hurts," she says. Sue must give a full report to the hotel after her visit because they pay for her advice.
The good news for Greaves is that Sue will not recommend taking away the Globe's red stars. The bad news is that another inspector will come back in two months to check if the problems have been fixed. "Good," Greaves says, but he does not sound very happy. 
**Questions:**
1. What is Sue Brown's job?
2. How long has Sue been a hotel inspector?
3. What mistake does the receptionist make when Sue and Christopher arrive?
4. How many rooms does the Globe Hotel have, and how many are occupied?
5. What does Sue suggest the hotel manager do about the bad smell in the lounge?
6. Who does Sue praise during her visit?
7. What does Greaves want to know about getting three rosettes?
8. What is the good news for the Globe Hotel at the end of the inspection?

Doug Scott, a mountaineer, shares his experiences of climbing the highest mountains on each continent, known as the Seven Summits. He started this journey later in life and will tell his story in the order he climbed them.
**A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**  
Doug and his climbing partner, Dougal Haston, were in a snow cave below the summit. Dougal started talking about sleeping bags, which Doug found strange since it was just the two of them. He thought it was because of the lack of oxygen. Doug began talking to his own feet because they were getting cold. He remembered other climbers who lost fingers and toes to frostbite. They were not just worried about surviving but also about how well they could survive. Over the next two days, Doug thought about their time on the summit ridge. He felt confident climbing with Dougal and knew they would succeed. He focused on finding a better rhythm to reach the summit.
**B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**  
This mountain is known to be very dangerous. In April 1976, Doug and Dougal arrived at the Kahiltna Glacier and spent four days carrying equipment and food to the base. After the first day of climbing, they realized how big their task was. They followed a route from 1967 but decided to take a new route to the summit. They climbed with all their gear on their backs, which was a new way to climb this mountain. After three days, Doug's sleeping bag was wet. They spent a night on a windy ridge and both felt tired. Because the air pressure was low, it felt like they were much higher than they actually were. Finally, they reached the summit and celebrated.
**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**  
In September 1976, Doug and his friend Paul Braithwaite flew to Nairobi to climb Mt. Kenya. However, they got a free ride to Kilimanjaro, Africa's highest mountain. On their way, they got lost in the thick jungle and ran out of water. On the second day, they found arrows painted on trees and some trash that led them to a rock pool. They were happy to find trash because it meant they were on the right path. They tried to climb a steep wall but had to turn back due to falling rocks and ice. Instead, they took the Umbwe route to reach the summit.
**D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**  
In January 1992, Doug and his wife, Sharu, arrived at Punta del Inca. They met a guide named Phil who was taking a group up a different route. After waiting for bad weather to pass, they left base camp. The Polish Glacier was icy and dangerous, so they chose to go towards the standard route where many people were climbing. The wind was strong as they walked to the summit, and they camped outside a refuge that night. At base camp, they met a group planning to climb the Seven Summits. They encouraged Doug to join them, and he began to think seriously about this goal.
**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**  
Doug learned that climbing Vinson Massif could be done by guiding enough people to pay for the trip. In November 1992, his team left Britain and traveled to the South Pole. During this time, the sun stays above the horizon all day and night. When the wind stopped, it was very quiet. On December 7, they set off for the summit. Despite strong winds and very low temperatures, they all reached the top in eight hours. However, they could only see a few meters because of a storm.
**F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**  
In the summer of 1994, Doug's team gathered in St Petersburg. When they arrived at Terskol, they had to pay a fee for bringing foreigners into the valley. After a few days of getting used to the altitude, they took a cable car up to 3,900m and then walked to a refuge at 4,200m. Two days later, they faced strong winds as they climbed. They thought they reached the summit but found there was still a long ridge to go. They returned to the refuge and the next day went down the volcano.
**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**  
On their trip to Carstensz, Doug and his team wanted to create a new climbing route and spend time with the local Dani people. They were warned about possible dangers from bandits but decided to continue. On May 12, they started climbing. The weather got better, and two team members went ahead while Doug and Sham moved slower because Sham was filming. They reached the summit by 11 am, and Doug received a standing ovation for completing his seventh summit. Mission accomplished!

**Style Merchants**
Style is important in our lives today, from clothes to home decoration and accessories. Jo Foley shares some trends for this year's fashion lovers.
**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**  
Ned Ingham creates beautiful and romantic wedding dresses. He says, "People should avoid traditional, stiff dresses and the frilly look. Instead, choose simpler styles." Ingham has been drawing and designing wedding dresses since he was a boy. At 16, he went to fashion school to learn how to make clothes. You don’t have to be a bride to wear an Ingham dress; he also designs long evening dresses in modern colors and fabrics. For those who prefer classic styles, he offers a navy-blue summer suit, which has been popular with English women for many years. But with his touch, it looks very fresh.
**Sally Quail: Jeweller**  
Sally Quail used to work for an art dealer but has no formal training in jewellery. She started designing her own engagement ring when she couldn’t find one she liked. This led her to become a designer in 1990. Now, many famous people want her jewellery. Her style features large semi-precious stones set in gold, creating beautiful necklaces, bracelets, and rings inspired by the 18th century. Recently, she has started using diamonds. "I think it reflects my age," says 36-year-old Quail. "Every woman wants a diamond at some point in her life."
**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**  
Lily Grimson started her fashion business four years ago and has already had two of her designs chosen for a big exhibition. All of her bags are handmade in the UK. A Grimson handbag is not just a bag; it is full of style, whether made from soft calfskin or heavy silk. Her bags are special because they combine elegance and care.
**Peter Little: Hairdresser**  
For over 20 years, Peter Little has styled the hair of many famous people. He says, "Most women want hair that looks real and is easy to manage at home." His goal is to make sure his clients look natural, not like they just came from a salon. However, his services are expensive, costing £250 for the first appointment, and there is a three-month waiting list. Peter has also created his own line of hairdryers and styling tools, so people can style their hair at home.
**Penny Pratt: Florist**  
Penny Pratt runs a small flower shop and also works as a flower consultant for a large supermarket chain. She gives floral ideas to top restaurants. She has no formal training in floristry and left her teaching job 10 years ago to try something new. Her modern flower arrangements have won many design awards, helping her start her own London Flower School. She has also given successful lectures in Japan and the USA. She says, "Flower arrangements are simpler now. Keep them strong and don’t use too many leaves; they can be too big. For wedding bouquets, remember: all the flowers should be the same type."

Five-Star Luxury and Modern Technology**
The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It was created by changing four large old houses and took almost two years to complete. The hotel has the latest technology to help both staff and guests.
General Manager Peter MacCann wants his staff to know the guests' names. For more details about what guests like, he uses the hotel’s computer system. This system helps the hotel give special service to returning guests. Although it cost £250,000 to set up, MacCann believes it will save money in the long run. He is happy with how well it works and the services it provides. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them when they come back.
Many hotel guests often complain about room temperature. The Merrion Hotel has a high-tech system that allows guests to change the temperature in their rooms. They can adjust it by three degrees around the normal temperature of 18°C. The front desk can also change the temperature anywhere between 14°C and 25°C.
Business guests will find the technology in their rooms very useful. MacCann thinks that about 65% of the hotel’s business will come from this group. To meet their needs, the hotel has put a business center in each room. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that can also copy and print, and a video-conferencing system.
Technology changes quickly, so the hotel has prepared for future improvements. They have added extra cables for new technology. The televisions are rented, so they can be replaced with newer models when needed. DVD recorders can also be updated.
Even with all this modern technology, MacCann wants guests to feel comfortable. The hotel has 145 large and well-furnished bedrooms that are welcoming. There is also a swimming pool, a gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.
The food at the hotel is very important. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, has moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This change has many benefits for both him and the hotel. He has designed a new kitchen and improved parking. The hotel can now offer a great place to eat without financial risks. With good technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is likely to be very successful.

An Eye for Detail**
Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. The large garden around her house gives her many ideas for her art. It is full of her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread all over the garden. The two long flower borders along the path in the garden have a beautiful mix of colors and shapes. This is partly because the previous owners were good gardeners and left plants that Susan liked. She also kept the gardener, Danny. "In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along very well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' for some of the things I wanted to add, but when I said I wanted to paint them, he understood what I meant."
Susan likes to focus on painting individual plants instead of the whole garden. Sometimes, she paints a group of plants, but usually, she picks one flower and takes it to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which might take a few days. Then I bring in another one and build up the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."
Her busiest time is spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all come out together, and you're so busy," she says. But she also finds beauty in how flowers change as they decay. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for a day, and they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, you think they are boring, but they change all the time."
Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and used to collect wildflowers from the countryside," she says. "I wasn't really interested in gardening then; I thought garden flowers looked fake, like silk or plastic. To me, only wildflowers were real. I was fascinated by how they could grow in difficult places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs."
Today, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they seem to fit in well. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, like a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don’t cause too much trouble. With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of subjects to paint, she has found it hard to work in the garden lately. She now hires an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected with her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Text:**
Many trees in the Brackham area fell during the strong storms in March. The town lost two big lime trees from the old market square. The loss of these trees changed the look of the town center, which upset some of the local people. Normally, Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, the head of the local police, would have been one of those upset. But during the storm, when the wind knocked down the walnut tree in his garden, he was too sick to notice. Pelham, a large and healthy man, was seriously ill for the first time in his life with bronchitis. When he first felt pain in his head and tightness in his chest, his wife, Molly, tried to get him to see a doctor. He thought the police needed him too much, so he ignored her and kept working. This made him forget things and made him short-tempered. It was only when his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor that he finally agreed to go. By then, he was too weak to argue. Soon, she took him to the pharmacy to get his antibiotics and then home to his wife, who sent him straight to bed.
On Thursday morning, when Molly told him that the walnut tree had fallen during the night, Pelham could not believe it. On Thursday evening, he weakly asked if the house was damaged. He was relieved to hear it was not and pulled the sheets over his head. It was not until Saturday, when the antibiotics worked, and he got up, that he realized the loss of the walnut tree had changed the living room forever. The Pelhams' big house had a large garden. It was expensive, but Pelham was happy with his choice. The garden had given them privacy. Now, the storm had changed how he saw things. Before, the living room had a beautiful walnut tree outside. This tree did not make the room dark because there was also a window on the other wall. The tree created nice patterns of light and shadow that hid the old furniture from their previous house. Without the tree, the room was too bright, showing the worn furniture in all its bad condition. The view from the window was not nice either. The tall house next door, which was hidden by the tree, was now visible, with its ugly purple bricks and pipes. It had many upstairs windows that seemed to watch the Pelhams all the time.
“Doesn’t it look terrible?” Pelham said weakly to his wife. But Molly, standing in the doorway, sounded more happy than upset. “That’s what I’ve been telling you since we moved here. We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost.”

Living in the Valley**
We had been living in our valley for sixteen months when we first noticed the dangers in the hills around us that could threaten our survival. It was the year when the storms came early, even before November ended. Until then, we felt safe in our valley below the hills. Soon, snow began to fall. Within a day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. It almost completely blocked our lane and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. But in the hills, the snow was much deeper and stayed for longer. Up there, the wind blew strongly. In our valley, we felt only sudden gusts of wind; the trees swayed, but their branches stayed strong. Still, we knew we had reasons to worry. The snow and wind were annoying, but they did not really scare us. It was the river, the Ryburn, which usually flowed gently, that worried us the most. It reminded us of what could happen if the water from the hills was not controlled by the dams built many years ago.
Soon, the snow started to melt. Day after day, we watched dark clouds gather over the hills to the west. These grey clouds spread over the valleys, warning us of what was coming. We had seen enough of the sky; now we began to watch the river, which was getting fuller and wilder every day. The snow was washed away as more rain fell from the clouds, but the reservoir in the hills was filling up and getting close to overflowing. Then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. It was like a small Niagara Falls, as the water rushed over the dam and into the stream below. The river looked wild as the water poured down towards its lower parts. Just a couple of meters from our cottage, the stream was furious beneath the bridge. It was much deeper than we had ever seen it so close to our home, crashing against its banks. For three days, we hoped it would stay below its edge. Luckily, our hopes were answered as the dam held and the water began to go down.
In the past, before the dam was built, the river had flooded nearby villages many times. Now, the dam controls the river's flow, and usually everything is fine. The large amount of water from the hills, from snow and heavy rain, stays behind the dam with only a little overflow sometimes. Because of this protection, we can enjoy the big clouds over the valley and feel excited by the river's power. Thanks to the dam, we can feel that our home in the valley is still safe.

Film critic Mark Adams looks back at his ten years of work as a film critic for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing articles about films for The Front Page was my first real job. Before that, I had done some reviews - books for other newspapers, films for a magazine, and anything I was asked to do for the radio. That is how I met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who also wrote for radio and television. He hired me, but Tom was not mainly a journalist, or he would have been more careful in choosing his staff. 
At first, he wanted a team of critics to cover art forms that didn’t need special knowledge: books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. We would have a weekly lunch to choose what to write about from the artistic material Tom wanted us to cover, and there would also be guests to make it friendly. It felt like a dream at that time: a new newspaper, and I was part of the team. It seemed unlikely that a new paper could succeed in a busy market. I even thought a millionaire wanted to help me personally and was pretending to hire me because I lacked self-confidence. The first time I saw someone reading the newspaper on the London Underground and turning to a page with my review, I didn’t know where to look.
Tom's idea for a team of critics for the arts did not work out. It was a good idea, but we didn’t meet as planned, so everything was done by phone. It turned out that the public preferred to have a reviewer focus on one subject area, so I chose film. Without Tom's help, we would not have the current setup, where I write a longer weekly piece, usually about one film. I like this way of working. I wouldn’t have enjoyed the usual film critic's job, which means watching every new film. That routine would make me tired quickly. I would soon be sitting in my seat on a Monday morning, thinking, "What terrible film do I have to watch now?" - a thought that many critics have around the world.
The time I have allows me to expand my ideas or, in a boring week, to create something interesting from nothing. But what is my role in the public eye? I think people choose films based on the stars, the advertising, or the director. Some people are loyal to certain types of films, while others avoid them. It is rare for someone who dislikes westerns to buy a ticket for one after reading a review, or for a romantic film lover to skip a love story because of a review. So if a film review is not really a guide for consumers, what is it? I don’t feel I have to be "right" about a movie. I also don’t think there should be a set number of "great" and "bad" films each year. All I need to do is present an argument. I’m not a judge, and I don’t want to be one.

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers? Because "it's fun." 
Melanie Sears is a teenager who loves endurance sports. She is looking for a training partner for triathlons, preferably a girl. The partner should enjoy long-distance running (15 kilometers regularly), swimming (especially in cold water), and cycling (100 kilometers is a plus). It is important to be able to do all three sports without resting.
Triathlons are becoming very popular in the Olympics. Many people are amazed (and sometimes shocked) to see athletes swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers without stopping. But why do these athletes push their bodies so hard? 
Melanie, who is 17 and does well in school, has not yet learned the usual phrases about personal satisfaction and mental challenges that many athletes say. She explains, "You swim 1500 meters, then run out of the water and jump on your bike, still wet. Of course, then you freeze. After the 40-kilometer bike ride, you have to run 10 kilometers, which is hard when you're tired. But it's great fun, and it's all worth it in the end."
Melanie started her first triathlon when she was 14. "I won the junior section, but I was the only junior there. It felt so easy that I waved at my teammates as I went around." Feeling confident, she entered the National Championships. Although she had the second fastest swim and the fastest run, she did not do well overall. "I was following a man, and suddenly we reached the sea. We realized we had gone the wrong way. I ended up cycling 20 kilometers too far. I cried all the way through the run." But she did not give up and is determined to keep trying. "Sometimes I wish I could stop because then the pain would be over, but I am afraid that if I stop just once, I would want to stop again."
Steve Trew, the sport's director of coaching, admires her determination. "I tested her fitness," he says, "and she worked so hard on the running machine that it finally threw her off into a wall. She gave it everything, but while most people stop when they can't go further, she just kept going."
This year, Melanie was the top junior in the European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. "I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running, but much slower at cycling. That's why I'm working very hard on it." She is trying to convince her parents to buy a £2,000 bike (with a £1,000 discount) for her trip to New Zealand for the World Championships. 
However, her tough training has made her a bit of a loner. "I don't have a social life," she says. "I'm not a party person. After two hours of hard swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I call and write to the other girls on the team." What do they talk about? Boys? Clothes? "No, we talk about our times in the races."
Where will all this focus lead her? Melanie has tried other events, like the triathlon "sprint," where you only swim 750 meters, cycle 20 kilometers, and run 5 kilometers. She wants to enter even tougher events than the triathlon. "The big problem is, I have no one my age to train with," she says.

The Collectors**
Amanda Roy writes about collecting and why many people enjoy this hobby. I have always loved collecting, and one in three adults shares this interest. Collecting is a world of passion and excitement. However, if you want to collect something, remember this: only collect items you truly love. 
Since ancient times, people have wanted to collect things. Long ago, early humans collected pebbles and wore them as necklaces. They liked the shapes and colors of the pebbles, which were their first attempts to gather objects for personal reasons. Over the years, not much has changed. Children still collect stones and seashells just for their beauty.
I have been collecting all my life. I have collected many things, from flowers like tulips to pottery and paintings. My first collection was stones I found in my parents' garden. When I was six, I went to a school in a remote part of England, a cold place surrounded by hills. When my parents visited, they took me to a local museum filled with objects collected by people in the past. I was fascinated by these items. 
Surprisingly, I am not alone in my interest in collecting. One in three adults enjoys this hobby. People collect for many reasons, and some say it is the only part of their lives where they feel in control. For me, it is just something I enjoy.
One famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France. He had a "room of wonders" filled with natural and man-made curiosities, like cups made from coconut shells and pieces of Oriental china. Another collector, Catherine the Great of Russia, owned more than 4,000 paintings. But you don’t have to be rich to start a collection. I have collected many different items, like tulip bulbs and china cups, with great determination. 
I remember when I convinced another tulip collector to sell me a special tulip. I planted it and took care of it, but one year it disappeared—stolen by another collector. I also collected 350 American rag dolls, searching all over the USA for different designs. Sadly, this collection was destroyed when my house caught fire. The next morning, I stood in my front hall and saw the remains of my furniture and my collection. I was very sad about both.
I have always been interested in how collections change hands. A silver spoon that belonged to a king or a poet gives value to items traded in markets. As small objects become popular among collectors, their prices go up. For example, toys from the 1950s are now valuable, especially if you kept the original boxes. (Unfortunately, I threw away both the boxes and the toys!)

My Line of Work**
Four people talk about their jobs.
**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**  
I organize temporary exhibitions. This means I plan and design the exhibition and promote it. I read about the exhibition topic and talk to important people to find out the main themes and goals. I decide what objects and pictures to display. I also plan interactive displays, workshops, and theatre to help the public understand the exhibition. I work with engineers and electricians to make sure the exhibition is safe for visitors. Before the exhibition opens, I help create brochures and leaflets to inform people about it.
**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**  
When I arrive at 7:30 a.m., I first check the accounts. Then, I see what new maps and documents we need for the taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are in school, learning how to make the journeys. They find the best routes, using one-way streets and making the right turns. I help when there are disagreements, like whether a right turn is allowed at a certain junction. When they are close to the test, I give them a simple route, but I tell them they must take a different route because the road is closed. The next student has to find another route, and I give them a reason why they can’t go that way. This is to make them think.
**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**  
I live by the coast and work from home. I answer phone calls, create educational materials, and set up training courses. Sometimes, I go to our main office, but I usually work on the coast. I work with schools and study centers and run courses for coastal managers and decision-makers about the sea. I take them out to sea in a boat to help them understand the life below the water. This often changes their views because it is very different from making decisions on a computer. I am lucky because conservation is my hobby, so I enjoy my job. However, I work for a charity, so I always need to find more money, which makes it hard to do everything I want.
**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**  
My job is quite varied. I make sure our publishing program meets market needs and that we have about 300 books in stock. We have high standards for information and content. We receive many letters from readers about issues like international boundaries, and I must respond carefully. I discuss future projects and current sales with co-publishers. I work with a great team, which makes the job enjoyable. The downside is that there is too much administration, which leaves less time for more interesting tasks like product development and design.

No Title**
Every June, we went to Ireland. Since the four of us started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It is a big house by the sea, not far from the village of Ardbeag. The English couple who own the house, the Malseeds, have made some changes to it, but they did it carefully. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds were still advertising. "How about this?" he said one evening and read the details. The summer before, we had gone to a hotel recommended by friends, but it was not good because the food was terrible. The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, but my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school; Dekko Deacon sounds nice, I guess. He and Strafe were in school together, which is why we call Strafe by his last name like the teachers did. We are all about the same age and live close to the town where the Malseeds lived before moving from England to Ireland. We always think it is a funny coincidence.
"How very nice," Mrs. Malseed said, smiling to welcome us again this year. She seems to know when guests are arriving because she is usually waiting in the large hall that smells of flowers. "Arthur, take the luggage up," she told the old porter. "Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium," she said, naming the rooms we would stay in. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of using numbers. In winter, when not many people come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of little details like that; her husband takes care of repairs and decoration. "Well, well, well," Mr. Malseed said as he came into the hall from the kitchen. "A hundred thousand welcomes," he greeted us in the Irish way. He was smiling, and his dark brown eyes sparkled, making us feel special, not just another group of guests. Everyone smiled, and I could feel that our holiday had truly begun. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; everything was good. Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. "You look younger every year, all four of you," she said, making everyone laugh again. 
Arthur led the way to our rooms, carrying as much luggage as he could and coming back for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while but not for too long because we were still tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner because Glencorn Lodge is always full in June. From our table by the window, we could see some guests walking on the lawns and others going down the cliff path to the beach. In the morning, we would do the same: walk along the sand to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, returning in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. I knew this because over the years, we had developed this routine. Since we first came here, we had all fallen in love with the beautiful landscape.

Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**
A chalet girl's work is never done, says Sarah Sutherland-Pilch. This is her second year as a chalet girl. Sarah, 24 years old, is from West Sussex, England. She works in Val d'Isere, France, cooking and cleaning for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah studied French and History of Art at Oxford Brookes University.
Sarah does not see being a chalet girl as a long-term job. She enjoys it and thinks it is a good way to meet interesting people. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before making breakfast for the guests. They have a big breakfast with porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants.
After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she says is the worst part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. On good days, she can ski until 4:30 p.m. 
After skiing, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. Dinner is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen. She prefers to start the next day with a clean kitchen. Sometimes she talks with the guests, but other times they want to be alone. 
Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives, and they go out around 11 p.m. They usually start at a place called Bananas, then go to G Jay's, and maybe end the night at Dick's T-Bar. However, she does not stay out too late on Saturday because Sunday is her busiest day.
On Sunday, she starts work early. Breakfast for guests leaving has to be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, Sarah cleans quickly. If she has not done the shopping for the week on Saturday, she does it now. Around 3 p.m., after cleaning, she prepares tea for the new guests who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes the new guests are confused and have many questions.
Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski boots or skis and then gets a ride back to the chalet. Soon, it is time for dinner again, and sometimes she has a drink afterward, but if she is too tired, she goes to bed early.

Miss Rita Cohen was a small girl with pale skin. She looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but she said she was six years older. One day, she came to Seymour's factory wearing overalls and big shoes. Her curly hair framed her pretty face. Seymour found it hard to believe that she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania and doing research on the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree.
A few times a year, someone would contact Seymour to ask if they could visit his factory. Sometimes, he would help students by answering their questions over the phone or giving them a short tour if they seemed serious. Rita was very small, almost like the children from Marie's third-grade class, who had visited the factory years ago to see how gloves were made. Seymour remembered how Marie loved to watch the workers shape and press the gloves using hot brass hands. She called them the "pancake hands" because they looked flat and strange.
Rita asked, "How many pieces come in a shipment?" Seymour replied, "Between twenty and twenty-five thousand." She took notes and asked, "Do they come directly to your shipping department?" He liked that she was interested in all the details. "They go to the tannery first. The tannery is a contractor. We buy the material, and they prepare it for us. My grandfather, father, and I all worked in the tannery here in town. Have you ever been inside a tannery?" 
"Not yet," Rita said. 
"Well, you should visit a tannery if you want to write about leather. I can help you set that up. They are old places. The technology has improved, but it is still similar to what it was hundreds of years ago. It’s hard work. Tanning is one of the oldest industries. They found 6,000-year-old tools for tanning in Turkey. The first clothes were just animal skins that were tanned by smoking them. It’s an interesting subject. My father knows a lot about leather. If you talk to him about gloves, he could talk for two days. Glovemen really love their work. 
"Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?" 
"I can't say I have." 
"Never seen anything made?" 
"I saw my mother make a cake when I was a child." 
Seymour laughed. She made him smile. She was innocent and eager to learn. His daughter was much taller than Rita, but Rita reminded him of Marie. She had the same bright intelligence that filled their home when Marie came back from school, full of what she had learned. 
"I have an idea. We will show you the whole process. Come on! We are going to make you a pair of gloves, and you will watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?"

**Is it a tough job?** Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they are as great as they seem.
**A. Raquel Graham**  
Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She cannot meet us tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles instead. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she has to travel around the world quickly. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss. However, she has one small problem - she does not like flying. "On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to help me relax," she says. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. "It felt so closed in with those tiny windows." When she is not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She has to do some boring paperwork, like organizing schedules, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning trips, and making more travel arrangements. She did not apply for this job. A chance meeting with a pop group manager led to her getting work behind the scenes, and she took a secretarial course in the evenings. Five years later, she was in the right place when her boss needed a personal assistant.
**B. David Brown**  
David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy, which means he carries a golfer's bags. He prefers being a caddy because golf is his passion. However, there are some downsides. He earns a small flat fee plus a percentage of the winnings. The average earnings are between £25,000 and £35,000, but much of that goes to travel and hotels. He was 31 when he first caddied for golfer Greg Norman. "You are not just carrying bags. You give advice, use your knowledge, and try to understand the course," he explains. Recently, his accounting skills were recognized by European Tour Productions, and they made him a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes statistics from the caddies, which are important for TV commentators, golf magazines, and the golfers.
**C. Martin Fern**  
Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a daily newspaper. One of his easier tasks is to try food at the best restaurants. What does he think about restaurants that charge high prices? "For those who can pay, it's their choice," he says. "I would rather spend £120 on a meal I will remember than buy a microwave." His cooking talent led to a friend offering him a food column in a Saturday Review. At that time, he was the creative director of an advertising agency, and it was a good extra income. He was 42 when another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "It meant a 50% cut in my guaranteed income," he says. "But it was a chance to turn my passion into a job." He still cooks at home and tries to stay healthy by cycling a couple of miles to the nearest tube station.
**D. Dick Prince**  
"I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago," says Dick Prince, one of Britain's most popular children's writers. "Before that, I loved words and enjoyed using them, but I mostly wrote poems. Then I had an idea for a story. I had been a farmer and knew about chickens being killed by a fox. So, I wrote a story called The Fox Busters, which became my first published children's book." Where do his ideas come from? "It's not easy; I have to work hard on them," he says. "I usually do this in the mornings. I don't wake up at dawn, I'm afraid. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing what I wrote in the morning. I use an old portable typewriter instead of a laptop. I get between 50 and 100 letters a week, and that is the part of being a writer that I enjoy the most. I try to answer them all, but now I have some help with that."

'In the lumberyard by the lake, trees from the woods were turned into boards for building. There was an old brick building that was two floors high, and outside, there were big piles of soft sawdust. These golden piles of dust covered the yard down to the blue lake. That afternoon, feeling bored, all the boys followed Michael up the ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking out at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and without thinking, he jumped off the roof and landed in the sawdust, rolling around and laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards," he said, trying to get them to jump too. 
Still laughing, he watched them hesitate on the roof, looking scared. One by one, they jumped down and got up smiling with relief. In the hot afternoon sun, they lay on the sawdust pile telling jokes until one of the boys said, "Come on up on the roof again and jump down." They were not very excited, but they went up to the roof again and started jumping off in a determined way until only Michael was left. The others were down below, smiling and calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong with you?" 
Michael wanted to jump down and join them, but he stayed on the edge of the roof, nervously licking his lips and grinning. He wondered why it did not seem like a long drop the first time. For a while, they thought he was just joking, but then they saw him clenching his fists. He was trying to count to ten and then jump. When that did not work, he tried to take a deep breath and close his eyes. Soon, the boys began to laugh at him; they were tired of waiting, and it was almost dinnertime. "Come on, you're a coward! Do you think we're going to sit here all night?" they shouted. When he did not move, they started to walk away, still shouting. 
"Who started this? What's wrong with you all?" he called. But he stayed on the edge of the roof, looking sadly at the ground. He was alone for nearly an hour while the sun slowly set over the lake. His clothes were wet from nervous sweat. Finally, he closed his eyes, jumped off the roof, and fell heavily into the sawdust, lying there for a long time. The yard was quiet; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he could not jump before. Then he got up slowly and walked home, feeling very ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone. He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You should be able to get home in time for dinner. If you won't come home, you might as well stay in tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin and a little grey in her hair, always patient. She spoke with a serious tone, but Michael, with his dark face looking sad, hardly heard her. He was still thinking about the boys laughing at him on the sawdust pile.'

**Careers Advice**
Are you unhappy in your job and not sure how to change it? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people who want to change their job go to a careers adviser. First, you will write a short history of yourself and then take some tests called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, you will receive a summary of the results and suggestions for different careers, along with any retraining you might need.
I decided to try Career Analysts, one of the biggest organizations that give career advice. Taking the careers test felt like being back in school during science exams. I was with about ten other people, and we had to answer questions quickly. I reminded myself that it was not about passing or failing. It was hard to see how the psychometric tests would show an accurate picture of me. The tests included finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes.
After the tests, I talked with an adviser. He used my test results and our conversation to create a report with his observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of what he said, but I was a bit upset to learn that I did poorly in the scientific and practical tests. I am glad I never became a nurse! However, it was good to hear that I had made the right choices regarding journalism.
Changing your career does not always mean making a big change. Last March, after working as a marketing manager for five years, 25-year-old Donna Laney lost her job. Her friends suggested she visit Career Analysts for help. "Losing my job was a great chance for me to think about my career," says Donna. "I wanted to look at my skills and interests." Some of the results surprised her. "I didn’t know I had a talent for design. But I had to think about the cost of retraining in design compared to my financial situation," she explains. Other ideas included taking a year off to work in the Far East. "I decided to use my existing skills and find a job that suited me better than insurance. Now, I work as a Public Relations officer. I believe I would have reached this point without Career Analysts, but they helped me understand what I really wanted to do. I have sent several friends there, and they are all happy with the service."
Some people feel they would not have made important decisions without help. A visit to Career Counselling Services helped 26-year-old Juliet Greene make life-changing choices. "After working at a big bank for six years, I found my job boring and wanted a new challenge. I had no idea what I wanted to do, so I went to Career Counselling Services with an open mind. I took the tests, which showed I was interested in sciences," she says. "I had four sessions with an adviser. The third session was recorded, which was helpful because you forget many things you say. After the fourth meeting, I listened to the test results and decided I wanted to study geology. I plan to start a degree in it later this year. I think the advice from Career Counselling Services was worth the money. I am much happier now."
However, career advice does not work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, says, "I reached a point in my career where I didn’t know what to do next. I thought a careers adviser might suggest something new. Although I received many ideas, I rejected them because they either meant a big pay cut or a lot of retraining. I didn’t learn anything new about myself," she says. "You have to share a lot of personal information with the adviser, and I felt that if I had told a friend the same things, they would have given me similar advice."

Fun at the Dentist's**
If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in the center of Glasgow, you will see bright paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch where patients sit while he checks their teeth. Jerome says, "Fifty percent of people only go to the dentist when they are in pain instead of for regular check-ups. This is because they are scared." To help with this, he has tried to make a place where people feel safe. That is why he decided not to wear a white coat, which many people connect with pain. He believes that dental treatment should happen in a relaxing, interesting, and enjoyable atmosphere.
This idea is surprising for many people who think of dental visits as painful or very formal. Jerome says, "If people are relaxed, entertained, and treated well, they will forget their bad experiences." One of his new ways to help people relax is by using virtual-reality headsets. "We were the first dental office in Britain to use them, and they are very popular. The headsets are used during the first check-up, where the patient sits comfortably on the blue couch and watches a film about underwater wildlife while I check their teeth. Then the headset shows a special camera that gives the patient a view of their mouth."
Most patients seem to enjoy this part of their visit. Another important thing is that the office smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's office. Today, it smells like orange. Jerome explains, "When people walk in, I want them to feel with all their senses that it is not like going to the dentist. Smell is very important. The usual dentist smell can make people feel nervous." I found the nice smell in the office very pleasant.
Even though he is known as Glasgow's most stylish dentist, Jerome takes his work very seriously. The relaxation methods are important, but the quality of the treatment is the most important thing. For example, Jerome uses a special tool that sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them instead of scraping. It feels a bit strange at first, but if people are relaxed, it is not painful at all.
Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn about dental techniques. "One thing I learned is that when you make it easier for the patient, it is easier for you too," he explains. He believes that his patient-focused approach is the beginning of a change towards less formality in British dentistry.
At that moment, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly goes to him, offers a cup of tea (herbal or regular), asks what video he would like to watch, and gently leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this special treatment, and it is easy to see why. The office feels more like a beautiful salon than a regular dental practice.

Chocolate, which comes from South America, is now a big business around the world. In the UK, people spend over £230 million on chocolate at Easter. This is about eight percent of all chocolate sales for the year. People eat even more chocolate at Christmas. 
The large production of chocolate started in the last century, but the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over three thousand years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and South-East Asia. The fruit of this tree is the size of a melon and has 20-40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often called cocoa beans, which is a spelling mistake from the 17th century.
The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and made a drink called xocoatl, which means "bitter water" in their language. They flavored this drink with spices for special occasions. The Spanish liked the drink better with cinnamon and sugar, but it took another hundred years for the recipe to reach the rest of Europe. 
In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in European cities where people could drink chocolate. Until the last century, the drink was made from solid chocolate blocks that had to be melted in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the beans. The chocolate bar we know today started in 1847 when a company in Bristol, Fry and Sons, mixed cocoa butter with chocolate liquor and sugar to make a solid block. A Swiss company later added milk to create milk chocolate.
At the beginning of the 20th century, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their factory Bournville, hoping to attract some French style. Then, in 1905, Cadbury introduced the Dairy Milk bar, which was first called Dairymaid. Smart advertising linked it to the healthy milk from the English countryside, making it popular against French brands.
Today, people in Britain eat about four chocolate bars each week. This has made chocolate companies look for new ways to attract customers. One new idea is to turn chocolate bars into ice cream, soft drinks, or desserts to appeal to chocolate lovers who want something different. 
However, cacao farmers are still struggling because cocoa bean prices fell in the late 1980s. Many small farmers went out of business. So, next time you enjoy a chocolate bar, think about the farmers who grow cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**
At 83 years old, Peter Cooke is a master of his art. He still wants to try new things, like making paper and working with feathers. For now, he focuses on what he loves: creating beautiful objects from shells. 
As he shows me his work in his apartment, he asks, "Am I boring you?" There is a fine line between being boring and being passionate, but Cooke is definitely passionate. His charm and the beauty of his creations make it easy to listen to him. 
He points to some shell-covered decorations above his fireplace. "I won’t mind if people don’t buy them because I love them. I never planned to sell my work. About five years ago, some friends told me I should have an exhibition so more people could see my art. They helped me talk to a gallery owner." This led to an exhibition in London, where 70% of his pieces were sold. His second exhibition opened yesterday. 
The prices for his work are high—around £2,000 for some decorations. Cooke says he has nothing to do with the prices and is open about them. He believes that no one else makes art like his, and the gallery owner told him, "One day you will stop, and everyone will want your pieces because there won’t be any more." 
Cooke wishes he had started this work earlier in life because he thinks he could have made even more amazing things. Although he still has many ideas, he feels he is more limited now than when he began. However, his work is very different from the common shell items found in seaside shops. 
"I have a miniature mind," he says, which has led him to create boxes covered in thousands of tiny shells, small pictures made from shells, and baskets of very realistic flowers. He has developed his own method and uses materials he finds. For example, he uses cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases, a special glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. 
"I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just happens," he says about his working process. The details, colors, and balance in his work look very careful and not random at all. 
Cooke searches for beautiful, tiny shells not just on his local beaches in Norfolk, but also in places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He lies on the sand to find shells to take home. He only collects dead shells and defends himself against people who accuse him of harming the beaches. "When I collect shells, I see many people stepping on them much faster than I can collect them. The sea breaks up the shells that are left. I would never take shells with living creatures in them, but once they are empty, why shouldn’t I collect them?" 
His argument is strong, especially considering the beauty of his work often exceeds the beauty of the shells themselves.

**The Schoolgirl Model**
Kira Langer is a 15-year-old girl who is a model. When she is not traveling to exciting places or appearing on magazine covers, she is studying for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw learns more about her.
The receptionist at Kira's modeling agency told me, "I'm afraid Kira will be a little late." I thought, "Oh, that's fine." I had read some bad things about models, like they can be difficult or vain, and I worried that Kira would be late. I wondered how late she would be. Would she come at all? What if she chose to go to the hairdresser instead of meeting me? If she was late, she might be in a bad mood and not want to talk.
But when Kira, the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition, arrived, she was smiling and relaxed, and she was with her mother. Kira was not wearing fancy clothes; she had on a simple black dress and trainers. She seemed very friendly and was not selfish at all. Kira explained that all models under 16 must bring an adult with them to work. Her mother looked proud of her daughter.
Kira seemed a bit confused by her sudden fame, which was unexpected. It was her older sister who encouraged her to enter the modeling competition. Kira said, "She saw the competition and told me to join. I said no, but she sent some photos anyway." When Kira found out she was a finalist, she was at school. Being chosen for the final gave her the confidence to continue, and she did very well. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London offered her work right away.
Now, Kira has to manage her two different lives. Her friends and teachers are proud of her, but some people at school are not nice about her success. They say she thinks too highly of herself. Kira finds this hard to handle because she is not a selfish person. She said, "They think that because I am a model now, I can't be the same. But the only thing that has changed is that I am more confident. I can stand up for myself more."
Being a busy model affects her social life. The Select agency can call her at any time to offer her a job for the next day. Kira said, "If my friends are going out, I can't promise to join them because I don’t know what I will be doing. I can’t make plans, and sometimes they get canceled, but my friends understand. They don’t say, 'You never have time for us anymore.'"
Kira has the looks, talent, and support to have a great career ahead of her, and not many people can say that before finishing their school exams. As I was about to end the interview with this girl who seems to have it all, I asked her what she would like to do if she didn’t have her beauty. She thought for a moment and replied, "I would like to do what you are doing."

Father and son start Gold Rush
Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from the cold north of Canada to the hot land of Africa looking for gold. The father and son team—one is an explorer and the other is a mineral expert—think their mine on a Welsh mountain could have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they believe they are very close to finding a gold vein worth five million dollars. 
"As we dig, we are finding a lot of gold; now we just need to dig a few more meters to where it is concentrated," said Terence, 68, from Liverpool. The pair have dedicated their lives to finding gold. Their search began when Terence read about gold worth millions buried in the 'Dolgellau gold belt,' an area near the town of Dolgellau in Wales. While reading old mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth, they chose the best area of land to study.
Since they first cleared the land and found pieces of gold in the rocks, they have spent the last ten years getting permission to work from the landowners, taking soil samples, and removing old cars and trash. They have dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to create a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft. Now, they are running out of money. They have spent their savings on this dream and need to convince someone to invest £50,000 to dig a little deeper to find the gold.
Chris Madden says, "Right now, it looks doubtful, but we have a few people we can contact." As news spread through the valleys about their dig, more people became interested in gold. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and local residents are hopeful. "It would bring more people here if they are right," said Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, "but if they find gold, I hope millions of people do not come and dig up the hillside."
The Welsh gold industry has declined a lot since its peak in the late 1880s when thousands of people worked in many mines across the countryside. One of the last remaining mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. Now, however, individual gold diggers are coming back. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel deep into the hill on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. "Searching for gold is very emotional," said Hall, 70. "It's adventurous and exciting, the thrill of finding hidden treasure. Maybe I will be lucky this time."

IN HOT WATER**
Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and does research in marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she gets into a small steel vehicle for underwater exploration and dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. 
Inside the vehicle, space is very limited. Rachel says, "I can reach out and touch the two pilots." They cannot stand up or move around, and they must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there is a problem and they need to get to the top quickly, they can hit a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that goes quickly to the surface. Rachel says, "No one has tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a very pleasant journey."
Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. It was on a ship, and she got in with an instructor. He explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They were testing how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. They went to a place that was a five-day sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. There, on the ocean floor, is a large area of underwater volcanoes that blow out black smoke. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study a project that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano.
When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. She says, "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research on the 'black smokers.'" This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. This water comes out at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees.
Rachel recalls a frightening moment when she first dived with an American team. They were towing equipment on a 50-meter rope when suddenly there was an explosion. There was a huge bang as the shock waves hit their vehicle, and she thought, "I'm going to die." They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they felt incredible relief—they were still alive!
Rachel finds it exciting to dive to the deepest part of the ocean. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She thinks, "Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them." Rachel studied the black smokers for three years for her PhD, and when she finally saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling.

"I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a little sunburned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was tired, and my mind was confused by foreign train schedules, money, and languages. 'Never again,' I said as I stepped onto home ground. I said the same thing the next year and the year after that. All I had to do was buy one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. 
Sleeping in a train corridor is very different from sleeping in a regular bed. The movement of the train rocks you to sleep. Carrying all your things in a backpack makes you travel simply and can lead to wasting things, like burning socks that smell bad and throwing away books after reading them. However, this way of thinking is part of the Inter-Rail spirit, where common sense can be forgotten along with old books and socks. All you need is one of those tickets in your hand. 
A ticket that lets young people travel through many countries in one day is special. On my first trip, my friends and I didn’t know how much we could do with this ticket. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to our campsite in southern France. But the idea of traveling non-stop was too exciting. There was always one more country to visit, just a little further away. And it didn’t cost us anything extra. 
We were not completely uninterested in culture, but this was our first holiday without parents, like many other Inter-Rail travelers. We planned our own schedule and focused on the sights we could see easily. This was a chance to avoid guided tours and do something different. I was proud that in many places, all I wanted to see was the view from the train station. We were just trying to enjoy ourselves, like most other Inter-Railers who shared the train corridors, food, water, money, and music with us. 
The excitement of travel comes from arriving in a place that was just a name before. It feels like the city didn’t exist until the train arrives, and you see it with your own tired eyes for the first time. Only by seeing Europe, watching the changing landscapes, and noticing different lifestyles can you really understand the continent. Everyone knows what is there, but it means nothing until you see it yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos can be boring. While the train trip may not let you discover new things in the world, it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is big, and Inter-Rail gives people a great chance to see this, even if it didn’t happen for us right away."

'There is nothing more disappointing than arriving at an airport in another country and finding out that your luggage has been left behind. At best, you will have to wear the clothes you have on for hours or days until the airline brings your luggage to you. At worst, you may be in a different climate, far from home, and have to wear clothes that are not suitable. Although airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, it is a fact that regular travelers will eventually be separated from their luggage. Even the best airlines make mistakes sometimes, and it is impossible for any airline to guarantee that your checked luggage will travel on the same flight, especially when you have to change planes. 
The system works like this: Airlines ask passengers to check in early, which means arriving at the airport a certain time before the flight. This is to give enough time for the luggage to go through the airport and be loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest time needed to change from one flight to another. These times are also longer to help with luggage transfers. Usually, the system works well. But extra security checks and air traffic problems can cause flights to be delayed. All of this can lead to problems with the luggage system. There is also the chance of human error, like if the label on your bag gets torn off. These issues can be worse at large airports, called 'hubs', because many bags are processed there. 
For example, last year, London’s Heathrow airport had more than 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, most of whom had to walk one mile between Terminal 1 (for Domestic and European flights) and Terminal 4 (for long-distance flights). Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich can have bad days. The risk of losing luggage when changing planes is higher at some airports. The United States also has issues; Miami airport is known for losing luggage when transatlantic passengers connect to flights in Latin America. 
To avoid losing your luggage, choose direct flights whenever you can and check in early. If you must change planes, try to fly with the same airline. Allow more time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and make sure to label your luggage inside and outside with your home and holiday addresses. Don’t forget to include your flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.'

The Kingfisher**
Wildlife photographer Charlie James is an expert on the kingfisher, a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and eats fish. Old trees hang over the stream, providing some shade to the shallow water. The main colors in this scene are soft greens, browns, and different shades of yellow from the sunlight. The sound of the water is gentle, like a breeze. The kingfisher moves quickly and smoothly, like a flash of light. It is gone in a moment, but its image stays in your mind, powerful for such a small bird.
Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers when he was young. He feels a strong connection to this little bird, but he cannot explain why. The kingfisher is part of many legends. In Greek mythology, the kingfisher is a moon goddess who became a bird. Another story says that the kingfisher flew so high that its upper body became blue like the sky, while its lower body was burned by the sun. There is some truth in this story. Kingfishers do not have blue pigment in their feathers. Instead, the way their feathers are structured scatters light and reflects blue. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or rich emerald green, depending on the angle of the light.
It is no surprise that many wildlife photographers love kingfishers. The beautiful colors and the fact that kingfishers are shy but can be watched from a distance make them very interesting. Charlie James's first hideout was an old blanket he put over his head while he waited near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird came back within minutes and sat just one meter away. However, it took him four more years to take his first good picture. During this time, the European kingfisher became a big part of his life. He spent as much time as he could by a stream where kingfishers lived. Unfortunately, school took away some of his time with the birds, and he missed classes, calling himself an "academic failure." But people started to notice his interest in the kingfisher, which is the most common kingfisher in the world and the only one that breeds in Europe. 
At 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine. He then worked as an assistant to the editor and eventually became a freelance wildlife film cameraman. Now, he wants to make the perfect kingfisher film. "No speech, just beautiful images that say it all," he says. "I like to photograph parts of kingfisher wings..." His voice trails off as he thinks about the colors of the bird he has spent more than half his life observing, which still fascinates him. His photographs express some of his feelings, but Charlie knows that there is much more to his relationship with the kingfisher than his work can show.

Conducting an Orchestra**
Giving directions to an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work.
**A. ANNE MANSON**  
Anne Manson, 30, asked if she could watch conductor Claudio Abbado's practice sessions in Vienna. She ended up filling in for an absent assistant. Later, she was asked to help with another opera the next season. "I had to lead the first rehearsal for Abbado. No, I wasn't nervous. I have always felt good about standing in front of an orchestra." Manson, who is from America, works with a well-known opera company in London that focuses on modern music. She is also becoming known in other European countries, thanks to support from the British Arts Council. Since that first time, she has helped Abbado on several more projects.
**B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE**
