The hardest part of being a conductor is finding the right opportunities, says Andrew Constantine, 31. He won a big competition in 1991 after trying twice before. Looking back, he is thankful for the timing: "If it had happened earlier, I would have been forgotten." The competition gave him many chances to perform and a time as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, Constantine finds it hard to shake off the "competition" label: "If in three years my name is still linked to the competition, I will be worried," he says. "But orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra, who hired me after the competition, are now inviting me back. If this doesn't happen, my career will slowly fall apart."
**C. WASFI KANI**  
Wasfi Kani, who started Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long practice time needed for any opera production. "The music deserves four weeks of attention," says Kani, who began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. Starting lessons with Sian Edwards was a key moment for her. "I saw her conduct and realized she was the same size as me. I had always been taught by much bigger people, which makes a big difference." She likes the complex nature of opera: "There are many arguments, and you have to think about the singers' personalities."
**D. ROGER VIGNOLES**  
"Conducting surprised me, but it is very interesting," says Roger Vignoles, 48. It is not such a strange career move for him. He started as a musician in an opera house and worked with good conductors. Last year, he was asked to direct Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival, something he had never done before. "It was easier than I thought. I knew the music well and what I wanted it to sound like. I tried my best to get the performance I wanted. Luckily, people respect my skills as a musician. I am learning from every experience I have had, both in musical style and in performing. Now, I will do whatever people ask me to find out what I enjoy."
**E. WAYNE MARSHALL**  
In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed a young assistant conductor during one of his productions and told his agent about Wayne Marshall. Now 32, Marshall soon found himself conducting a musical in London at short notice, which was a tough start. He even had to deal with some relaxed professional musicians reading newspapers during the show: "I was strict with them. I always gave a clear beat and did my best. Many orchestral musicians I have seen do not seem to need advice from a conductor. But I am never afraid to say what I want. If people see you are worried, it gets worse. I have never studied conducting formally, and no book teaches you how to conduct, but people have been kind to me. I am determined and know what I like."

**Variations on a Theme**
If you are thinking about taking children to a theme park, there are many to choose from in Britain. We asked five families to try out some of the best parks.
**Fun Island - The Burns Family**  
Last year, we visited a big theme park in the US and thought Fun Island would be boring in comparison. However, we were surprised. The park is good for younger children, so our three-year-old felt included. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older children, there are scarier rides, like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were ready to leave, but the children wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park could have a better atmosphere, and the scenery was not very nice. But the staff were very helpful, and we found it clean, well-organized, and safe.
**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**  
None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn’t know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and especially liked Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings. The older children liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road. We spent six hours there and were happy that there were places to relax. The park is beautifully designed, and the staff were friendly and helpful. There is something for everyone, including adults.
**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**  
After seven hours, we felt there was still a lot to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus, which had a great trapeze act. We went on the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared and kept their eyes shut, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you will get wet, but you don’t. For younger children, Toy Land is a lot of fun. The children looked at the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were relieved when they found out they were too small to go on it! The park is so well designed that even waiting in line for rides is not too boring. It is very clean, and the staff are wonderful. On one ride, I couldn’t sit with both girls, so a staff member offered to go with one of them.
**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**  
We arrived at one o'clock and were disappointed that the park was only open until 5 p.m. This is a great theme park for younger children because the rides are not too scary. I am a bit of a coward, but I still had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slowly and then becomes very exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and then it was over quickly! I wouldn’t go on the Big Leap, but if you are brave, it looked fun. If the children had been a little older, they might have found it a bit boring, but they were the right age and loved it.
**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**  
According to the park's advertising, there is "No Limit to the Fun," and we felt that was true. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is very impressive, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride, while Jennie said the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older children went on several times. Sarah was too small for some rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. We found the staff's attitudes were mixed. Some were great with younger children, but the welcome was not always friendly. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldn’t have dared tell the kids we were going home early.

**Running a Business in the Countryside**
Five women share their experiences of starting a business in the countryside.
A. "My customers are friends," says CHRISTINE HOGAN, who runs a computer design business that makes over £200,000 a year and has four full-time employees. "My husband and I moved from London to the countryside when our children were small. I wanted a job I could do at home. I had worked with computers before I got married, so my husband suggested I start a computer design business. It needed a lot of money, and things were hard at first. But I was careful and told the bank manager if I might spend too much. Working from home saves money, and I can work in the evening if I want. It has stayed a small business. We hardly ever deliver work; people from the area usually come to pick it up."
B. "I enjoy being independent," says MAGGY SASANOW, who designs greeting cards from home. "I studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum. But when I got married, we moved to the countryside, where there were no jobs like that. So, I decided to start my own business and now I make 50 different greeting cards that I sell to museums. I work in a big room upstairs. The downside of working from home is that there is always something to do, like mowing the lawn. I get all my customers by word of mouth; I don’t advertise. People send work from London because I am cheaper than other artists. Working alone means I don’t share ideas with others, but there are more good things than bad."
C. "It has been hard at times," says DELIA TURNER, who makes curtains. "I started my business eight years ago. At that time, this type of business was growing, and in two years my income went from £24,000 to £80,000. I used to have six full-time curtain-makers. But I had to let them go because the economy got worse, which was hard because it is not easy to find other jobs here. Now, I am back to making curtains at home with my husband’s help and using women who work from their homes. I have to be ready to lower my prices when needed and look for new opportunities."
D. TESSA STRICKLAND runs her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. "I moved to the countryside three years ago for two reasons. First, it was cheaper than London, and second, I love the countryside. I like being able to work when I want. Eighty percent of my income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so I have to take calls at strange hours. The downside is that I need to be disciplined to close the office door. I publish children's books from different cultures, working with authors and artists. I had all my professional experience in London, so I felt very alone at first."
E. MEG RIVERS runs a cake delivery business and a shop that makes £250,000 a year and employs six people, some part-time. "I started ten years ago at home. I am very interested in health, so I began making fruit cakes with good quality flour and eggs. Then I got requests from friends and family, and soon I was sending cakes all over the country. Seven years ago, I rented a small building where everything is made. We have a baker, an assistant, and a professional cake decorator. I don’t bake anymore; I manage the business side. My biggest problem has been the financial side, which has been hard because we didn’t have a lot of money to start."

Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**
The Watkins family is very talented in music. The sons are composers and musicians who have won awards, while their dad makes musical instruments. 
John and Hetty Watkins are schoolteachers from South Wales. When they needed to buy a cello for their ten-year-old son, Paul, they found it was very expensive. John thought, "Maybe I can make one." He discovered the Welsh School of Instrument Making nearby and took evening classes for about three years. 
After trying to make violins and violas, John made his first cello. Paul, now 28, says, "It turned out really well. He made me another one later, and I used it until a few months ago." John has now retired from teaching and makes about twelve violins each year. He was very happy to sell one to the famous American musician Jaime Laredo.
Paul and his younger brother, Huw, started playing music when they were young. Paul remembers, "I began playing the piano as soon as I could reach the keys." He later wanted to play the cello. His parents wanted him to play the violin because their dad played the viola in a group. Paul tried the violin for six weeks but did not like it. He was inspired by the cellist in his dad's group and started taking lessons.
Huw, now 22, says, "My parents were supportive and relaxed. I wanted to follow in Paul's footsteps, not feel pressured." Huw is now becoming a pianist and composer.
Paul has done very well with the cello his dad made. He won the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition. At just 20 years old, he became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, using his father's cello until last year. Now, he plays a Francesco Rugeri cello, which is on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. 
Paul says, "Dad hasn't said anything about my new cello, but he played both and admitted mine is quite nice!" He believes his father's cello will get better with age, just like his Rugeri, which is already 304 years old.
Soon, Paul will perform on television with the Rugeri cello in Elgar's Cello Concerto. He says, "The history of the piece doesn’t change how I play it. I will always do it my way." However, Paul cannot watch himself on TV because he is performing at the Cheltenham Festival that same night. Huw's String Quartet will also have its London premiere at the Wigmore Hall that evening. John and Hetty will have to be very organized to keep up with all their sons' music events in the coming weeks.

**Looking after the Countryside: The National Trust**
The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden who works for the Trust to care for the beautiful areas it owns.
Gareth believes that a National Trust Warden needs common sense. "You also need to be good at dealing with people," he says, "because you are always working with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and building companies." Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people wanted the job of National Trust Warden for the Lleyn Peninsula. In the end, Gareth got the job because of his local knowledge and farming experience, even though he did not have formal training.
"I find it helpful that I still farm with my parents," he explains. "I can talk to farmers as equals and understand their problems. They can't trick me!" His farming background also helps him with the physical work of the job, like putting up fences, planting trees, and building walls. Since he started working with the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. "When I was young," he remembers, "I used to pick flowers, collect butterfly larvae, and find old birds' nests. I recently thought about where I would find those flowers and nests now. I see that farming has changed the countryside. It's not the farmers' fault; they were just following what the government told them."
Gareth says that when he began his job, farmers and conservationists did not get along. Both sides wanted things done their way. Now they are talking and understanding each other better. "We are at a point where we can bring them together," Gareth says.
Conservation is a big part of Gareth's work, along with allowing the public to visit the Trust's land, planting trees, and meeting the Trust's tenant farmers. "My job is to make sure tasks are completed with as little trouble and cost as possible. What I enjoy most is seeing projects finished, even though I spend about half my time on reports and paperwork."
Gareth loves his job and enjoys every moment, especially talking to the public. However, he admits, "I dislike the attitude of some people. They come into the area, demand everything, and then leave as if they have a right to do so. Being nice to those people can be frustrating!" But as Gareth says, it all comes down to common sense. If you have plenty of that and like the idea of working outdoors, you might consider applying to be a warden like Gareth. Just don't expect a job to be available on the Lleyn Peninsula for a long time!

**The Netball Captain**
In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day, teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I focus on my movements and my feet, so I don’t notice much else. I might see cars slow down a little, but that’s it."
Kendra said, "My whole life is about being my best for the Championships." She is following a strict schedule to be as fit as possible. This is her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries participating. "We will have home support, which is very special," she said. "It’s important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure. The crowd will have expectations and support us more. People want us to start the tournament with a good game."
Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra mentioned, "We have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play against. They have a lot of talent." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra knows the Championships will be tough. "You have to push yourself to play every day. There is no rest between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different. You only have one chance, and you must be ready."
In the fifteen years she has played at a high level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. Kendra said, "You don’t train hard to lose. But after the final whistle, we become friends again."
Netball is also using more science for fitness testing. Kendra said, "It is important that we think and train like world-class players. As captain, I need to have a strong mindset and lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging my team."
Kendra explained, "From the start of my netball career, I have planned everything carefully. I decided a while ago that this competition would be my last as a player." She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**
How can parents help a child who has great musical talent? It can be hard to know the best way to support their gift. Some parents may not see their child's needs until the child becomes frustrated and acts out. While most schools can help children who are good at academic subjects, musically talented children need special support that may not be available in regular schools, especially if music is not seen as important.
Children who are musically gifted, and those whose talents are encouraged by their parents or teachers, may benefit from attending a specialist music school. There are five music schools in Britain, and they have been created recently. These schools provide a caring environment for gifted children aged seven to eighteen to develop their musical skills with the help of professional musicians.
At specialist music schools, children spend about one third to one half of their day on music activities. This includes individual lessons (up to three hours a week for their first and second instruments), playing in orchestras, chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and music theory. They also practice in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on a limited academic program that focuses on important subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages. Students can also study more subjects if they want.
All five British specialist music schools are independent, meaning they are not funded by the government. Classes are small, with a high number of teachers compared to students. Most children at these schools live there full-time, which means they eat and sleep at school. This allows them to spend their formative years with others who share their interests.
What are the downsides? One major issue is the cost; fees can be high (between £12,000 and £17,000 a year for boarders). However, each school tries to help parents of talented children with scholarships and financial aid. Also, not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many directors of specialist schools have concerns about admitting children as young as seven into such a strict environment. They emphasize that their main goal is to help children become well-rounded individuals.
It is clear that separating musically gifted children from a young age can cause stress. Some early signs of musical talent may fade during the teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to feelings of failure. However, all specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and provide help when needed.
Most former students of music schools feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music teaching, but many worry about the limited academic program, which often comes second to music. Many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and can handle academic challenges. They may feel frustrated if their academic needs are not met.
For these reasons, it might be better to wait until a child is older and can make their own choices before considering a specialist music education. Children who are also academically gifted can do well in a regular school with a good music program or by combining a normal school schedule with music training at junior departments of music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with excellent teachers, as well as orchestral and chamber music experiences. However, this option may not be possible for families living far from London or other major cities.

An Eye for Detail**
Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. The large garden around her house gives her many ideas for her art. It is full of her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread all over the garden. The two long flower borders along the path in the garden have a beautiful mix of colors and shapes. This is partly because the previous owners were good gardeners and left plants that Susan liked. She also kept the gardener, Danny. "In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along very well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' for some of the things I wanted to add, but when I said I wanted to paint them, he understood what I meant."
Susan likes to focus on painting individual plants instead of the whole garden. Sometimes, she paints a group of plants, but usually, she picks one flower and takes it to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which might take a few days. Then I bring in another one and build up the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."
Her busiest time is spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all come out together, and you're so busy," she says. But she also finds beauty in how flowers change as they decay. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for a day, and they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, you think they are boring, but they change all the time."
Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and used to collect wildflowers from the countryside," she says. "I wasn't really interested in gardening then; I didn't like garden flowers because they looked like fake ones sold in some shops. To me, the only real flowers were wild ones. I was fascinated by how they could grow in difficult places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs."
Today, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they seem to fit in well. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, like a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause too much trouble. With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of subjects to paint right outside her door, it has been hard for her to find time to work in the garden. She now hires an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected with her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**
Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl who works hard to keep holiday-makers happy. She tells Veronica Lee about her job. This is Sarah's second year as a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and comes from West Sussex, England. Sarah works for a company in Val d'Isère, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets.
Sarah graduated from Oxford Brookes University last summer, where she studied French and History of Art. She thinks being a chalet girl is not a long-term career, but a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a different job. "It's a good way to meet people," she says. "I meet successful people every week."
Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can sleep up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before making breakfast for the guests. "They get a full breakfast - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants." After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either makes afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she says is "the worst part of the job." By about 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. "On a good day, we can ski until 4:30 p.m."
Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower before cooking but does not sleep because she says, "It's bad if you do." Dinner is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, Sarah cleans the kitchen. "There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning." Sometimes she talks with the guests, but other times they prefer to be alone. "Good guests can make a week great - breakfast this morning was fun - but some weeks are not as good."
Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives, and they go out around 11 p.m. "We usually start at Bananas, then go to G Jay's and maybe Dick's T-Bar at the end of the night," she says. But Sarah does not stay out too late on Saturday night because Sunday is her busiest day. "It's a hard day," she says, "when you don’t want to cook breakfast feeling tired."
On Sunday, work starts earlier than usual. Breakfast for guests must be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, Sarah cleans quickly. "We clean everything - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, and get ready for the new guests." If she has not done the shopping on Saturday, she does it now. Around 3 p.m., after cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for the new guests. "They arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are confused and have many questions. I think the mountain air affects them."
Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need boots or skis and then gets a lift back to the chalet. Soon, it is time for dinner again, and sometimes she chats with friends, but not always. "Sometimes I'm so tired I just go to bed early," she says.

Changing Lives with a Stranger**
Mandie Currie is a zoo-keeper. She spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing what to wear was hard because I usually wear a uniform at the zoo. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is a calm place, but here I was rushing around when I could be quietly cuddling an animal. Some people on the fashion team seemed stressed, but my job is not very stressful. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed because I usually clean cages or handle rats. I find it interesting to see how magazines work, but I really enjoy my job at the zoo, so I will stay there."
Alice Cutler is a fashion assistant at Marie Claire. She spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived at the zoo in my leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to wear, which was good because I got very dirty. While I stroked an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I smelled bad, but I had a great day. When I retire from fashion, I could see myself working with elephants, maybe in Africa."
Karen Hodson is a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital. She worked with the television gardening program Ground Force. "I was very excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was really nice. I liked being outside because I sometimes don’t see daylight at work. Even though it was hard work, it was fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. I didn’t expect gardening to be so hard or need so much planning. I am more enthusiastic than effective, so I don’t plan to quit my nursing job."
Charlie Dimmock is a landscape gardener on Ground Force. He worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and handed out medicine. I thought I would faint during some tasks, but I surprised myself and felt fine. The friendship among the nurses is great, and it felt very different from my usual male work environment. I think my job is not as important as nursing. My day at the hospital was not easy, but it made me feel satisfied."
Lucy Harvey is a personal trainer. She spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and when I put it on, I felt different—people looked at me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone has a heart attack, which I knew from my training. When the passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I handed out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt nervous. On the return flight, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn’t sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult."
Sonia McDermott is an air hostess with Ryanair. She spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was worried about this swap because I don’t exercise. I was surprised by how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. At lunch, I saw that some trainers didn’t eat very healthily, but they all drink a lot of water. I wouldn’t change my job for this, but it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier."

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Memories**
**A. Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There is a local train from Cannes that goes along the coast and crosses the border into Italy. It takes you past some beautiful sea views. It doesn’t matter what the weather is like or what time of year it is; the journey is always magical. Out of the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and homes in France. It feels like you are looking into the lives of the rich and famous. The other passengers are always lively because there is a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the amazing journey.
**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have had many great train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which travels across the desert in northern Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. I was sent to stay with my aunt instead. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn’t traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real train station I ever saw, and its big glass roof amazed me.
**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I am very grateful to one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I thought was wonderful. Someone said that pink is good for the brain, and I have worn it ever since. What I remember most about the journey is how lovely it was to travel through France and then by boat up the Nile. It was the perfect way to relax after all the wedding plans.
**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on articles about a trip around the world and had to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the train known as the Desert Express. The schedule was not reliable; we were just told to be ready on a certain day. We heard that the driver would often wait for days if he knew people were still coming. When the train arrived, many people rushed to get on, and some even traveled on the roof for free. During the night, the train passed through some of the most beautiful landscapes I have ever seen. It felt like a dream, like traveling on the moon.
**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
I think most people have favorite memories of trains from when they were children, but that is not true for me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains and didn’t travel on them. It wasn’t until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film that featured a railway in Yorkshire. Most of the filming was done on an old part of the line that volunteers had taken care of. That’s where my love for steam trains started. When we weren’t filming, we took every chance to ride the train, and when I went back last year, it felt like time had stopped. Everything was still the same, even the gas lights on the station platform!

'Want to Get Published?**
If you want to publish your story, our expert Margaret Stubbs has some advice for you. Many readers of this magazine ask, "I have written a story/book. Where should I send it?" One of the first things they need to do is research publishers and improve their writing skills. Turning your writing into something that can be sold requires knowledge about the publishing world. 
No matter what you write, you need to understand the markets you want to reach. The best way to do this is by reading as much as you can. Visit your local library and check out local bookstores and newsagents. Reading widely will help you understand what types of writing publishers are accepting right now. 
This knowledge needs to be updated because new publications come out all the time. Editors change jobs, and magazines change their focus. Publishers are always looking for new writers, so you need to give them what they want. 
At first, you might not know what you want to write. For example, if you think you want to write short love stories, the first step is to find out which magazines publish love stories. This market is quite small these days, so get as many recent copies of those magazines as you can. Learn about the types of stories they buy and who their readers are. These readers expect different things, and the editor wants to meet their needs. 
Writers often ask me, "This has been rejected three times - am I wasting my time? Do I have a chance?" As a former teacher, I never want to discourage anyone. However, it is likely that the work is not ready for publication. Many new writers are too eager to send their work out before they are ready. If you have only written one story or article, it is very unlikely to be published. This almost never happens. 
When you read about someone’s success, you often find that they have been in publishing or journalism for years before they became successful. When you finally send out your work for the first time, keep writing while you wait for a reply. Write ten more stories, or even twenty. Each one will be better than the last, and you will start to see yourself as a writer. This will help you become more confident and fluent. 
Don’t throw any of your stories away; instead, try to improve them. I also suggest not showing your work to others, especially in the beginning. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections before they succeeded. 
Do everything you can to improve your writing career. Look for a creative writing course near you. If you can’t find one, consider joining a local writers' group. This will help you gain ideas and confidence by meeting other writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.'

No Title**
On the last day of a bad year, I was leaning against a pillar in the Baltimore train station, waiting for the 10:10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people waiting than I expected. The station did not feel as nice as it usually did. Older couples with matching bags filled the benches, and many college students had left their bags on the floor. A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to different strangers. He looked well-off: he had tanned skin, a nice sweater, and a soft beige coat. He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. Then he came over to a girl near me. She had long blond hair, and I thought I would like to talk to her too. The man asked, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" 
"Well, I'm going north," she replied. "But I'm going to New York." 
"Thanks, anyway," he said, and moved to the next bench. Now I was really paying attention. He asked an old lady, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" When she said she was going to Wilmington, he just walked on to a couple with matching bags. I stood up from my pillar and moved closer, pretending to look at the platform. I was going to Philadelphia. He could have asked me. I understood why he didn’t; he probably thought I looked unreliable. He glanced at me quickly and then went to the other end of the waiting area. He looked very stressed now. 
"Please!" he said to a woman reading a book. "Tell me you're going to Philadelphia!" She looked up from her book. She was about thirty-five years old, older than me. She looked like a school teacher. 
"Philadelphia?" she said. "Yes, I am." 
"Could I ask you a favor?" I stood a few feet away and looked at my wrist, even though I didn’t have a watch. I could tell she was becoming cautious. The man must have noticed too because he said, "Nothing too difficult, I promise!" They were announcing my train now. People started moving toward Gate E, older couples pulling their wheeled bags behind them. 
Then I heard the man talking. "My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, stopped for groceries, and came home to find my wife upset. She hardly said 'hello' to me. My daughter forgot her passport. She called from the station in Philadelphia and didn’t know what to do." 
The woman nodded sympathetically. I would have stayed quiet and waited to see where this was going. 
"So I told her to stay put. I said I would get someone to bring her passport." 
I thought this was a strange story. Why didn’t he go himself if it was such an emergency? 
"Why don’t you go yourself?" the woman asked. 
"I can’t leave my wife alone for that long. She’s in a wheelchair." 
I thought this was a weak excuse. It seemed like too much bad luck for one family. I looked at them. The man was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, but a padded envelope the size of a small book. Aha! Padded! So you couldn’t feel what was inside! From where I stood, it looked stapled shut too. Be careful, lady, I thought silently.

'Gary and Me'**
John Moore, the owner of a restaurant, talks about his relationship with his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef. He believes everyone gets a chance in life. Gary had his chance with cooking, and John had his chance to run a restaurant. When John heard about a restaurant for sale, he quickly went to see it. The place was in bad condition, but it was perfect for his plans. 
Running the restaurant reminded John of his childhood. He remembers being sad when his mother went to work in a factory and left him alone. Because of this, he wanted to have time for family. His wife took care of their children and managed the accounts while John ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always made time to eat together as a family. This helped their children, Gary and Joe, become confident. From a young age, they would talk to the regular customers, which gave them a good start in life.
Gary was a lively child. When he was about seven, he jumped into a corner bath like it was a swimming pool and hurt himself. As he grew older, he had to earn pocket money. He started with small jobs and by age ten, he was working in the kitchen every weekend, which gave him plenty of money at school. He was disciplined and often woke up before his father. In a family business, everyone helps out, and John liked seeing Gary work.
Gary was not very good at school, but he was great in the kitchen. By age 15, he was as skilled as the adult chefs and sometimes even managed the kitchen. He could cook over a hundred meals, and John knew Gary would work in catering because he had talent. When Gary needed work experience for school, John sent him to a friend’s restaurant.
Recently, Gary started playing the drums and formed his own band. John wonders what will happen to Gary’s cooking if his music career takes off. He advised Gary to focus on one thing at a time to be successful. John told him, “If you want to achieve something, you need to do it by age 30. After that, it’s harder.” 
At 17, Gary went to catering college. On his first day, while other students were just starting, Gary quickly chopped vegetables and sliced meats. He finished his work in an hour and even helped others. Everyone is amazed at how successful Gary’s TV cooking show has become. John is very proud of him. He always tells Gary that if you want something, you must work hard for it because nothing is given for free. Gary has seen his chance and taken it.
As children grow up, parents hope they listen to their advice. John thinks that if Gary remembers even a little of what he has said, it is a good thing. He sees that Gary listens sometimes by the things he says and does.

Finding a Flat in Dublin**
Finding a good flat in Dublin that you can afford is very hard. The best way to find one is through personal contacts. If you know someone who knows someone who is leaving, that can help. But if, like Jo, you just arrived in Dublin, you don’t have any contacts. You have to stay in a hostel and look for a flat. For Jo, Dublin felt very new and unknown. She didn’t think about why she was going there. Everyone at her school thought she would leave her small town. They wanted to escape and see more of life. Some of her classmates went to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family members helped them settle in. But Jo was going to Dublin alone.
Jo’s mother thought it would be good for her to stay in the hostel forever. It was run by nuns, so her mother believed she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm because they are often cold. Jo’s sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy for staying in a hostel for a whole week. But Jo didn’t know they were still talking about her while she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was very close to her job at the post office and seemed too good to be true. Jo hoped it would be nice and that the people would like her, and that it wouldn’t be too expensive.
There wasn’t a line for this flat because it was more about needing a third girl than just renting a flat. The mention of "own television" made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked normal. It was a simple red-brick house with a basement. The flat was upstairs. As Jo climbed the stairs, a cheerful girl with a college scarf came down. "Desperate place," she said to Jo. "They’re both awful. Common as dirt."
"Oh," said Jo and continued up. "Hello," said the girl with "Nessa" on her T-shirt. "Did you see that stuck-up girl leaving? I can’t stand her kind." 
"What did she do?" Jo asked. 
"She didn’t do anything. She just looked around and giggled, saying, 'Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear,' in a posh voice. We wouldn’t want her here, would we, Pauline?" 
Pauline, who had bright, colorful clothes, looked very different. Jo was surprised to meet a punk. She had seen them on the street but never talked to one before. 
"I’m Jo, I work at the post office and I called about the flat," Jo said. 
Nessa said they were about to have tea. She got three mugs: one with "Nessa," one with "Pauline," and one with "Other." "We’ll put your name on a mug if you come to stay," she said kindly.

Behind the Dolphin's Smile**
People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them in seaside areas, movies, and TV shows. However, according to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, dolphins are in trouble. Mark Simmonds talks about the decline of dolphin species.
Dolphins are special to us. They are very intelligent, sensitive to human feelings, and they make us dream of freedom in the ocean. Our love for dolphins has been supported by TV shows. First, there was Flipper, and now there is Darwin from Seaquest. But these happy images hide the real problems dolphins face in polluted and overfished seas.
The number of North Sea harbour porpoises (a type of dolphin) has dropped by up to 89,000. You might think that such popular animals would be protected by law and cared for in special marine areas. Unfortunately, this is not true, and the lack of protection could lead to a major wildlife disaster.
There are forty different types of dolphins in the world. In northern Europe, the most common dolphins are the striped dolphin, the common dolphin, the bottlenose dolphin, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The striped and common dolphins usually live far out in the open sea and are seen in small groups. We know very little about them. 
Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be seen near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and were often found along the Channel coast and in rivers in Britain, like the Thames. Now, they can only be found in a few places, like the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few that are left show signs of stress.
It is hard to know exactly why dolphin numbers are decreasing. Overfishing is reducing fish populations and harming local fishing industries, which also affects dolphins and porpoises. Porpoises need to find food quickly, and if fish are removed from one area, they may not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. They can also get caught in fishermen's nets, which they cannot see. 
In modern fishing, large nets are often left in the water or pulled quickly through the sea. Recently, many dead dolphins have washed up on the beaches of France and Cornwall. Marks and cuts on their bodies show that they died because they were caught in these nets.
Pollution in the sea can also harm dolphins. For example, pesticides can build up in their bodies. Female dolphins produce milk that can contain these poisons, which can harm their young. There has been at least one case of a young dolphin dying from its mother’s milk.
Another serious threat to dolphins is noise pollution caused by humans. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to understand their environment. In the sea, noise travels much better than in the air, which may disturb dolphins in ways we do not fully understand.

**GETTING FIT**
Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It is one of the best ways to feel balanced, especially when life feels chaotic. You might be tired of reading about fitness, but there are many good reasons to exercise, and very few reasons not to.
Exercise helps improve your muscle tone and can change your body shape quickly. It makes your muscles stronger and helps you stand and sit better. It can also prevent muscle imbalances that might cause injuries. Exercise can quickly improve areas like your thighs, stomach, and upper arms. It is good for your heart, lungs, and blood circulation.
You may have heard these reasons many times, but here’s something new: exercise can help reduce feelings of depression and tiredness, and it can help you sleep better. It also helps manage stress and can relieve some health problems. 
If you are not convinced yet, just think about it: exercise is good for you. There are many types of exercise you can try, such as aerobics, jogging, or using weights. However, be careful not to train too hard or lift too much weight, as this can cause injuries. If you are unsure about what is best for you, talk to your doctor.
Good posture is also very important. No amount of exercise will help your body shape if you do not have good posture. Good posture makes you look and feel better. If you tend to slouch, imagine that a balloon is pulling the top of your head up. This can help you lift your chest and breathe better, while also making your body look slimmer.
Stretching your muscles is important too. It helps you move easily and keeps your posture correct. Stretching can prevent injuries from overuse. If you stretch four or five times a week, you will have a more flexible and fit body. 
Your exercise routine should include a warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**
What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman stay away from home for many months? They are looking for the perfect shot. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, it is not easy to find producer Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman. Right now, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has had six months of almost continuous rain. This has caused many problems. Newman said they had to buy an expensive piece of equipment so that if one of their vehicles gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him back to safety. Their teamwork has created some of the best wildlife films on TV, like their popular film about leopards. While this film was being shown, they were already back in the field, this time following the shy jackal.
Traveling film-makers have been moving around the world to film exotic wildlife since television began. I spoke to Newman during one of his rare meetings with other people at a safari lodge. He said, "We do have occasional arguments, but we get over them quickly." Neither of them sees themselves as the leader. They get along well because they both understand the animals in a similar way. 
"When we are on the move, we have to set up our tents each night. But this time we have a more fixed camp. We set out at 5 a.m. each morning, so we make tea the night before and keep it warm in a flask." Their daily meals are pre-packed and heated by whoever is available. "We can be out for up to eight weeks at a time, so cooking can be a bit stressful," says Newman. It can be a tough life, but being in remote areas allows them to get close to the animals. Newman remembers filming a family of lions, where one lioness would often go off alone. When she returned, she would greet all the other lions and even came to greet their car.
Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift." Two years later, they began working together to film Arctic foxes. Since then, they have learned to spend four months in one location to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before they can start filming, they must submit a script for approval. "Amanda and I had a good working relationship from the start," says Newman. "We shared the same ideas and vision. We want to create a film that shows the true spirit of the place and the animals, and that touches people's hearts. I believe if you can make people feel something, that is better than just making them think."

**The Netball Captain**
In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day, teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I was surprised to hear about her training place. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I focus on my movements and my feet, so I don’t notice much else. I might see cars slow down a little, but that’s all."
Kendra said, "My whole life is about being my best for the Championships." She follows a strict schedule to be as fit as possible. This is her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries taking part. "We will have home support, which is very special," she said. "It is important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure. The crowd will have expectations and support us more. People want us to start the tournament with a good game."
Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra believes they have always won against them, but it will still be exciting to play because they are a strong team. The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra knows the World Championships will be tough. "You have to push yourself to play every day. There is no rest between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different. You only have one chance, and you must be ready."
In the fifteen years Kendra has played at a high level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. "You don’t train hard to lose," Kendra says. "But after the game, we are all friends."
Netball is also using more science for fitness testing. "It is important that we think and train like world-class players," Kendra explains. As captain, she believes it is important to have a strong mindset and lead by example. "I see my role as supporting and encouraging the team."
Kendra says, "From the start of my netball career, I have planned carefully." She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She will likely coach young players in the future, but right now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have tears in her eyes. Her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.

In Hot Water**
Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemicals in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle, about the size of a car, and dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.
"Inside," she says, "the space is so small that I can touch the two pilots. They are used to these conditions, which means we can't stand up or move around, and we must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up to the surface."
"If something goes wrong and we need to get to the top quickly, we can hit a panic button. The outside drops away, and a small escape vessel is released. It goes quickly to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in a bath. No one has tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a pleasant trip."
"I didn't know how I would feel the first time I got into the vehicle. It was on a ship, and I got in with an instructor. He explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack! They were testing how I would react in such a small space." 
Now Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. "We went to a place that was a five-day sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. Here, on the ocean floor, there is a large area of underwater volcanoes, with their chimneys blowing out black smoke. This is where the Atlantic Ocean comes alive. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study a project that would make a hole 150 meters through a volcano."
When she is not at sea, Rachel is in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research on the 'black smokers.' This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. This flows out at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees."
"The only time I was scared was when I first went down with the Americans. We were towing equipment on a 50-meter rope when suddenly there was an explosion. There was a huge bang as the shock waves hit our vehicle, and I thought, 'I'm going to die.' We looked at each other in silence, waiting. When nothing happened, we couldn't believe it. The relief was incredible - we were still alive!"
"Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is such an adventure. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, I feel amazed. Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before. I studied the black smokers for three years for my Ph.D. When I got down there and saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling."

**Interview Tips**
First impressions are very important. Studies show that people form opinions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body movements, and how fast or slow we talk, as well as our voice and the words we use.
Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She worked hard to earn her degree and felt very confident when she graduated. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. On the day of the interview, she saw a small hole in her jacket. She thought about changing, but she knew it would make her late, and she believed it was important to be on time. Unfortunately, Mary did not get the job. A friend who teaches at the school told her that the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn't take the time to look their best at an interview, what kind of teacher will they be?"
Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "People who look like they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. Many think that what is inside is what matters, but in an interview, you should try to show your best side." However, many people do not understand how important a professional image is.
For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a big accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the job but did not even get an interview. She thought it was a mistake and asked the Director of Personnel what happened. He told her she did not fit the image of an office manager and suggested she improve her wardrobe before applying again. Janet was shocked because she believed she did a good job and that her clothes should not matter.
Movement and gestures also affect how an interviewer sees a candidate. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that only 7% of our message about feelings comes from the words we use, 38% comes from our voice, and 55% comes from our facial expressions. If our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will pay more attention to the non-verbal message. So, make sure your words match your body language. Mixed messages can confuse the interviewer.
It is also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. When Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion, her interview went very well, and she was offered the job right away. She was very happy but showed too much excitement. The boss realized she would not turn down the offer, so he gave her a lower salary than she wanted. Sheila believes she could have gotten more if she had controlled her excitement.
Finally, what we say and how we say it can help us succeed in an interview. David Artesio, a manager of an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. For example, the annual report can tell you about the company’s work. Mentioning something that interests you during the interview can show your interest in the company.
Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confusing sentences. She says, "Poor communicators talk in long paragraphs. Successful communicators use short sentences and clear points."

**A NEW LIFE**
**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in the business, I found that working in the City was no longer fun. I had planned to stay for another five or ten years, but then I lost my job unexpectedly. I didn’t get a great pay-off, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with one of the best restaurants in the country. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat online. I’m happy to be out of the office, but it’s surprising how little has changed: I still work 80 to 90 hours a week and sell a product."
**The Painter**  
Ron Able White was a manager in advertising, but now he makes a living as an artist. "I started painting as a hobby, but I found it much more exciting than my job. It made sense to take redundancy and become an artist. The career counselor I spoke to was very helpful. I think I was the first person to tell him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' He was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to find work quickly for money. My wife and I married young, and our children no longer need our support. It was a big change for us. We moved to the north of England, where we didn’t know anyone. We left our friends, but we have been lucky; many of them visit us now."
**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was fun and I earned a lot of money, but the hours were long. I didn’t want to become a senior partner and work even more hours, so I left. Many people said I would get bored, but that has never happened. The key is to have deadlines. In fashion, there are always collections and new designs to work on, so I have to keep a strict schedule. I feel happier now and less stressed. However, I miss socializing with colleagues. What I love about this job is that I am fully responsible for my work. If I do a bad job, I am the one to blame. When you work for a company, you care, but when your name is on the product, you care even more."
**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I worked in financial markets from the age of 22, making deals. I liked the excitement, but I never found the work satisfying. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I left and traveled for a year instead. During that year, I thought about what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited some of the best gyms and talked to the owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took courses in massage. Then I got a part-time job at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my life. That is the best part."

'Dedicated to Their Sports'**
Four young sports stars talk about their lives.
**A Darius (Runner)**  
I have always loved sports. I played many sports, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football club, but I chose to focus on athletics instead. My biggest moment was when I competed for my country in the youth team and won a medal. Unfortunately, it did not get much media attention, which was disappointing. I hoped to get some sponsorship because training is expensive. I train at home all winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It is fun because there are great facilities for athletics and the nightlife is good too. However, I have to be very disciplined. If friends invite me out the night before training, I have to say no. I wish I didn’t have to, but dedication is important in this sport. My main goal is to reach the next Olympics - that would be amazing.
**B Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so I meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are often at dawn, so I have to avoid late-night parties. I don’t mind this too much, but I love sleeping in, and I usually have to give that up too. However, it is worth it because without this dedication, I might not have won the National Championships last year. After any win, I make sure to celebrate with a big night out, and if I win money, I go somewhere nice. The sacrifices are worth it because winning that championship allowed me to present a surfing series on TV. I guess I am a bit of a celebrity now.
**C Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
When I am on a boat with my friends, we have a lot of fun. We are traditional and always celebrate our wins in style. Some people say we act a bit childishly when we celebrate, but we do not look for media attention. Sometimes, reporters seem more interested in our celebrations than in our race results. I am away for eight months a year, so it is nice to come back and spend time with my friends who do different things. You cannot live and breathe the sport all the time; it is not healthy. I am known in the sailing world, but I am rarely recognized in the street. I would not like to be a celebrity. I do get nice letters from fans asking for signed pictures, and I reply to every one, even if it takes time.
**D Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It is always exciting to walk onto the court and feel the crowd's support. At my last tournament, it got a bit crazy with many people around. I enjoy being recognized by fans when I am out shopping, but it has its downsides. My last girlfriend did not like it when I got too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that is why we broke up. It was hard, but you have to make sacrifices in any sport; you need to be serious and professional. It does not bother me too much. I am happy to focus on my game now and will catch up on other things in life after I retire, which comes early in this sport.

Young Shoppers**
Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it’s not the latest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I can’t afford all this, and if I give in to their requests, I feel guilty about buying unhealthy food. I hate saying no all the time, and I get stressed before we even leave home. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but then I worry that they are missing out on learning how to make their own choices. I feel stuck."
Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they go shopping. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising aimed at children, mostly on television. This amount is likely to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often do not understand why their parents say no to certain things, especially when they see attractive ads for sugary products. 
Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always correct. It is good for parents and children to talk about food. If children only hear about products from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they have to compete with advertising and often disappoint their children."
The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb explains, "The goal of advertising is to convince people to buy products. Even if they can’t say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."
Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to accept and which to refuse. One mother says she is patient when talking about food with her children, but she still feels bad about how she handles their requests: "My son pays attention to ads but is critical of them. We talk a lot about different products and look at labels together. I’ve talked so much that he thinks all ads are bad. Now, we have very little conflict in the supermarket because the children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."
Parents also admit they are not always consistent in their responses to their children’s requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We refuse to buy sweets for him because they are bad for him, but we buy double cream and chocolate for ourselves. It’s nice to buy good things, and it’s normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on how I feel. If I’m in a good mood, I’m more likely to say yes. It’s hard to be consistent."
Supermarkets could help reduce the conflict between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. Even if parents spend less money without their children, the idea of shopping without their kids’ demands might attract more customers.

Five-Star Luxury and Modern Technology**
The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It was created by changing four large old houses into a hotel. This process took almost two years and included a lot of research to understand what customers want. The hotel has the latest technology to help both staff and guests.
General Manager Peter MacCann wants his staff to know the guests' names. For more details about what guests like, he uses the hotel’s computer system. This system helps the hotel give special service to returning guests. Although it cost £250,000 to set up, MacCann believes it will save money in the long run. He appreciates how well it works and the services it provides. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them when they come back. This is possible because of the guest-history feature that allows staff to record guest preferences.
Many hotel guests often complain about room temperature. The Merrion has a high-tech system that lets guests control the temperature in their rooms. They can change it by three degrees around the normal temperature of 18°C. If they want, the front desk can adjust the temperature anywhere between 14°C and 25°C.
Business travelers are very important to the hotel, and MacCann estimates that about 65% of their business will come from this group. To meet their needs, the hotel has put a business center in each room. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing system.
Technology changes quickly, so the hotel has prepared for future improvements. They have installed extra cables for new technology. The televisions are rented, so they can be replaced with newer models when needed. DVD recorders can also be updated.
Even with all this modern technology, MacCann wants guests to feel comfortable, not overwhelmed. The hotel has 145 large and well-furnished bedrooms that are cozy and inviting. There is also a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a lovely garden.
The food at the hotel is very important. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This change has many benefits for both him and the hotel. He has designed a new kitchen and improved parking. The hotel can now offer a great place to eat without financial risks. With good technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is likely to be very successful.

Where I Get My Energy**
Emma Marsden asked six women how they find energy in their lives.
A. **Jeanette Kupfermann, Journalist and Author:** "I get my energy from excitement. I need to do things that challenge me. When I learn something new, I feel very energized. I also love rhythm; right now, I am learning flamenco dancing. Dance is amazing and gives me energy. If I am bored, I feel tired and think life is not worth it. Doing something useful, even in a small way, gives me energy."
B. **Linda Kelsey, Magazine Editor:** "I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it all. I love my job, so it doesn’t feel like hard work. If you like what you do, you don’t feel sad, even if you are tired. I need enough sleep, and when I get it, I feel great. If I only sleep six hours, I feel a bit weak. I know exercise gives me energy, but sometimes it’s hard to find the energy to do it! I go to a yoga class once a week and try to exercise at home. After I exercise, I feel much better. I often feel low in the afternoon, so I think it’s good to eat something then."
C. **Annie Nightingale, Disc Jockey:** "I don’t eat very healthily for energy; I think it comes from being enthusiastic and positive. I don’t like negative people. I believe we should enjoy our lives and have fun. It’s important to achieve things and set goals. I love my job, and the last two years have been very exciting. I work with many lively young people, which energizes me. I enjoy taking photos, even if I’m not the best at it. I also write words for fun songs, which helps me relax when I travel a lot."
D. **Floella Benjamin, Author and Children's TV Presenter:** "My energy comes from doing things I enjoy. I believe in what I do, both at work and at home with my family. Being positive helps a lot. I love working with kids because they are full of energy. Energy is like a natural feeling that comes from talking to others. Just smile at someone and see how good it feels when they smile back. It’s much better than feeling sad. I try to eat healthily and don’t smoke or drink, but I don’t have a strict exercise plan. I get my energy from playing with kids."
E. **Deborah Moggach, Author and Playwright:** "What I love most is creating a garden from a wasteland. I once turned a concrete area into a beautiful garden. It was better than any workout. Knowing that someone wants to read my writing gives me energy too. I enjoy sneaking into a farmer's land or a forest. If someone catches me, I say, 'Oh, what a lovely place! I didn’t know it was private.' I like this because it feels playful."
F. **Katherine Monblot, Therapist:** "I believe you should care about what you do in life. I like to take risks and get bored easily, which keeps me motivated. Doing things you don’t want to do can make you tired. I used to be part of many committees, but I didn’t like how they took my time. You only have a certain amount of energy, so use it for what matters most to you."

**ICE SKATING**
Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until iron skates were made in Scandinavia around 200 AD. For the rich people in Scandinavia, skating was an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was seen as stylish, but in the 1924 Winter Olympics, 11-year-old Sonja Henie showed a more athletic way of skating, which made it very popular.
Today, skating combines art and athletics. It is both beautiful and physically challenging. For beginners, balance and control are very important, and you can only go faster as you get better. The way you position your body is key to maintaining balance. Your legs should be slightly bent, and your knees should be relaxed to keep your weight centered. In this position, your body leans a little forward.
Relaxation is very important in skating. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. When you push forward with one foot, make a small movement with the other foot. It’s not too hard! If you can keep this up for a while, you can slowly make your movements longer as you gain experience.
Learning how to fall is one of the first skills a skater should learn. Even professional skaters fall sometimes. To fall safely, you should stay relaxed. This helps reduce the impact when you hit the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel, and then stand up.
Once you can move confidently on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance skating, speed skating, and skating in pairs. The best way to start is to learn figure skating and then basic freestyle. Most ice rinks have good teachers who can help you learn the basic moves, and soon you will be able to do turns, jumps, and spins in freestyle.
If you watch good skaters, you will see how relaxed they are and how easily they move. To achieve this, you should practice a regular exercise program. It can be dangerous to skate with a stiff body, so warm-up exercises are important. These should include exercises for your legs, back, and shoulders, especially for your ankles and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to avoid stiffness.
Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also helps your heart and lungs and makes your body stronger. When combined with swimming or jogging, it is a great way to stay healthy and fit.

**Trills and Bills**
If there is one thing that can make you cry, it is seeing a talented child winning a medal. Julia Gregson asked three young stars and their mothers to share some of the joys and challenges of their lives.
A. **Annika Reeder, 15**  
Annika won a gold medal for gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The training is very hard right now. I don’t have time to watch TV, go out with friends, or do much besides gymnastics and school. I try to take it one day at a time. When I feel very tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I just keep going. You can’t take too many days off because it makes your body stiff."
B. **Annika's Mother**  
"From a young age, Annika showed great talent. I have seen some parents push their children, but it doesn’t work. To perform at Annika's level takes a lot of time and energy, and you have to want to do it yourself. People often say that we, as parents, have given up a lot, but they don’t see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it has done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who hid behind me, but now she has met people from all over the world and gained confidence."
C. **Sarah Stokes, 12**  
Sarah started show-jumping at age 10 and has won the British National Championship. "It’s great that my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. The shows can last from one to five days. I never get tired of it; I love show-jumping events because they are exciting and fun. Even if my parents weren’t there, I would still do it because I am very determined. My goal this year is to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."
D. **Sarah's Mother**  
"From the moment Sarah sat on a horse at age 1, I knew she had found her passion. When she was 5, she would wake up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for big shows, we have to travel all over England. To save money, we sleep in the living area of our horse box. Sarah is very organized. She is always happy on a horse and knows what she is doing. Watching your child succeed at something they love is amazing."
E. **Jane McShane, 10**  
Jane is the Under-14 Chess Champion in Britain. "Tournaments are really friendly. I know everyone, and it’s fun. When I play, I don’t concentrate as much as I should. I just look around and don’t think too much. I’m not worried about being proud; I don’t talk about my success at school because I don’t like to feel embarrassed."
F. **Jane's Mother**  
"Jane played her first game when she was 5. My father said, 'Let’s see if she likes it.' He tried to teach me when I was young, but I was bored. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she had memorized all the moves, and by age 6, she was beating adults. When she wins, I am happy, but if she wanted to stop playing tomorrow, I would support her. I don’t want to hold her back because she is so talented. If she has this gift, I want her to reach her full potential."

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher that he wanted to join the navy after school. The teacher asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. 
Every ten years, the average height of people in Europe increases by one centimeter. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are going back to how we were as cavemen. We are losing the effects of many years of poor diet.
