Professor Chris Stringer, a palaeontologist, says, "We are starting to reach our true potential. We are becoming like Cro-Magnons, the people who lived 40,000 years ago."
For most of human history, our ancestors ate a variety of foods. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found that they ate 85 different wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, farming started, which changed everything. Farmers took over many green areas, and now just three plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories people eat today. This poor diet has harmed human health. 
In Ohio, scientists found that when they started to grow corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, which was thought to be good, turned out to be a health problem. However, farming spread because one piece of land could feed ten times more people than hunting could. 
Most people who rely on farming are still not well-nourished. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets starting to reflect the variety of our ancestors' diets again. Now, the average man in the US is 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a good trend, but it has its own problems. 
Even though people are getting taller, standard bed lengths have stayed at 190 cm since 1860. Legroom in planes and trains seems to have gotten smaller, and clothing companies have to change their products often. The question is: how tall can we get? 
According to Robert Fogel from a university, we could reach a height of 193 cm this century. But scientists say that while individuals may be getting taller because of better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were a bit rounder and taller to keep warm. Now that the climate is warmer, we seem to be getting thinner and shorter, even when we eat well. As the planet continues to warm, we may get even shorter. In other words, global warming could stop human growth.

Studio Audiences**
What is it like to be in the audience when a television show is being made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a common part of television, but many people do not understand them. When we watch game shows, we often wonder, "Who are these people?"
Some people think that studio audiences are not very important. I have heard that even people who work in television do not think highly of them. Some say they treat studio audiences "like cattle." I used to think that studio audiences were made up of silly people who wanted a moment of fame. However, there is no typical studio audience. They come from different backgrounds, jobs, and income levels. Television shows try to attract different types of people for different programs.
Many people who watch television at home do not understand why anyone would want to be in a studio audience. Why would someone apply for tickets, travel far, and sit for hours in a studio just to watch what they can see at home? One reason is that people hope to be on television for a moment. I did not believe this until I spoke to Angela. When I asked her why she came, she said, "It was a chance to appear on television." 
Another reason is that people are curious to see how a show is made. But the most common reason I heard was, "A friend gave me a ticket." Most of us have never been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it is like. You sit close to strangers while someone holds up signs that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you clap or laugh when told. This is true for some shows, but not all. As one studio manager said, "We always assume a show will be good enough not to need these signs."
Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching at home? For Claire, being in a studio is "more exciting," while Charlotte liked being part of live television. "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. When you watch him at home, you miss a lot." What I missed was seeing the live actors. From my seat, I could only see the back of someone’s head. The opening scenes were so far away that I ended up watching the show on a studio monitor.
Going to a studio may not be the best way to watch television, but that is not what matters. For most of the audience, it was just fun and a free night of entertainment.

Favourite Places**
**Bruce**  
I don’t like wild landscapes. I prefer places with people. When I travel, I enjoy lovely villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I would ride my bike to the village of Lastingham in its beautiful valley. Cycling helped me relax from school. I loved exploring the hills, valleys, and old villages. Coming from Scotland, I found the landscape both familiar and different, and I still visit there today. I used to write about my adventures in my diary. This was my first try at travel writing, which later became my career.
**Sophia**  
There is a small train that goes from Hythe to Dungeness, run by volunteers. I always travel first class because it doesn’t cost much more than the regular ticket. The scenery is not amazing. The train goes across Romney Marsh with its sheep and next to a canal. But there is one part of the journey I always look forward to - when the train goes through back gardens. For a few moments, we see people doing everyday things, like making tea or folding a chair. I see myself in their eyes, a woman in a small train carriage, looking into their homes. I like the simple landscape of fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. It makes me look more closely for something special.
**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a quiet and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to reach and have many rocks, so there are not many people here. A few brave surfers come, but most visitors enjoy the beauty of the sea. This coast, facing the Atlantic, is known for shipwrecks. There are walking paths along the coast that you can combine with trips into beautiful valleys full of oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in a simple self-catering place with a family in the village of Southole.
**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a wide-open moorland that is perfect for hiking. There are not many people living there or visiting. It is a quiet and remote area, and I like the feeling of space. I found this place by chance when I was a student, and I visit every year, either alone, with my boyfriend, or now with my son. It has not changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits more special. I feel sad that he is growing up in a city.
**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. I wanted peace and to reconnect with my English roots. I grew up in what is now Sri Lanka, but at twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and village streets. There was a story about a place we would never cycle past: if you went down the driveway, you would never return. That place was Glenthorne. It is my dream place. It is a magical, quiet, romantic house. You can only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**
We are 'animal people' who love all kinds of creatures. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work to tell me she had found a wonderful pine snake. "Can we keep him?" she asked excitedly. I said, "Yes, but only for one night." We had a special tank ready for animals like this, so we could admire it and look it up in our natural history book.
I got home late and quickly put a pot on to boil when I heard my sons screaming, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I rushed to their bedroom. The problem was with Domino the cat and Bianca the white mouse, which I had received as a Mother's Day gift. Domino was running around with the mouse in his mouth, trying to find a way out. I jumped into the chaos and tripped over something, falling to the floor. 
As I thought about how to stop Domino, I noticed the snake. It had escaped and was slithering off the table and onto the floor. I crouched down as the snake moved closer, while the kids and the cat were jumping around in a loud mess. The dog was barking, and the pot in the kitchen boiled over. I quickly turned off the gas and returned to the chaos with new energy. 
This time, I caught Domino by the tail and pulled the small, wet, and surprisingly unharmed mouse from his mouth. The same mouse was caught by Domino three more times in its life but eventually died of old age. Feeling encouraged, I looked at the snake, but it didn’t seem to have any weak points. 
In the end, I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer, rocking back and forth, but without a flute. Slowly, the snake relaxed and rested its head on its body, but its eyes still looked suspicious. I carefully placed my hands under the snake and stood up, walking to the end of the garden. I pointed the snake towards a tree, hoping it would live happily there.
When I finally let go of the snake's head, expecting it to bite me, it instead slid over my shoulders like a colorful shawl, making itself comfortable. We stood together in the fading light: four young children, Mum, and the snake. My eldest son, DJ, broke the silence with a funny comment: "You know what it is, Mum? You're nice and warm, and the shed isn't." 
I had the children gather at the snake's tail and gently encourage it to move on. Slowly, it did. Without looking back, the snake climbed up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last bit of its tail vanished, my three-year-old son Clay sighed and said what we were all thinking: "Boy, that was one big snake!"

'Write to Me!**
In our fast world of phones and computers, writing letters is at risk of disappearing. However, I believe that receiving a letter is special and cannot be replaced by other ways of communicating. There is excitement when a letter arrives, joy in seeing who it is from, and happiness in reading what it says.
I have been writing letters for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the little notes I wrote to my mother. She always made sure I wrote my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts. It didn’t matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters.
When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I wrote to my parents every week, and they wrote back to me. Sometimes my father wrote long, funny letters, which I loved. Most of the letters from home talked about everyday life with my parents and their friends. We also made phone calls, but I remember the letters the most.
I also received letters from my boyfriends. Many of them had to work or study far away, so we kept in touch by writing. Writing letters actually helped our relationships because I could express my feelings better in writing than by speaking.
I enjoy letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Short notes are nice, but it’s even better to get a lot of news! I love receiving letters from different places, like Mangala in Sri Lanka, a friend from training over 20 years ago, and penfriends in Australia and Vancouver. There is also a lady from France who writes to me. We started talking in a restaurant while on holiday, and I asked for her address. If she hadn’t replied, we would have missed out on a great friendship. Now, we write to each other regularly, and I can practice my French with her.
This summer, my family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was surprised that our friendship lasted so long, and the local newspaper even wrote about it!
I am happy that my children are continuing this tradition. Like my mother, I make sure they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did for my mother. She and my son have their own penfriends in Texas, set up by my penfriend.
I encourage everyone not to let letter writing become a lost art.'

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art**
Many ancient pictures carved into the rocks at one of France's important tourist sites are being slowly destroyed. Scientists are worried that the 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged so quickly that they may not last for future generations. The mountain is believed to have been a place for prayer and worship, and it has drawings that are 4,000 years old. These include pictures of cows, fields, and different gods and goddesses. However, as more people visit the site, the pictures are being ruined by careless graffiti.
Jean Clottes, the chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, says, "People think that because the pictures have been there for so long, they will always be there. But if the damage continues at this rate, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings, which wears away the rock and makes the artwork less clear. Some visitors even take pieces of the rock home as souvenirs. "When people cannot take a good photograph, they rub the drawings to make them look clearer," he said. "The drawings are already polished by the weather, and if the sun is shining and visitors cannot see them well, they rub and scrape them to make them look fresher."
Other researchers have seen people arrive with long sticks to scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks. Experts disagree on the best way to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, the director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, believes the only way to save the site is to make the whole mountain a "no-go" area, allowing the public to visit only on guided tours. He says that if this does not happen, the site will be completely destroyed, and important research will be lost.
Clottes disagrees. He thinks that Henry de Lumley's plan is too extreme and will upset local people. "The site was declared a historic monument by the Ministry of Culture, and we must do everything we can to save what is there," he said. David Lavergne, a regional architect, also wants to keep the site open. "Henry de Lumley's idea isn't ideal," he said. "Our department believes the best solution is to let people see the site, but it is hard to stop visitors from causing damage because the area is so large. I would prefer that everyone could visit, but the main problem is money. We do not have enough funds to hire enough guards. We may need to think about charging a fee. There seems to be no chance of government funding."
In Nice, Annie Echassoux, who also studied the site, is worried that as the mountain becomes easier to reach—tourists can now avoid a long walk by hiring vehicles—the damage will increase quickly. She believes the only solution is to block off the area and provide guides. "You can't say the plan can't happen because there is no money," she said. "That is not good enough. Money must be provided because the Ministry of Culture has classified this area as a historic site. If we do not take action, we will be responsible for losing the drawings for the next generation."

Young Shoppers**
Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it's not the latest sugary cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I can't afford all this, and if I give in to their requests, I feel guilty about buying unhealthy food. I hate saying no all the time, and I get stressed before we even leave home. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but then I worry that they are missing out on learning how to make choices. I feel stuck."
Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they go shopping. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising aimed at children, mostly on television. This amount is likely to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often do not understand why their parents say no to certain things, especially when they see attractive ads for sugary products. 
Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always correct. It is good for parents and children to talk about food. If children only hear about products from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they have to compete with advertising and often disappoint their children."
The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb points out, "The goal of advertising is to convince people to buy products. Even if they cannot say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."
Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to accept and which to refuse. One mother says she is patient when talking about food with her children, but she still feels unhappy about how she handles their requests: "My son pays attention to ads but is critical of them. We talk a lot about different products and look at labels together. I have talked so much that he thinks all ads are bad. Now, we have very little conflict in the supermarket because the children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."
Parents also admit they are sometimes inconsistent in their responses to their children's requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We refuse to buy sweets for him because they are bad for him, but we buy double cream and chocolate for ourselves. It is nice to buy good things, and it is normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on how I feel. If I am in a good mood, I am more likely to say yes. It is hard to be consistent."
Supermarkets could help reduce the conflict between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. Even if parents spend less money because their children are not with them, the idea of shopping without their children's demands could attract more customers.

Climbing Walls**
Climbers used to go to the mountains to climb. Now, you can find climbing walls both indoors and outdoors. The crowd watches closely. High above them on a climbing wall, hanging upside down by two fingers, is the French climber Francois Lombard. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at the National Indoor Arena in Birmingham. This arena is better known for the TV show Gladiators, but both events have one thing in common - The Wall.
The reason for these events is new technology that is developing quickly. Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs where there were good climbing spots. In winter, they had to deal with the cold, go for walks, or climb on snow and ice in Scotland. As the sport grew, it became important for climbers to stay fit. Since they could not use cliffs for much of the year, they started to climb on brick edges or stone buildings. This helped them keep their fingers strong and avoid getting bored.
Soon, many sports centers began to build climbing walls using special bricks. One of the first climbing walls was made by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher, in the mid-1960s at Leeds University. He created a wall with natural rock set in concrete. Many climbing walls like this were built in sports halls in the 1970s, but they had some problems. These walls could only be straight up and down, while real cliffs have different shapes like overhangs and slanted rocks. Once the walls were built, they could not be changed, and climbers would get tired of the same routes.
In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny created a new material that could be shaped like the rocks on cliffs. These shapes could be attached to any wall and removed when climbers wanted something new. French companies also started to make climbing panels on steel frames. Concrete was too heavy for making overhanging walls without a lot of work, but steel frames could be built anywhere. This system allowed climbers to have many different holds to choose from.

'So You Want to Be an Actor'**
If you tell someone that you want to be an actor, they will probably say it is a risky choice. Acting is indeed a risky career. There are many actors, but not enough jobs for all of them. When you decide to become an actor, some people you thought were your friends might think you are making a mistake, while others may support you. Everyone will give you different advice. It is a personal choice, and you are responsible for your own decisions and dreams. 
There are no easy ways to become an actor. There are no tests to pass, and even after training, there is no guarantee you will get a job. Success depends on luck and talent. However, there is always a need for new actors, and acting can bring excitement, glamour, and sometimes good money.
Many people ask what talent is. I think talent is a mix of natural skill and imagination, which is hard to measure. It also involves courage and belief in what you are doing. 
Why do people want to act? It can be hard to explain. In theater, the important moment is the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is what motivates actors to perform. If you ask successful actors how they achieved their success, they might not have a clear answer. They know some things about their skills and techniques, but they also understand that their success can change quickly. 
Disappointment is a big challenge for actors. Last month, you might have been without work, doing other jobs. Then, you might get a chance to audition for a role. But even if you want the job very much, you might not get it. Because of this, actors often avoid talking about their chances of getting a role. They find ways to cope with the stress of competition and the fear of rejection. No one likes to be rejected. 
From the moment you start auditioning, you are saying you are ready and hopefully talented enough for the job. In many ways, it is up to you. If you do not care enough about your acting, others may not care about you either.

**Food for All**
We are happy to share our special selection of the best cookbooks available now.
A. If you ask people to name a famous TV cook and writer, many will say Delia Smith. Her recipes come from many places around the world, and she loves exciting food. She also understands what the average cook can do in a normal kitchen. The book that made her famous is "Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course." This book is now a key reference for modern cooks. It gives simple but expert advice on basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of great recipes that are not boring. Recently updated, it answers the question: "If I could only have one cookbook, which would it be?"
B. Raymond Blanc took just 15 years to go from being an amateur chef to owning the most famous French restaurant in Britain. Now, with his first TV series called "Blanc Mange," he has a book with the same name. Raymond wants to help everyone become better cooks by showing how and why certain ingredients work together. He believes good cooking is easy when you understand what happens in the pan. The book has over 80 amazing recipes that show this. It is a practical guide that explains why some dishes can go wrong and includes some basic food science. Monsieur Blanc loves to cook for others, and this book shows he is very good at it.
C. Le Cordon Bleu is a name that represents the best in classical French cooking. For the past 100 years, expert chefs at this famous cooking school have trained students of all levels to achieve perfection. To celebrate its 100th anniversary, they have released a new book called "Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook," which includes 100 of the school's most respected recipes. Although these recipes are classics, they still feel fresh. Le Cordon Bleu has always supported traditional French cooking but has also changed to reduce rich, creamy sauces and calories. The book starts with basic kitchen skills and includes chapters on Appetisers, Main Dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe has step-by-step pictures and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from Cordon Bleu schools around the world have chosen a recipe they are famous for and shared their secrets.
D. Fast food? No way! Many people think good food takes a long time to cook. But Nigel Slater, the food editor of The Observer, disagrees. His new book, "The 30-Minute Cook," shows that fast food can be good. Nigel believes that when people come home tired and hungry, they want something good to eat quickly. He thinks it is possible to make something tasty in the time it takes to get a pizza delivered. In this new book, you will find many delicious recipes, and each one can be ready in just 30 minutes. Nigel has written over 200 recipes from around the world in his fun and enjoyable style. Just because he likes fast food doesn’t mean he doesn’t appreciate good food. If you think fast food can’t be great, try his recipes—they are simply delicious.

**A NEW LIFE**
**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in the business, I found that working in the City was no longer fun. I had planned to stay for another five or ten years, but then I lost my job unexpectedly. I didn’t get a great pay-off, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with one of the best restaurants in the country. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat online. I’m happy to be out of the office, but it’s surprising how little has changed: I still work 80 to 90 hours a week and sell a product."
**The Painter**  
Ron Able White was a manager in advertising, but now he makes a living as an artist. "I started painting as a hobby, but I found it much more exciting than my job. It made sense to take redundancy and become an artist. The career counselor I spoke to was very helpful. I think I was the first person to tell him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' He was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to find work quickly for money. My wife and I married young, and our children are grown, so we didn’t need to worry about that. We moved to the north of England, where we didn’t know anyone. It was hard to leave our friends, but we have been lucky; many of them visit us now."
**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was fun and I earned a lot of money, but the hours were very long. I realized I didn’t want to become a senior partner and work even more hours, so I left. Many people said I would get bored, but that has never happened. The key is to have deadlines. In fashion, there are always collections and new designs to work on, so I have to keep a strict schedule. I feel happier now and less stressed. However, I miss the social interaction with colleagues. What I love about this job is that I am fully responsible for my work. If I do a bad job, I am the one to blame. When you work for a company, you care, but when your name is on the product, you care even more."
**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I worked in financial markets from the age of 22, making deals. I liked the excitement, but I never found the work satisfying. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I left and traveled for a year instead. During that year, I thought about what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited some of the best gyms and talked to the owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took various massage courses. Then I got a part-time job at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my life. That is the best part."

A Winning Game**
Two brothers are discovering that their childhood game is great for business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, two bearded brothers in their forties, are sitting in their simple home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, and remembering their childhood. In front of them is a wooden board with round plastic pieces. They are playing the old game of pichenotte, which they say is special. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, a grocer from Quebec, Canada, brought the game to the USA and taught it to his family. Soon, every weekend and holiday, the family played the game and, as Dave says, "had the best time ever." Eventually, the family moved to New Mexico, but they did not forget Grandpa's pichenotte board, which he made from old wooden crates. They continued to play regularly. When visitors came, they were often curious because the game was unknown in the southern USA.
Three years ago, Dave set up the old pichenotte board and saw how cracked and worn it was. He decided to make a new one, which turned out to be beautiful. A relative saw it and wanted one, then a friend wanted another. Curious about the interest, one night the brothers took one of Dave's new boards to a sports bar in Santa Fe. "People started to watch," says Dave, "and said, 'No way I'm playing that silly game.' Then they'd sit down, and soon you couldn't get them up from the table!" When people asked about the game's origins, Dave did some research. He found that the roots were probably in India, where a similar game called 'carroms' exists. This game was adapted into 'squails,' played in British pubs, and British people brought it to Canada. Pichenotte is the French-Canadian version that developed in Quebec.
Pichenotte can be played by two to four people and is a game of skill. Each player gets 12 pieces or 'pucks.' These are flicked across a wheel-like board using one finger. Flicking a puck into a small hole is worth 20 points. There are three rings around the hole worth 15, 10, and 5 points, and eight small posts are obstacles. The game usually lasts about two minutes. When they saw how popular the game was at the Santa Fe bar, the Lagasses made more boards and took them to markets and craft fairs. Crowds gathered, money changed hands, and the game's popularity grew. Soon, championships began, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. As word spread, the boards sold quickly, and the brothers decided to start the pichenotte business full-time. They set up a workshop in their garage and began making boards. They have produced more than 450 boards so far. Made of birchwood and mahogany, each board weighs 12kg and is 1cm thick. Norm explains, "They're very durable, as they have to last a long time." They are available for $595 each on the brothers' website.
Currently, there are no professional pichenotte players or TV shows about the game. However, the day may come when the brothers' garage will have a luxury car instead of tools and wood. Until then, they are happy to spend their free time playing the game they hope will bring them success.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**
When you first enter the Model Village, it is hard to believe that a few years ago this was just a piece of empty land, flat and covered with weeds. For a long time, it was seen as useless land. The careful planning and hard work of one man, with the support of his wife, changed this land into the beautiful place you see today. Many tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat area into the lovely landscape you see now. Although machines helped to change the land, a lot of hard work was also needed.
Once the land was shaped, about 1,000 tons of topsoil were brought in to create the lawns, flower beds, and rock gardens. In building the Model Village, hundreds of trees and bushes were planted. These plants had to be chosen carefully for the area. Only plants that could survive the salty air near the sea were used. They also had to be strong enough to handle the strong winter winds. Most of the plants came from local garden centers, but some were brought from as far away as Canada and New Zealand.
The whole village was created by Colin Sims, who made over 100 models by himself over nine years after the village opened in 1972. The models are made from different materials like stone, concrete, treated wood, and plastic to resist all kinds of weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts who taught him how different materials would last through changing weather. But soon, he became an expert himself.
You will notice that everything is built to the same scale, and even the smallest details on the models have been carefully made. This was done with patience and special building techniques. The Model Village is a very popular place and is known for its high quality and care. The methods used to create these realistic models have been used in other model villages in England and have even been included in some college courses about modeling.
All the buildings you will see in the village show traditional British styles and are not based on one specific place. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House. This is a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower and stone walls, based on manor houses found in the West Country. As you walk around the village, you will also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest addition to the village.
We ask you to stay on the paths during your visit and not to touch any of the models; if you accidentally break something, it can take us a long time to fix it. You can take photos from the pathways only. Dogs are welcome on a short lead.
To make your visit more enjoyable, you will see buttons in front of some of the working models. Press these buttons to make the models move. At the end of your visit, we would love to hear your comments. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us create a more interesting display. We also want to know if there are any models that you think need improvement. We are always replacing and updating the models, and we need to know which ones need attention.
We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Don't forget to tell your friends about it!

Every week, British tabloid newspapers publish pictures that invade people's privacy and break the rules set by newspaper editors. While some pop stars do pose for photographers sometimes, this is not common. More often, serious harm is done to famous people when their private moments are shown on the front page. Very few of them ask for help from the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which was created to handle these problems. These pictures are rarely in the public interest. For example, do private photos of pop stars help solve a crime? How did a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony help public health and safety? The actress has complained about long-distance photos before, and since she was in a hotel, where people expect privacy, she had a good reason to complain, but she did not take any action. It is a scandal that the PCC did not start an investigation. The PCC should also look into a recent shocking story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star has not made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action on this and other unfair stories? 
This seems like a good idea. It could lead to many decisions against newspapers. These decisions would be reported by other newspapers and shown on TV and radio. The public would not support these newspapers, and editors would have to stop publishing such stories. Photographers would also be affected, as they would no longer be able to hide and take pictures of celebrities. If the PCC decided to act like a "police officer," there would be some problems. How would it decide to start an investigation? Should it talk to the victim and encourage them to complain? And if the person still did not want to do anything, should the PCC still act? Also, celebrities and royal family members might expect that any story about them would be investigated, and they could be upset if it wasn’t. 
The job of the PCC is very big. How could it monitor all of the British press: national, local, and magazines? There is also the issue of embarrassment. Even if someone's privacy is invaded, would they want the added embarrassment of an investigation? Many people just want to forget about it and move on with their lives. Some might have other reasons to stay quiet. They might have a worse story that they want to keep secret, and they know that complaining could make it public. In this way, the PCC could also become a problem for them. 
One British comedian faced issues with the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He did not complain then, and he also did not complain when he and his family were photographed during a holiday. He was afraid that the newspaper, News of the World, would publish the pictures again with a new story about his anger, saying they thought it was just a joke and that, as a comedian, he would have a sense of humor. This fear is understandable. People think they will be targeted again if they challenge the tabloids. It is hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem. 
**Questions:**
1. What do British tabloid newspapers often publish that invades people's privacy?
2. Why do very few famous people complain to the Press Complaints Commission (PCC)?
3. What is one example given in the text of a situation where a famous person might feel their privacy was invaded?
4. What could happen if the PCC decided to take action against newspapers?
5. Why did the British comedian not complain about being photographed on his honeymoon?

There is a lot of advice for college graduates who are starting their first job. In this article, we will talk about moving to a second job. We are not talking about people looking for a temporary job while they search for a permanent one. We also will not discuss those who leave a job they do not like within the first few weeks. Instead, we will focus on those of you who are ready to take a real step in your career. You have learned some skills and have an idea of what you want to do next.
What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. You need to think about whether you want to specialize in a certain area, move up to a job with more responsibility, or change to a different field. Whatever you choose, you should be careful when picking your second job. You should plan to stay in this job for two to three years. Future employers will look closely at this job when you apply for your next one. It should show that you have thought seriously about your career. Most importantly, it should help you grow, develop your skills, and give you more responsibilities.
If you want to travel, now is a good time to do it. You can work temporarily when you come back and then find your second job. Future employers will be happy to see that you have traveled and are not likely to leave again soon.
Juliette Davidson spent her first year after leaving St. Aldate's College working for three lawyers. It was a good first job because they were very supportive. She learned how to work in an office and improved her typing skills. However, there was no chance for promotion. One day, she decided to leave, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year.
Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. She says, "In two and a half years, I have become more skilled, and my job has really changed. From the start, my boss wanted to help me grow. My job title is the same as when I started, but my tasks have changed. I now do most of the correspondence and budgets, and I handle questions from company chairmen to people wanting to start their own business. Brenda includes me in all her work and also gives me specific projects and events to organize."

'What is the Secret of Confident People?'**
Confident people may seem like they were born that way, but most will say it is a skill they learned. Nina Hathway asks five people how they became confident.
**A. Jenny**  
When I left school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. When I was about twenty-five, I helped at my daughter's school. I was nervous, but I did well, and someone suggested I take a university course. On my first day, I was very anxious, but my confidence grew over time. Working at the school changed my life and helped me become more outgoing.
**B. Michaela**  
Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to take over the family business. I was scared and became a bit too aggressive. I thought that was how confident people acted, but I learned that to be confident, you must believe in yourself. If work gets too hard, I don’t feel guilty about leaving some tasks for the next day. When I face something difficult, I remind myself that I have nothing to lose. Fear can make you feel less confident, so I talk to myself to calm those fears.
**C. Lisa**  
People think I am very confident, but I often feel scared inside. I learned to look confident because it is important in my job on TV. Interviewing people showed me that many of us feel nervous in important situations. The best advice I got was from my mother when I worried about my clothes as a teenager. She said, "Who is looking at you? Everyone is too busy worrying about themselves." I also believe you gain confidence by facing your fears. I was very nervous during my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt I could handle anything.
**D. Barbara**  
My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but I have built it up over the years. If you keep working and learn from your mistakes, you will feel more confident next time. I work hard and am liked at the restaurant, but not everyone will like you. You must like yourself for who you are, not try to be what others want. My company offers training courses, which have helped my self-esteem. It is good to set small goals so you can see your progress instead of trying to do everything at once.
**E. Kim**  
After college, I worked as a secretary and often sat in meetings without speaking up. Eventually, I found the confidence to share my thoughts. When I started working in politics, I had never spoken in public and would shake with nerves. I told myself, "Don’t be silly. People do this every day, so you can too." I also found it helpful to write down a few notes to refer to, like a comfort blanket! I believe everyone feels a bit nervous when speaking in public. The real secret to confidence is to keep telling yourself, "Nothing is impossible."

**Visit to Malaysia**
Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival and spends a nervous night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled as I gave him his torn kite. "You have to keep it," he said, "it's traditional. If the line breaks, finders keepers... and anyway, I have many more." He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All were 120 cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and bamboo. We sat in the shade of the tall trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan and looked at Malaysia's biggest kite festival. 
In the center of the beach, there were 10 platforms where helpers held up the kites. A row of nervous competitors held the lines of their kites and waited for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites flew into the air like rockets. More than 500 men and boys had signed up for the competition, which lasts for five days every year. Each person entered four different kite designs, which were judged on decoration, stability in the air, and flying ability. 
"Flying kites isn't so hard," said Adnan, "but making them takes real skill. Visit me at home, and I'll show you how." I received five invitations that day, and I decided to accept his. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a large room. As night fell, he asked me to come back the next day to help rebuild his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur, into mountains covered with thick rainforest. 
I took a wrong turn, and the smooth road ended at a river. A small boat was waiting to take people across. Nearby, I saw a sign that pointed up a path into the forest and said: "Jelawang Jungle 3 km." Before I started, it would have been good to know that most of this distance was uphill, steep, and slippery. When I reached the track, I found a man named Baba waiting with a flask of tea. He took care of a kitchen and a few bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about insects crawling under my thin mattress. 
The night was very dark and full of different sounds. A waterfall roared nearby, and many creatures moved and squeaked. In the morning, there was a great view over five ranges of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, the wind blew, then lightning struck the treetops. Seconds later, I was soaked. Sliding downhill, I wondered how the giant butterflies avoided the heavy rain. I also worried about my car being washed away (it sometimes happens) and the chance of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, my car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the track. 
In Kota Bahru, the capital of Kelantan, everyone asked me questions: "Where are you from?" "How old are you?" But they were friendly. Kelantan is known for its kites, but I remember it more for the kindness of its people.

What Kind of Shopper Are You?**
We all go shopping, but we do it in different ways. Do you know what kind of shopper you are? Abby Edwards asked some people about their shopping habits.
A. **Melanie, 22, dancer**  
I love shopping! I can't spend enough money. When I have cash, I go shopping and feel happy. I find it hard to walk past sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often go shopping together. We are both addicted to shopping!
B. **Brenda, 40, office manager**  
I don’t like shopping much. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he likes. I don’t spend much time shopping for clothes. I take my son and daughter shopping, but we all have different tastes, so it’s not fun. I don’t buy things for myself often, and when I do, I feel guilty and tell my husband I spent less money than I really did.
C. **Juliet, 28, personnel manager**  
I only shop for what I need. I really dislike shopping and only go when I have to. When I do go, I know exactly what I want and won’t buy anything else. Shopping makes me tired, and I would rather be doing something else.
D. **Anita, 35, TV producer**  
I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don’t waste time and try to shop quickly. However, I have bought things I didn’t really need, so maybe I’m careful but sometimes make mistakes.
E. **Lizzie, 41, secretary**  
I really don’t enjoy shopping. I dislike shopping for clothes because I can never find what I want or get help. The shops are too noisy and messy, which makes it a nightmare for me. Luckily, I don’t have to shop for clothes often because I get most of my clothes for free. For food, I go to the supermarket once a week and do it quickly.
F. **Lisa, 22, actress**  
I think I’m a happy shopper. Sometimes I go shopping with my friends, and we often end up buying things. I don’t usually go with a specific item in mind, but if I see something I like, I buy it.
G. **Suki, 26, art gallery assistant**  
I’m a careful shopper. I enjoy shopping, but I don’t buy a lot. I usually know what I want and don’t spend too much. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but then I often feel worse because I spent too much money.
H. **Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker**  
I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it’s too busy. I’m a careful shopper. I usually have an idea of what I want and don’t buy things right away. I like to check other shops to find better deals, which takes me a long time.
I. **Linda, 32, restaurant manager**  
I don’t like shopping much. Since I work in the city center, shopping is not exciting for me anymore. When I have to shop, I don’t try things on because it’s too much trouble. The clothes I buy don’t always fit, but I don’t mind too much. I prefer to make a few mistakes than spend a lot of time in shops.
